XLO v XLP

XLO v XLP
[2025] SGFC 48

Case Number:Summons No 1206 of 2024
Decision Date:30 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Mohamed Fazal Bin Abdul Hamid (I.R.B Law LLP) for the complainant; The respondent in person.
Parties: XLO — XLP

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection

30 April 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       The Complainant and the Respondent are sisters. The Complainant is 44 years old this year. The Respondent is 50 years old this year. The Complainant and the Respondent live separately. The Complainant lives with her son, though her parents and her other sisters sometimes live with her.

2       On 26 June 2024, the Complainant applied for a personal protection order (“PPO”) against the Respondent. On 19 July 2024, the Respondent applied for a personal protection order against the Complainant. I heard both applications together and dismissed both. The Complainant has filed an appeal against my decision to dismiss her application. As the Respondent did not file any appeal against my decision to dismiss hers, this decision will focus on my reasons for dismissing the Complainant’s application.

The Complainant’s case

3       In the Complainant’s complaint form (the “Complaint Form”), she claimed that the Respondent caused hurt to her, placed her in fear of hurt, and continually harassed her. The Complainant primarily relied on an incident on 24 June 2024 to support her application.

4       The Complainant’s recount of the incident on 24 June 2024 is, in brief, as follows:

(a)     The Complainant had just stepped out of her room after a shower and was surprised to see the Respondent sitting in the dining area of her home. The Respondent did not inform the Complainant that she would be there.[note: 1]

(b)     The Respondent then started threatening the Complainant. The Respondent brought up the fact of the Complainant’s recent divorce from her former husband, saying “that is why your ex-spouse and you have to divorce because you are like this.”[note: 2] The Respondent started taking a video of the Complainant using her phone. This agitated the Complainant, who asked the Respondent to stop. The Respondent refused to stop, saying “I want to see how you’re so angry.”[note: 3] The Respondent called the Complainant’s son, to ask him to look at the Complainant.[note: 4]

(c)     The Complainant saw her mother packing her belongings into her luggage and noticed that she had taken a teeth retainer belonging to one of her sister’s daughters. The Complainant told her mother to remove this from her luggage. When she did not comply, the Complainant removed this from the luggage herself using her right hand.[note: 5]

(d)     The Respondent and her mother then tried to stop the Complainant. The Respondent tried to grab the teeth retainer and hurt the Complainant in the process. After the Respondent successfully took away the teeth retainer from the Complainant, the Complainant freed herself.[note: 6]

Legal requirements

5       The definition of ‘family violence’ is set out in Section 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) (the “Charter”). This includes the commission of the following acts:

(a)    wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)    causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

…

(d)    causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member

…

6       Section 64 of the Charter also defines ‘hurt’ as “bodily pain, disease and infirmity”.

7       Section 65(1) of Charter 1961 provides that the court may grant a PPO if two requirements have been met. First, the court must be satisfied that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed. Second, the court must be satisfied that a protection order is necessary for the protection of that family member. The burden of proof is on the Complainant to prove that these two requirements have been met on a balance of probabilities.

My decision

8       On the balance of the evidence before me, I was not satisfied that the Respondent had committed family violence on the Complainant, or that the Respondent was likely to commit family violence on the Complainant.

Did the Respondent cause the Complainant hurt?

9       The Complainant claimed that the physical altercation caused her soreness on her right arm, scratches on her palm and wrist, and a bruise near her thumb. These injuries could constitute “hurt”, as defined in Section 64 of the Charter. The Complainant adduced five pictures showing a wound on her right palm and marks around her right hand.[note: 7] She also adduced a memo with a referral letter, certifying that the Complainant had visited a clinic on 26 June 2024 for “right shoulder strain and superficial abrasion over right wrist and palm”.[note: 8]

10     The evidence provided by the Complainant may have shown that the Complainant did suffer some injuries, but it did not necessarily establish that it was the Respondent who caused her these injuries. It remained unclear from the evidence who caused the injuries and how they were caused:

(a)     There was no evidence advanced by the Complainant to show that the Respondent was responsible for the injuries, bearing in mind that the tussle over the teeth retainer (that the Complainant says led to the hurt) was a tussle that involved three persons. There was also a lack of detail and description, whether in her Complaint Form, her affidavit, or from her oral evidence, to explain just how the Respondent had caused her the injuries she claimed. Even the referral form issued by the clinic she visited on 26 June 2024 stated that the Complainant was “uncomfortable to elaborate more other than she was pushed”.[note: 9]

(b)     During cross-examination, when asked about the cause of the blister on her palm, the Complainant was initially reserved in levelling any accusation that it was the Respondent who directly caused her injuries. Instead, her response was more oblique and general, saying that it was caused by the “commotion … by the physical interaction that was---came towards [her] while the Respondent is trying to take the teeth retainer from [her] palm.”[note: 10] The Respondent in fact did not seem certain as to the cause of the blister, saying that she “suspect[ed]” that it was from a sharp nail.[note: 11]

(c)     While the Complainant complained of a pain on her upper arm and suggested that this was caused during her physical altercation with the Respondent[note: 12], she had, in her Complaint Form, also conceded that this was because she “just had [her] covid booster on 7th June.”[note: 13] This cast doubt over whether the Respondent was responsible for the pain that the Complainant felt in her upper arm.

11     Further, I note that there were some inconsistencies in the Complainant’s evidence, which in my view diminished the credibility and likelihood of the Complainant’s claims relating to her injuries:

(a)     In her Complaint Form, the Complainant accused the Respondent of “hurting [the Complainant’s] palm with scratches and bruise on [her] right hand”.[note: 14] However, in C1, which contained the Complainant’s fleshed-out evidence, the Complainant did not mention being scratched by the Respondent at all.

(b)     In C1, the only acts of physical contact alleged were that the Respondent pushed the Complainant when trying to snatch the teeth retainer from her, and that the Respondent had restrained her (implied in the Complainant’s claim that she had to “free [herself]” from the Respondent). However, there was no suggestion on the Complaint Form that the Respondent pushed the Complainant or tried to restrain her. It is also noted that the nature of family violence complained of by the Complainant was not that of physical restraint.

12     On the evidence before me, I therefore found that the Complainant was unable to prove that the Respondent had caused her the hurt she claimed to have suffered.

Did the Respondent place the Complainant in fear of hurt?

13     The Complainant did not articulate in what way she had been placed in fear of hurt. While she suggests in C1 that she had to “break free”[note: 15] from the Respondent, there was no indication that the Respondent had intended to hurt her, such that she should have been afraid of being hurt if she had not freed herself. This is especially so where on the face of the Complainant’s evidence, the Respondent appeared focused on taking the teeth retainer away from the Complainant, rather than on specifically inflicting or threatening to inflict any sort of hurt on the Complainant.[note: 16]

14     The Complainant also mentioned being ‘threatened’ by the Respondent[note: 17]. However, there were no details as to what was said, or what were the threads made by the Respondent. There also did not appear to be any history of the Respondent threatening to hurt the Complainant, nor was there any suggestion that the Respondent was predisposed to inflict violence, such as to give the Complainant cause for such concern.

15     I therefore did not find sufficient evidence to establish that the Respondent had placed the Complainant in fear of hurt.

Did the Respondent continually harass the Complainant?

16     The Complainant claims to have been traumatised by the Respondent’s unannounced entry into her home. The Respondent had not given the Complainant any prior notice that she would be there, and the Complainant was surprised to see the Respondent in her home.

17     I did not find the Respondent’s entry into the Complainant’s home in itself to have placed the Complainant in fear of hurt (given the absence of any threat of hurt), or to amount to continual harassment for the purposes of establishing family violence. Both the Respondent and her mother each had a key to the Complainant’s home, and there was also no evidence that the Complainant had asked the Respondent to return her house keys prior to the incident. This suggests that the Complainant did not consider them to be persons whom she was afraid of and whom she could not trust with access to her home.

18     Furthermore, the Respondent did not enter the Complainant’s home by force, nor did she do so without reason. It was evident that she was there to accompany her mother, who was there to pack her belongings which were left in the Complainant’s home. In this context, it did not seem to me that the Respondent had appeared in the Complainant’s home with the intent of causing her anguish. In fact, it is unclear to me whether the Respondent would even have known that her presence in the house would have caused the Complainant anguish. I therefore did not find the Respondent’s entry into the Complainant’s home, as unwelcome as it may have been, to amount to continual harassment.

19     The Respondent had also allegedly made hurtful remarks to the Complainant about her relationship with her ex-husband, started taking a video of the Complainant, and asked the Complainant’s son to look at her while she was angry. Taken at face value, I accept that such acts could be provocative and aggravating. However, I did not find these claims to have been established on the evidence presented. In any case, the law requires that any harassment must be continual (see Yue Tock Him @ Yee Chok Him v Yee Ee Lim [2011] SGDC 99 at [43]); that is, the act must be repeated or repetitive (see XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [6(d)(ii)]). I did not consider any harassment that may have been caused to the Complainant to be continual, bearing in mind that there was no suggestion or proof of that the Respondent had previously provoked the Complaint in similar fashion.

20     I therefore did not find the Respondent to have committed family violence against the Complainant by way of continual harassment.

Conclusion

21     Having found no family violence committed by the Respondent, I consequently declined to grant the PPO sought by the Complainant.

22     For completeness, even if I were to find that the Respondent had inflicted family violence on the Complainant (which I did not in this case), I would not have found a protection order to be necessary for the protection of the Complainant. In my view, the tussle on 24 June 2024 was a one-off incident between the parties that started when the Complainant removed a teeth retainer from her mother’s luggage. It was her mother who first intervened to stop the Complainant, before the Respondent intervened. There does not appear to have been any other incident between them, whether before or after this incident, whether within the Complainant’s home, or anywhere else. It was also the Complainant’s position that the Respondent never entered her home before this incident, even though the Respondent held a key to her home, which suggests a low probability of the circumstances on 24 June 2024 repeating itself. I also noted that between the hearing on 27 November 2024 and 13 January 2025, the Respondent returned her copy of the Complainant’s home key to the Complainant.

23     In any event, I also noted that it was the Complainant’s own evidence that her interaction with the Respondent was limited at best. The Complainant’s evidence was that the parties were not close to each other, and that if at all, they only communicate to arrange for the Respondent’s daughter to give tuition to the Complainant’s son, which the Respondent’s daughter had been doing since March 2024.[note: 18] The Complainant said that the parties would cross paths with each other during family gatherings such as Chinese New Year, however I find the incidence of any family violence during such group settings to be unlikely. I therefore found the risk of the Respondent committing family violence against the Complainant in future to be low or non-existent, and that a PPO would therefore have been unnecessary.

24     As neither party made any request for costs, I made no order as to costs.

html:
XLN v XLM

XLN v XLM
[2025] SGFC 47

Case Number:Maintenance Summons No 1289 of 2024, (Registrar's Appeal No 12 of 2025)
Decision Date:29 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Sheela Kumari Devi
Counsel Name(s): Complainant- in- person; Respondent- in- person.
Parties: XLN — XLM

Family Law – Maintenance – Stay of proceedings – Forum non conveniens

29 April 2025

District Judge Sheela Kumari Devi:

Introduction

1       The parties (whom I will refer to as the “Wife” and the “Husband”) are Indian nationals. They had their traditional marriage on 16 November 2016 in India and registered their marriage in India on 16 September 2019. Parties moved to Singapore in mid-2019. Their child was born in India on 21 June 2022 (the “Child”).

2       The parties’ marriage was fraught with difficulties leading to the Wife moving out of the parties’ rental flat together with the Child and commencing divorce proceedings in Singapore via Divorce Suit No. 5293 of 2023 (“D 5293”) on 2 November 2023. The Wife also filed the present maintenance proceedings for wife and child maintenance (“MSS 1289”) and an application for a personal protection order for herself via SS 1057 of 2024 (“SS 1057”) against the Husband on 4 June 2024.

3       For context, the Husband applied to stay D 5293 on the ground of forum non conveniens citing that India was the better forum. The Husband also commenced divorce proceedings in India. The Husband’s stay application was allowed by the learned Deputy Presiding Judge Chia Wee Kiat on 30 December 2024 and no appeal was filed by the Wife against the same. The parties’ divorce proceedings are on-going in India.

4       Both parties acted in person. At the hearing of MSS 1289 and SS 1057 on 17 December 2024, the Husband orally applied to stay both proceedings on the basis of forum non conveniens. I heard the applications on 24 February 2025 and dismissed both applications. The Husband has filed a Notice of Appeal against my decision in respect of MSS 1289. I shall now set out my brief reasons for dismissing the Husband’s application to stay MSS 1289.

Affidavits filed by the parties

5       Parties filed the following affidavits in respect of the stay application for MSS 1289:

(a)     the Husband’s affidavit filed on 20 December 2024 (“R1”);

(b)     the Wife’s affidavit filed on 30 December 2024 (“C1”);

(c)     the Wife’s affidavit filed on 12 February 2025 (“C2”); and

(d)     the Husband’s affidavit filed on 16 February 2025 (“R2”).

The parties’ cases

6       The Husband’s case was set out in R1 and R2.

7       In summary, the Husband’s case was as follows:

(a)     India is the more appropriate forum for hearing the maintenance proceedings and ancillary matters.

(b)     The Singapore court has found that India is the better forum to decide on the issues related to the divorce including the ancillary matters such as maintenance. The outcome of the stay application in D 5293 is binding on the MSS court.

(c)     The Wife can apply for interim maintenance in India immediately.

(d)     Allowing MSS 1289 to proceed would be inconsistent with the outcome of the stay application in D 5293 that Singapore is not the appropriate forum to deal with the ancillary matters. Further, if the Singapore Court grants interim maintenance, it will interfere with the Indian divorce proceedings and complicate the overall financial adjudication.

(e)     There are ongoing divorce proceedings in India and an application for interim maintenance can be made immediately.

(f)     The parties have never intended to permanently settle in Singapore. As such, given their temporary status, it would be inappropriate for the Singapore Court to assume jurisdiction over long-term matters such as spousal maintenance, which should be decided in India, which is their home country.

(g)     There is no urgency for interim maintenance as the Wife has financial resources.

8       The Wife’s case was set out in C1 and C2.

9       In summary, the Wife’s case was as follows:

(a)     R1 only addresses why the divorce proceedings should not continue in Singapore and does not address why MSS 1289 should not proceed in Singapore.

(b)     The parties and the Child have no plans to relocate to India. The Wife has been staying in Singapore since November 2019 and now holds an employment pass on the basis of her employment. The Child is also studying in Singapore. The Husband has been working in the same office in Singapore for the past 4.5 years and has not indicated anywhere in his affidavit of his immediate intention to resign his job and go to India to work.

(c)     The Wife and the Child’s monthly expenses are being incurred and will continue to be incurred in Singapore. It is therefore better that the Singapore Courts assess how much they should both be entitled to for maintenance from the Husband. Further, if the Husband fails to pay maintenance, the Wife can go to the Singapore courts for aid and assistance in enforcement.

(d)     The Wife will suffer severe prejudice if a stay is granted as the Indian Courts do require quite a number of hearings to be attended to in person. The Wife will have to travel to India with the Child and engage Indian lawyers to assist her.

Issues to be determined

10     The applicable test to determine if a proceeding commenced in Singapore ought to be stayed on the ground of forum non conveniens is set out in Spiliada Maritime Corporation v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460 (the “Spiliada test”). As such, the issues that I was to decide on as per the Spiliada test were as follows:

(a)     Whether there was another available forum which was clearly or distinctly more appropriate than Singapore to determine the dispute as per stage one of the Spiliada test.

(b)     If there was another available forum which was prima facie more appropriate than Singapore, whether there were any special circumstances existing to warrant the exercise of the Court’s discretion to refuse a stay as per stage two of the Spiliada test.

11     In relation to the first issue, my finding was that Singapore is the most appropriate forum to determine the issue of interim maintenance. As such there was no need for me to go on to make to a finding on the second issue.

12     I set out my reasons for my findings on the first issue below.

Issue: Whether Singapore was the most appropriate forum?

13     The Spiliada test is essentially a factors-based test: the weight to be placed on the various factors varies with each factual matrix. What may prove to be critical in one case might not be that important in another. However, as noted by the High Court in BDA v BDB [2013] 1 SLR 607 (“BDA”) at [24], residence appears to be an important factor:

“Thus, where a defendant seeking a stay is working and residing in Singapore, there lies a greater evidential burden on him: the countervailing factors adduced in favour of the stay have to be correspondingly more convincing, in comparison to the hypothetical factual matrix, ceteris paribus, where the defendant is not resident in Singapore.”

14     In BDA, the parties were similarly Indian nationals and the wife had also made a s. 69 application for maintenance. The husband was resident in and employed in Singapore. The wife and the child were previously residing in Singapore but had left for India before the s. 69 application was filed. Parties were Singapore permanent residents. The husband commenced divorce proceedings in India shortly after the s. 69 application was filed. On appeal, the High Court dismissed the husband’s stay application. The Court noted, that the wife had instituted the maintenance application in Singapore, where the husband resided and worked. The Court also noted that the pending divorce proceedings instituted by the husband in India was not for the same relief as that claimed by the wife in her s. 69 maintenance application in Singapore. The former would result in the termination of the marriage, with the wife being entitled to apply for post-divorce maintenance while the latter was premised on the subsistence of the marriage.

15     In the instant case, the parties and the Child are presently residing in Singapore. While parties and the Child are Indian nationals, nationality per se is of limited significance as noted by the High Court in BDA at [29]. Parties are working in Singapore on their respective employment passes and are earning income from their work here. The Child is also presently enrolled in nursery in Singapore. The relevant living expenses of the Wife and the Child are incurred in Singapore. The marriage still subsists. If the matter is heard in India, both parties would have to travel from Singapore to India to attend to this.

16     While the Husband contends that parties’ stay in Singapore was temporary in nature and could be terminated at any point if their respective employment passes were not renewed, I did not think this was a strong factor to grant a stay as there was no evidence put before me that suggested that parties were at imminent risk of losing their jobs or that their employment passes would be terminated. In any event, should circumstances change, parties may make the appropriate application (if necessary) to vary and/or rescind any maintenance orders that have been made in Singapore.

17     Further, any maintenance order made in MSS 1289 would be temporary in nature for the following reasons:

(a)     Any spousal maintenance order made in MSS 1289 would cease to operate once the divorce proceedings have concluded in India and the Wife ceases to be a “wife” married to the Husband under the Women’s Charter.

(b)     The child maintenance order would also be superseded by any ancillary orders made by the Indian Court in relation to child maintenance.

18     I also did not agree with the Husband that there was an issue of lis alibi pendens arising. The pending divorce proceedings instituted by the Husband in India (which deals with reliefs arising post-termination of marriage) was not for the same relief as that claimed by the Wife in the present maintenance application in Singapore. MSS 1289 (at least in respect of the Wife’s claim for spousal maintenance) is premised on the subsistence of the marriage and any child maintenance order made in Singapore in these proceedings would similarly be overtaken by the ancillary orders made by the Indian Court. Thus, both proceedings are distinct and do not cover the same grounds.

19     I also address the Husband’s argument that the decision made by the learned Deputy Presiding Judge to stay the Singapore divorce proceedings in D 5293 was binding on this Court. Firstly, no legal basis was put forward as why the outcome of the stay application in D 5293 would be binding on this court. Secondly, the granting of the Husband’s stay application in D 5293 meant that Singapore was not the appropriate forum to deal with the divorce and ancillary issues. However, as stated above, the issues being raised in the application in MSS 1289 were not covering the same ground as the divorce proceedings in India. Finally, the Husband’s argument that any maintenance orders made in MSS 1289 would interfere with the Indian divorce proceedings and complicate the overall financial adjudication was not convincing. There were no specifics provided by the Husband beyond this bare assertion.

20     Ultimately, as stated by the Court in BDA, two questions must be addressed by the court in a s 69 application. First, the wife must show that she needs maintenance and that the husband has neglected or refused to provide reasonable maintenance for her and any child of the marriage. Second, the court will have to determine the quantum required for maintenance. On the first question, the court in Singapore is as well placed as any other to decide on the issue. As regards the second question, it would appear that the Singapore Court would be better placed to decide on this issue. First, the parties and the Child are presently residing in Singapore. Second, in determining the quantum of maintenance, the court shall have to take into account the standard of living enjoyed by the Wife and the Child before the Husband’s neglect or refusal to maintain them (see s 69(4)(f) of the Women’s Charter) and the present maintenance that they require. These determinations would be based on their expenses incurred in Singapore since they have been and are presently residing in Singapore. In this regard, the Singapore court would have an advantage over the Indian court in making these determinations.

Conclusion

21     For the reasons set out above, I find that the Husband has not discharged the burden of showing that India is clearly or distinctly a more appropriate forum. Therefore, based on stage one of the Spiliada test, MSS 1289 should not be stayed. There is then no need to go on to consider stage two of the Spiliada test.

22     The Husband’s application to stay the proceedings in MSS 1289 is dismissed.

XLJ v XLK

XLJ v XLK
[2025] SGFC 42

Case Number:Originating Summons (Guardianship of Infants Act 1934) No 77/2024, FC/Summons 3478/2024
Decision Date:30 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Muhammad Hidhir Bin Abdul Majid
Counsel Name(s): Cornelius Sng (Advox Law LLC) for the Applicant in OSG 77 /2024 and Respondent in Summons 3478/2024; Respondent in person in OSG 77/2024 and Applicant in Person in Summons 3478/2024
Parties: XLJ — XLK

Family Law – Guardianship – Welfare of child

Family Law – Custody – Care and Control – Access

30 April 2025

District Judge Muhammad Hidhir Bin Abdul Majid:

Introduction

1       Originating Summons (Guardianship of Infants Act 1934) No 77/2024 (“OSG 77”) was an application filed by the Applicant (“Mother”) on 18 June 2024 under section 5 of the Guardianship of Infants Act 1934 for sole custody, care and control of the child and for the Respondent (“Father”) to take all required steps to facilitate the handing over of the child to the Mother. The Mother also applied for the Father to surrender the child's passport to the Mother or to her solicitors forthwith.

2       The Mother alleged the Father had unlawfully removed the child from her lawful custody in China and eventually brought the child into Singapore. He had also refused to return the child to the Mother though she was granted custody of the child by the Chinese Courts.

3       Pending the final determination of OSG 77, the Mother filed for an injunction in Summons No 1903/2024 to prevent the Father from bringing the child out of Singapore without the Mother’s written consent or an Order of Court. An injunction was granted to prevent both parties from removing the child out of Singapore without the consent of the Court or the written consent of the other parent.

4       On 7 November 2024, the Father filed Summons 3478/2024 (“Summons 3478”) for orders that:

I)     The parties have joint custody of the child.

II)     The Mother have care and control of the child, on the condition that the Father shall have liberal access, including overnight and overseas access, to the child as follows:

Regular Access

(a)       On weekdays, the Father have access on at least two weekdays a week, with specific timings to be mutually agreed by parties in writing and in advance.

(b)       The Father have access during the weekends, from Saturday after lunch to Sunday after lunch, with specific timings to be mutually agreed by parties in writing and in advance.

Specific Access

(c)       In addition to the regular access, both parties shall endeavour to celebrate the child’s birthday together as a family at such date/time to be mutually agreed in writing and in advance. In the event parties are unable to reach an agreement, the Father have access to the child on his birthday from after lunch until after dinner to celebrate the child’s birthday.

(d)       The Father have access to the child for half of the child’s school holidays, with specific dates and times to be mutually agreed by parties in writing and in advance. In the event parties are unable to reach an agreement, the Father shall have access to the child on the first half of the school holidays and the Mother shall spend time with the child on the second half of the school holidays, on an alternating year basis. On odd years, the child shall be with the Father during the first half of the school holidays.

(e)       Save for Chinese New Year, the Father shall have access to the child on half of the public holidays, with parties to mutually agree in writing and in advance on which specific public holidays the child shall spend with each party. In the absence of an agreement, the Father shall have access to the child on alternate days of the public holidays.

(f)       For the Chinese New Year holidays (typically 14 days in China), the Father shall have access to the child on alternating years starting from 2025.

Overseas travel

(g)       The Father be at liberty to bring the child overseas (outside China) on an overseas trip during his access.

(h)       In the event either parent travels with the child, the travelling parent shall provide confirmation of the travel date and details at least 2 weeks in advance. The travel itinerary, with details on accommodation, flight, contact numbers, shall be provided at least 7 days prior to travel. Prior to travel, the Mother shall hand over the passport of the child to the Father at least 7 days prior to travel, or such earlier date if necessary for the application of the relevant visas and immigration permits, which shall be returned to the Mother within 7 days after travel.

Other provisions

(i)       In the event access does not take place, the Father shall have make-up access to the child within one month after the Sunday of that week of the scheduled access.

(j)       The Mother shall keep the Father informed of the child’s school arrangements, including the child’s school timetable, progress and any updates from the school. The Father is also at liberty to communicate directly with the child’s school, teachers, and other education stakeholders, regarding the child’s wellbeing and progress.

(k)       In the event of an emergency, medical or otherwise, either party shall inform the other at the earliest available and practical opportunity. Both parties are at liberty to accompany the child for any emergency medical visits.

(l)       In the event of any inconsistency or overlap in the access terms, the specific terms take precedence as follows: child’s birthday, Chinese New Year, Public Holidays, School Holidays.

(m)       Parties are at liberty to mutually agree in writing on adjustments or additions to the access times stated in this Order of Court.

(n)       To give effect to the Father’s access to the child, the Mother shall withdraw and discontinue any and all enforcement proceedings in China against the Father in respect of the child’s care arrangements, forthwith.

III)     In the event the above Clause (II) applies and to give effect to the same, the Father shall return the child to the Mother on 20 December 2024, after the child’s school term ends on 13 December 2024, or such later date as parties may agree in writing. The Father shall also hand over the child’s passport to the Mother on the same date.

IV)     In the event that the above Clause (II) applies and to give effect to the same, the Mother and Father shall take all practicable steps to mirror the prayers in Clause (II) in an Order of Court in China insofar as is permissible under, and in accordance with, Chinese law.

V)     In the alternative to the above Clause (II), in the event the Father is not granted liberal access to the child as prayed for, the Father shall have care and control of the child and the Mother shall have liberal access to the child, including overnight and overseas access.

VI)     Parties shall have liberty to apply.

VII)     The Mother shall bear the costs of these proceedings.

VIII)     Such further or other relief as the Court deems fit.

5       OSG 77 and Summons 3478 were jointly heard before me. Having considered parties’ evidence and submissions, I granted the Mother sole custody, care and control of the child solely for the purpose of having the child return to China, that the Father shall take all required steps to facilitate the handing over of the child to the Mother and shall surrender the child’s passport to the Mother or to her solicitors within 7 days of the order.

6       Pending the handing over of the child, I ordered that the injunction issued against the Mother be discharged and made a further order to prevent the Father from removing the child out of Singapore without consent or approval of the Court or the written consent of the Mother.

7       Having made the order in OSG 77, I dismissed the Father’s applications in Summons 3478 and awarded costs against him on both applications. The Father has since appealed against the whole of my decision in OSG 77[note: 1]. I now set out the reasons for my decisions.

Mother’s solicitor

28     The Mother submitted her solicitor’s opinion found in the solicitor’s affidavit of 17 December 2024. The solicitor is a practicing lawyer in China whose area of expertise included dealing with civil cases such as family division and divorce. He was engaged by the Mother to respond to the legal opinion of the Father’s solicitor dated 5 September and 26 October 2024 which were found in the solicitor’s affidavit filed on 10 December 2024.

29     The Mother posed a total of 16 questions for her solicitor’s legal opinion[note: 13]. The more relevant questions and the responses of the Father and Mother’s solicitor are set out below for ease of comparison.

30     The following question is relevant on the issue of custody:

(b)    What responsibilities and rights do the Mother has regarding the child under the Chinese court order?

Response of Father’s solicitor: The Chinese Court order states that the Mother has the responsibility and right to raise and educate the child. This implies that the Mother is entitled to live with the child, as well as the obligation to raise and take care of, provide daily necessities to, cultivate, and educate the child.

Response of Mother’s solicitor: Under the Chinese Court Judgment, the Mother has the responsibility and right to directly raise and educate the child. This includes the right to live with the child, as well as the responsibility to nurture, care for, provide for the child’s daily needs, and foster the child’s education and development. The Mother also has the right to make decisions about the child’s living arrangements and educational matters.

31     On access or visitation rights, the solicitors’ opinion on the various issues was as follow:

(k)    What access or visitation rights does the Father have according to the Chinese court order?

Response of the Father’s solicitor: The Father’s right to the child include the rights to contact, associate with, meet, visit, accompany, look after, protect, educate, and live together for short periods.

Response of the Mother’s solicitor: The Father’s visitation rights to the child primarily refer to the right to visit and interact with the child (e.g., face-to-face meetings and communication). The method and duration of visitation are to be mutually agreed upon by both parents. If an agreement cannot be reached, the matter can be litigated, and the court will determine the specifics of how visitation rights are exercised. Typically, Chinese courts allow visitation twice a month. However, the exact duration of each visit is not explicitly specified. Importantly, the Mother has not denied the Father the right to visitation.

In relation to the Father’s solicitor response to (k) that the Father has the right to live with the child for a short period, the Mother has asked her solicitor as to what is the upper limit of "short-term" and his response was:

Response of the Mother’s solicitor: Under Chinese law and judicial interpretations, there is no legal definition or upper limit for "short-term." Living with the child for a "short-term" period requires the consent of the direct custodian and exceeds the scope of visitation rights. Visitation rights typically involve supervised visits during agreed-upon times, without the right to take the child away. In this case, the Father never agreed with the Mother on how visitation would occur. Instead, the Father forcibly took the child away before the court's judgment and, after the judgment was issued, left the country and refused to comply with the Chinese court’s ruling. The Mother never consented to the Father taking the child out of the country or to the child living with the Father.

(l)    What is the legal procedure for enforcing visitation rights in China?

Response of the Father’s solicitor: Chinese law grants the parent who is not directly responsible for the care of the child the right to access the child. The parent may file an application to request that the court set the schedule and terms of access. The court shall accept the application of the person who has the right of access and make a judgment on the time and manner of access in accordance with the law. If the party who directly raises the child refuses to facilitate the access rights holder in enforcing the access rights after the judgment has entered into force, the access rights holder may petition the court for execution. The execution approach taken by the court is mainly to persuade the party who directly raises the child to do so voluntarily, the court may penalise him/her by imposing a fine, detention, or other measures. Nonetheless, the court hardly ever impose fines or incarceration on the parent who is raising the child directly in order to protect the child from potential harm. Therefore, if the party directly raising the child does not voluntarily fulfill the responsibility of assisting access, the access rights of the access parent will not be realised. The enforcement of access rights has always been a challenging matter in Chinese legal practice because the party who is directly responsible for the care of the child typically does not cooperate with access orders.

Response of the Mother’s solicitor: According to Article 1086 of the Civil Code, after a divorce, the parent who does not directly raise the child has the right to visit the child, while the other parent has the obligation to facilitate this. The method and timing of visitation are to be agreed upon by both parties. If no agreement is reached, the people’s court will make a ruling. If visitation is deemed harmful to the child’s physical or mental health, the court may suspend visitation. Once the reasons for suspension no longer exist, visitation rights should be restored.

The custodial parent typically provides visitation rights twice a month. If the custodial parent does not cooperate with visitation arrangements, the non-custodial parent may file a lawsuit with the court to request a judicial determination of the visitation schedule and method. The court must accept the application and issue a ruling on the timing and manner of visitation.

Once the ruling takes effect, if the custodial parent refuses to facilitate visitation, the non-custodial parent can apply to the court for compulsory enforcement. The court will initially attempt to persuade the custodial parent to voluntarily comply and fulfil their obligation to assist with visitation. If the custodial parent continues to refuse, the court may impose penalties, including fines, detention, or even criminal charges. The custodial parent cannot refuse enforcement measures, as failure to comply without valid reason could result in criminal liability.

(n)    Under Chinese law, does the Father have any measures to prevent being deprived of visitation rights to the child?

Response of the Father’s solicitor: Under Chinese law, the Father does not have any measures to prevent being deprived of the right to have access to the child. The Father will have to take legal action to exercise his right to have access to the child if the Mother refuses to facilitate the same. However, even if the Father exercises his right of access through legal proceedings, if the Mother still does not facilitate access, the Father’s right of access to the child cannot be realised.

Response of the Mother’s solicitor: Visitation rights are a common issue in many divorce cases across China. As a country with a well established judicial system, Chinese law ensures that if the Mother attempts to deprive the Father of visitation rights, the Father can file a lawsuit. The court will rule on the method and schedule of visitation. If the judgment or ruling is not complied with, the responsible party may face criminal liability. Under current Chinese law, unless a court determines that visitation by the Father is harmful to the child, no one has the authority to deprive the Father of visitation rights to the child.

32     In relation to the question of who could decide on the child’s care and education arrangements, the Father’s solicitor has provided his legal opinion on question “(d)” as to what are the Father’s responsibilities and rights under the Notice of Order for Performance[note: 14]. The Mother’s solicitor asked her solicitor to elaborate on the practical effect of the Father being the child's "legal guardian" and having "the same responsibilities and rights to raise and educate the child as the Mother" and which party has the authority to decide the child's care and education arrangements?

Response of the Father’s solicitor: According to the Notice of Order for Performance, the Father has the responsibility to hand over the child to the Mother for caregiving. Pursuant to Article 1084 of the Civil Code of the Peoples Republic of China, “The parents’ divorce does not nullify their relationship with their children. Whether the children are raised by their mother or father after the parent’s divorce, they will always be the children of both parents. Parents still have the right and obligation to raise, educate, and protect their children following divorce.” Although the Mother is currently the caregiver of the child, according to the Chinese Court Order, and has the right to live with the child, the right of caregiving is not unchangeable, and the Father has the right to apply for a change in the caregiver of the child at any time by filing an application. At the same time, even if the caregiver is not changes, the Father is still the child’s legal guardian and has the same responsibility and right as the Moher to raise and educate the child.

Response of the Mother’s solicitor: According to the Civil Code and relevant provisions, the Shangcheng District People's Court of Hangzhou issued Civil Judgment (2023) Zhe 0102 Min Chu 7390, determining that the Mother is the child’s direct custodian. The child's direct custody by the Mother is protected by the court and enforceable through compulsory measures.

Under the Civil Code, the direct custodian is the parent living with the child, who has the authority to make decisions regarding the child’s daily life and education. The direct custodian holds a higher guardianship status. In this case, the Mother, as the direct custodian, has the sole authority to arrange the child's living conditions and educational plans.

Legal guardianship based on blood relations (e.g., parents, grandparents, siblings, etc.) is supplementary. If the direct custodian is unable to fulfil their duties, other guardians have the right and obligation to take on the role of direct custodian. However, their guardianship primarily serves a supporting and supervisory role. This legislative intent aligns closely with similar provisions in Singaporean law.

Issues to be determined

56     In deciding the two applications, I considered the issues set out below as pertinent and relevant.

(a)     Whether the Order made by the Chinese Courts gave custody to the Mother.

(b)     If so, should the Singapore Court make another custody order when there is already one made which binds the Mother and Father.

(c)     As the Chinese Court Order is silent on access, how is the Father to seek recourse.

(d)     Is it in interest of the child for him to be return to the Mother?

(a)   Whether the Order made by the Chinese Courts gave custody to the Mother?

57     I construed the order made by the Chinese Courts as an order for custody which was granted to the Mother. This was borne out even by the judgement of the Court as the word “custody” was used based on the translation made by a neutral third party.

58     The relevant translated grounds of decision of the First Instance Court contained the following statement made by the court:

The focus of the dispute in this case lies in the issue of child’s custody that is (“the Child”)’s custody.

59     The finding by the Court on the above dispute was as follow:

.. it shall be more conducive to his health, growth for him to be raised and educated by Chen Li Ying. Therefore (“the Child”) shall be raised and educated by (“the Mother”) [note: 18]

60     Based on the above, I came to the view that the Chinese Courts gave the Mother sole custody of the child. This was also supported by the Mother’s solicitor’s opinion in paragraph 32 above which stated that the Mother is the direct custodian of the child and has the sole authority to make decisions regarding the child’s daily life and education.

b)   If so, should the Singapore Court make another custody order when there is already one made which binds the Mother and Father?

61     The Singapore Courts in dealing with issues involving children which are not of local born has given guidance on the approach to be taken.

62     In Re A (an infant) [2002] 1 SLR(R) 570, the Court stated that in custody proceedings, an important consideration had to be the child’s cultural connections with and affinity for the cultural and societal environment which the forum served. A child’s best interest was best determined by the forum which was best equipped to determine what was best for the child in all material respects ranging from its health care, education, moral and spiritual and other relevant needs.

63     In this case, the issue of custody had been decided by the court in China which has the closest connection to the parties and the child.

64     In matters which has been decided by a foreign Court, the Court in AB v AC and Another Application [2004] SGDC 6, at paragraph 15 of the decision, cited a High Court decision in Igra v Igra [1951] P 404 which held:

It has long been accepted that the court of the domicile is the proper tribunal to dissolve a marriage. Its decisions should as far as possible, be acknowledged by other countries in the interests of comity. Different countries have different personal laws, different standards of justice and different practice. The interests of comity are not served if one country is too eager to criticise the standards of another country or too reluctant to recognise decrees that are valid by the law of the domicile.

65     While the above case was in relation to dissolution of marriages, the same could apply to ancillary matters. The issue of custody had been litigated extensively in China including at the Appellate Court level whose decision is final. It is important to note that the Father admitted that he had presented to the Court the evidence which he had also submitted to this Court and despite that, an order was made against him.

66     As there is already an order made on the custody of the child by the Chinese Courts, it would not be in the interest of comity of nations if a Singapore Court is to make another order of custody. By comity I mean that there must be respect between countries shown by accepting each other’s laws, even where there is no reciprocal arrangement to recognise orders made by the two countries. The Father participated in the proceedings in both the courts which culminated in a final decision made by an appellate court.

c)   As the Chinese Court Order is silent on access, how is the Father to seek recourse?

67     The Father’s main concern was that the orders made, specifically the 7 August 2023 Order by the First Instance Court did not specify any access for him. This was also reflected in the various prayers sought in his summons including his prayer for mirror orders.

68     On the issue of access or visitation rights, the Mother’s solicitors provided the following insights on Chinese law:

(k)    What visitation rights does the Father has according to the Chinese court judgment?

Response: The Father’s visitation rights to the child primarily refer to the right to visit and interact with the child (e.g., face-to-face meetings and communication). The method and duration of visitation are to be mutually agreed upon by both parents. If an agreement cannot be reached, the matter can be litigated, and the court will determine the specifics of how visitation rights are exercised. Typically, Chinese courts allow visitation twice a month. However, the exact duration of each visit is not explicitly specified. Importantly, the Mother has not denied the Father the right to visitation.

69     Both solicitors informed that there are also legal grounds under the Chinese law for a variation of a child custody order. They also pointed out that there are safeguards available for the Father should he be denied access such as fines imposed by the Chinese courts.

70     Of the two, I was of the view that the Mother’s solicitor interpretation of the court orders and opinion on the relevant issues were more reliable for the following reasons:

(a)     The Father’s solicitor opined that the Father has not violated the Chinese Court Orders simply because they can be varied. I agreed with the Mother’s counsel that the Father’s solicitor’s opinion is non-sensical.

(b)     The Father’s solicitor must have advised the Father who was made to believe that in the Appellate Court order, there was no mention of sole custody being given to the Mother and thus it was also not appropriate to equate the phrase “raised and educated” in the Order with the legal concept of custody in Singapore. This was despite the court referring to the order as the order for custody of the child, based on the translation of the court decision.

(c)     The Father’s solicitor’s interpretation of the court order went against the grain of the two Chinese Court Order when he opined that “After divorcing (the Mother), (the Father) … has the same responsibility and right as (the Mother) to raise, take care of, and educate (the child).”

71     I further note that the Father himself had applied to another Court in China, the Hangzhou Court, for the right to raise and educate the child to be granted to him which application was still pending when OSG 77 and the above-mentioned summons were heard. This was one of the factors which I took into account in dismissing the summons filed by the Father based on Re A’s case. In Re A’s case, the father himself had chosen to have the issues of custody and access determined by the foreign court. As such, any appeal or application in relation to custody or access should be litigated or re-litigated in China by the Father.

d)   Is it in interest of the child for him to be returned to the Applicant Mother?

72     This is the crux of the matter at hand. In OSG 77, the Mother has applied under section 5 of the Guardianship of Infants Act 1934. She asked that she be given sole custody, care and control of the child and for the Father to hand over the child and his travel document to her. In essence, she was asking that the child to be returned to her in China.

73     In deciding matters relating custody of children, the overarching principle is found in s 3 of the Guardianship of Infants Act 1934:

Welfare of infant to be paramount consideration

3.    Where in any proceedings before any court the custody or upbringing of an infant or the administration of any property belonging to or held in trust for an infant or the application of the income thereof is in question, the court, in deciding that question, shall regard the welfare of the infant as the first and paramount consideration and, save insofar as such welfare otherwise requires, the father of an infant shall not be deemed to have any right superior to that of the mother in respect of such custody, administration or application nor shall the mother be deemed to have any claim superior to that of the father.

74     The welfare of the child is thus the first and paramount consideration and in particular the court ought to have some regard to the maternal bond between the mother and child as held in Soon Peck Wah v Woon Che Chye [1997] 3 SLR(R) 430. The Court therein emphasised the importance of maternal bond, especially for young infants who are deeply dependent on their mothers for care and emotional support. The Court, upon finding that the parents were both capable of looking after the child and had their respective families behind them to help out, stated:

All these things being equal between the father and mother, a very important factor to bear in mind was the fact that the child was very young. A child at a very tender young age would be most dependent on his mother for his physical and psychological needs. This should not be mistaken as reviving the old presumption of “maternal custody” of all young infants. In the best interest of the child’s welfare, we should not deprive him of his mother’s love and care: at [44] and [45].

75     Further, in TSF v TSE [2018] 2 SLR 833, the Court of Appeal outlined a non-exhaustive list of factors that the courts should consider, including the following:

(a)     the child’s physical, emotional and educational needs, and his physical and emotional safety.

(b)     the capacity of each parent to provide for the child’s needs and ensure the child’s safety.

(c)     the child’s relationship with each of his parents and with any other caregiver.

(d)     the need to ensure a continuing relationship between the child and his parents; and

(e)     the effect of any changes to the child’s life.

76     The Court stated that the above factors afford a sound starting basis for any court concerned with the issue of the child’s welfare and that factors (a) and (b) are closely related and should generally be considered in tandem. Further, the relevance of these or any other factors to a particular case, and the weight that should be given to each of the factors, is a matter of judgment and will turn on the specific facts and circumstances of that case.

Analysis of the child’s best interest

the child’s physical, emotional and educational needs, and his physical and emotional safety

77     The child was 4 plus years old when he was taken away by the Father and when the application was heard, was 6 plus years old. The court in Soon Pek Wah’s case emphasised the importance of maternal bond, especially for young infants who are deeply dependent on their mothers for care and emotional support. This was also acknowledged by the First Instance Court[note: 19] which made a finding that the child is still young and has endless dependence on his mother and thus it “shall be more conducive to his healthy growth for him to be raised and educated by” the Mother.

78     As for the child educational needs, prior to being taken away, he was in kindergarten. The Mother had enrolled the child in various other classes. After being taken away, he was placed by the Father in an international school.

79     While the child educational needs could be met either by him remaining in China or Singapore, the fact that the child is young weighed in favour of the Mother.

the capacity of each parent to provide for the child’s needs and ensure the child’s safety.

80     The Mother stated that she works as an insurance agent and event planner, and this gave her autonomy and flexibility in her working hours to attend to the child’s needs. She is supported by her retired father to attend to the child in China.

81     The Father’s occupation after he left his company of 10 years on 22 November 2023 was not made known in his affidavits[note: 20]. The Father’s mother who was on Long Term Visit Pass lived with the child who has been issued with a Student Pass. The Father informed that his mother’s Long Term Visit Pass was tied to the child’s Student Pass. The Father also informed that he had applied for a Long Term Visit Pass which was also tied to the child’s Student Pass[note: 21]. It was not clear what his long term plans are. If he were to return to China, we would have to deal with the orders made against him.

82     Based on the above, I was of the view the Mother would be able to provide a more stable environment for the child’s needs, growth and safety.

the child’s relationship with each of his parents and with any other caregiver

83     I did not find any evidence of any wrong-doing or anything against the Mother or any of her immediate family with regards to the child.

the need to ensure a continuing relationship between the child and his parents

84     It is well recognised that it is in a child’s best interests post-divorce for him to maintain a good relationship with both his parents[note: 22]. The Mother informed that she was more than willing to let the Father be a part of the child’s life and upbringing and willing to facilitate access in accordance with the law. According to the Mother’s solicitor, the method and duration of visitation are to be mutually agreed upon by both parents. If an agreement cannot be reached, the matter can be litigated, and the court will determine the specifics of how visitation rights are exercised. Typically, Chinese courts allow visitation twice a month. However, the exact duration of each visit is not explicitly specified. Importantly, the Mother has not denied the Father the right to visitation.[note: 23]

85     The Father on the other hand, instead of going back to the Chinese courts, had taken things into his own hands and had not allowed the Mother to have access to the child for long periods after the Father took the child from the Mother.

86     In my view, this factor weighed against the Father.

the effect of any changes to the child’s life.

87     The child was taken out of China and brought to Singapore where he was enrolled into a school so that he could be bilingual. Whilst the child had been in Singapore since December 2023, he had lived most of his life in China and taken care of by the Mother on full time basis from January 2019 to 2022 when the Mother started work.

88     Bearing in mind the importance of maternal bond, especially for young children as stated in Soon Peck Wah’s case, this factor also weighed against the Father.

the parents’ character and conduct

89     This was an additional factor which the court in TSF v TSE took into account in determining welfare of the child. The Father clearly had brought the child out of China for his own interest after he disagreed with the two court orders. Based on the evidence, the circumstances supported the Mother’s claim that the child was taken away from her without her consent.

90     The Father’s conduct had also led to the issuance of enforcement orders against him. The Father appeared not to have taken the orders seriously.

Conclusion

91     Having considered the above factors and the circumstances of the case, in the context of our guardianship laws, I came to the view that it is in the child’s best interest for the Mother to be granted care and control of the child. To enable the Mother to exercise this right, bearing in mind that there is already a custody order made by the Chinese court, I ordered that she be given sole custody for the purpose of having the child returned to China with the Mother. I also granted the Mother her second prayer to facilitate the return of the child. Consequently, I dismissed the Father’s application in Summons 3478.

92     In summary, I made the orders in OSG 77 and dismissed Summons 3478 for following reasons:

(a)     It is in the best interest of the child that the Mother be given care and control of the child, and to enable the Mother to exercise this right, for her to also be given sole custody for the purpose of having the child returned to her in China.

(b)     With the order made in the main application in OSG 77 which would result in the child being returned to the Mother in China, the child would not be within the jurisdiction requiring any other order for custody, care and control or access to be exercised by any of the parties including the Father.

(c)     There are existing orders for custody made by the Chinese Courts that had jurisdiction when the orders were made and will continue to have jurisdiction over the parties. It would be against the comity of nations for another jurisdiction to make another or further order or others on the same matter.

(d)     It was open for the Father to litigate the issue relating to the child including his access in China which is the proper forum. There is thus no necessity for a Singapore Court to even consider the mirror orders requested for by the Father. The Father should also deal with the orders made against him for his non-compliance with the two Chinese court orders.

93     Lastly, I did not grant the Father’s application to defer my decision on the matter pending the conclusion of the proceedings filed by him in the Hangzhou Court so as not to further prolong the separation of the child from the Mother.

Costs

94     On the issue of costs, the Mother’s solicitor sought $6,000 for OSG 77 and $4,000 for dismissal of Summons 3478.

95     The powers of the court to fix and assess costs is found in rule 851(2) of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (“FJR”). Rule 852(2) of the FJR states that costs should “follow the event” except where the court considers that “in the circumstances of the case some other order should be made as the whole or part of the costs”. I was of the view that the Father should pay the costs for both sets of applications.

96     There was a total of 13 affidavits filed for the two applications. Several case conferences and court attendances were conducted before the hearing which took close to two hours. An application for an injunction was also made and granted. Written submissions were prepared by the Mother’s solicitors for the purpose of both applications. Having considered the relevant factors, I awarded $4,000 costs for OSG 77 and $2,000 for dismissal of Summons 3478 against the Father.

[note: 1]The Father applied for a stay of execution pending the hearing of the appeal. Other than the order for cost, the other orders were stayed on 23 April 2025.
