html:
XIM v XIN

XIM v XIN
[2025] SGFC 17

Case Number:Divorce No 228 of 2023
Decision Date:10 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Chan Eng Jin, Darren (Zeng Yongren, Darren) and David Zhang (Legal Aid Bureau) for the plaintiff; Lim Hong Wen, Amelia and Low Seow Ling (Liu Xiaolin) (Emre Legal LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XIM — XIN

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Dissipation of shares

10 February 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       The Plaintiff Wife and the Defendant Husband were married on 2 October 2011. The Plaintiff filed her Writ for Divorce on 16 January 2023. The interim judgment was granted on 12 April 2023 (the “IJ”).

2       The Plaintiff was 53 years old at the time of hearing. The Defendant was 63 years old. There were no children of the marriage, although the Plaintiff had two adult children from his previous marriage and the Defendant had one adult child from her previous marriage.

3       The ancillary matters came up before me for hearing on 19 September 2024. I delivered my decision on 25 October 2024. The only issues for my determination were the division of the matrimonial assets and spousal maintenance. In respect of the former, the parties had agreed on the pool of matrimonial assets, save that the Plaintiff contended that: (i) the Defendant had wrongfully dissipated his shares in Company X, and that a certain sum should consequently be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets to account for this; and (ii) that the Defendant had transferred a sum of $71,356.44 to his friend which should be added back into the pool.

4       I ultimately determined that: (i) a sum of $101,874.69 should be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets on account of the shares that were dissipated by the Defendant; and (ii) the sum of $71,356.44 transferred by the Defendant to his friend should also be added back into the pool. I valued the total pool of matrimonial assets at $1,096,817.10 and determined that this should be divided in the proportion of 75% to the Defendant and 25% to the Plaintiff. I further ordered that there should be no spousal maintenance for the Plaintiff.

5       The Plaintiff has since appealed specifically against my computation of the amount to be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets owing to the Defendant’s dissipation of his shares in Company X. My decision here will therefore focus on this issue.

The parties’ cases

6       Company X was incorporated in 2009 by the Defendant and his friend, A. They each contributed $10,000 towards the start-up capital. The Defendant and A were the only directors and shareholders of the company.

7       On 19 May 2015, the Defendant transferred all 250,000 of his shares in Company X to his elder child, C1. C1 was 23 years old and a university student at the time. This transfer was approved by himself and A as directors of Company X[note: 1]. On the same day, the Defendant tendered his letter of resignation to relinquish his position as a director of Company X.

8       For reasons that are disputed, though his shares were transferred to C1 on 19 May 2015, the Defendant continued as a director of Company X until 21 August 2018, when C1 was made a director of the company in his place. C1 was 26 years old at that point, and remained a university student.

9       Although the Defendant had ceased to be the legal owner of the shares as at the date of the interim judgment, the Plaintiff nevertheless posited that the value of those shares should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets. The Plaintiff’s case was that the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X to C1 was an act of wrongful dissipation intended to deplete the pool of matrimonial assets at a time where the divorce was imminent. The Plaintiff argued that the shares were sold to C1 at an undervalue, that the Defendant’s narrative surrounding the disposal of his shares was untrue, and that the Defendant’s explanation for the transfer was unbelievable.

10     The Defendant’s position was that the sale of his shares to C1 was a legitimate one done at a fair and accurate market value. The Defendant disagreed that divorce proceedings were imminent at the time of sale. The Defendant consequently objected to the value of the shares being added to the pool of matrimonial assets.

Issues to be determined and the applicable law

11     Generally, the starting point in an exercise to divide the matrimonial assets is the identification of matrimonial assets and their respective values. The default operative date to determine the assets in the matrimonial pool is the date of the interim judgment, though the court retains the discretion to depart from this default position (see ARY v ARX and another appeal [2016] 2 SLR 686 at [31]).

12     However, simply identifying all the assets and liabilities in existence as at the operative date may not always sufficiently reflect the true material gains of the marriage, and therefore may not result in a just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets. This may be the case where an asset was expended prior to the operative date, such that the value of the asset would not be reflected in the pool of assets, to the benefit of the party who disposed of the asset.

13     To achieve an equitable outcome, the court is therefore empowered to add certain sums back into the pool of matrimonial assets. Where divorce proceedings are imminent, the court may order a substantial sum expended by one party to be returned to the pool of matrimonial assets if the other spouse was considered to have at least a putative interest in it and had not agreed to the expenditure, whether or not the expenditure was a deliberate attempt to dissipate matrimonial assets or not (see TNL v TNK and another appeal and another matter [2017] 1 SLR 609 (“TNL”) at [24]).

14     Further, even before divorce is imminent (or the grant of interim judgment), where it is proven on the facts and evidence that an expenditure amounts to wrongful dissipation with the intention of depleting the matrimonial pool, the court may add a sum back into the pool of matrimonial assets (see UZN v UZM [2021] 1 SLR 426 at [66] to [68]).

15     With the relevant authorities in mind, I considered the following two questions to determine whether the value of the shares in the company should be added to the pool:

(a)     Were divorce proceedings imminent at or around May 2015; and

(b)     Did the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X amount to wrongful dissipation?

16     If I were to determine that the value of the shares should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, then I would have to decide what notional amount I should add to the pool to account for the Defendant’s dissipation of his shares in Company X.

My decision

Issue 1: Whether divorce proceedings were imminent at or around May 2015

17     I first considered if divorce proceedings were imminent at or around the time that the Defendant transferred the shares to C1, i.e. on 19 May 2015. If divorce was imminent, I could, per the dicta in TNL, add the value of the shares back to the pool of matrimonial assets, whether or not the Defendant had deliberately attempted to dissipate the shares.

18     The Plaintiff argued that the parties’ marital relationship was no longer functioning at this time, and that divorce between the parties was imminent. The circumstances drawn up by the Plaintiff were as such: in April 2015, the Defendant committed family violence against her. This led to the Plaintiff applying for a personal protection order in or around May 2015, which she subsequently withdrew upon the Defendant providing an undertaking at a mention on 23 June 2015 that he would not use family violence against her. Around this time, the Defendant threatened her with divorce and reduced her allowance. Viewed as a whole, the Plaintiff submitted that the Defendant’s conduct indicated that the ‘prospect of divorce’ was already on his mind at the time. The Plaintiff suggested that the Defendant only withheld filing for a divorce at that time to avoid exposing his plan to dissipate his shares in Company X.

19     However, the Statement of Particulars (Amendment No. 1), which formed the basis for the grant of the IJ, did not rely exclusively on events in or around May 2015; nor did it cite the events in or around May 2015 as the core reason for the divorce. Rather, it referred to events even after May 2015 and suggested that the parties’ relationship had deteriorated over the years after the altercation in 2015, and that it was a cumulation of events that resulted in the breakdown of the marriage.

20     The fact of the matter is that the Writ for Divorce was only filed some eight years later. The Plaintiff withdrew the PPO, ostensibly with the hope of reconciliation. After May 2015, the parties even went on various overseas holidays as a couple between 2017 and 2019.[note: 2] The Plaintiff could have filed for a divorce herself at any time earlier, but did not do so. She consciously chose to stay in the marriage, even if for material reasons only. In the Plaintiff’s affidavits, she expressed her disappointment at the Defendant’s efforts to the marriage, which suggested that she continued to hold expectations of him as her husband over the years, even after 2015.

21     It therefore appeared to me that the love might have been lost, but the marriage very much remained. I was not satisfied on the evidence that divorce was imminent at that point in time, and did not accept the Plaintiff’s hypothesis that the Defendant only resisted filing for a divorce all those years just to avoid exposing his plan to dissipate his shares in Company X.

Issue 2: Whether the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X amounted to wrongful dissipation

22     Notwithstanding my finding that the divorce was not imminent in May 2015, I examined if the Defendant’s shares in Company X were wrongfully dissipated. If so, the court may nevertheless add the value of these shares back into the pool of matrimonial assets, even if divorce was not imminent at the time.

Were the Defendant’s shares transacted at an undervalue?

23     I first considered the value of the consideration that the Defendant said he received for the shares. While the adequacy of the consideration received might not in itself be determinative of the legitimacy of the transfer, the disposal of shares for consideration less than its true value might indicate that the transfer should not simply be taken at face value.

24     In this regard, the Defendant’s position was that the consideration of $150,000 was intentionally calculated to “accurately reflect the market value of the shares”.[note: 3] The Defendant explained his calculation as follows:

(a)     The principal amount of $359,820.98, based on the Net Asset Value (“NAV”) of the 250,000 shares in Company X as reflected in the IRAS Working Sheet C for Transfer of Shares (“IRAS Working Sheet”);[note: 4]

(b)     Divided by two, i.e. $179,910.49, because half of the shares were held on C1’s behalf, and that C1 therefore only needed to pay him for the Defendant’s half of the shares; and

(c)     Less the sum of $29,500, being the Defendant’s estimation of the company’s losses in 2015.

25     Shy of any better evidence, I accepted the NAV as reflected in the IRAS Working Sheet. This document purported to contain information from the company’s management accounts as at 31 January 2015, which preceded the events in April 2015 cited by the Plaintiff. There was nothing put forth by the Plaintiff to suggest that the information in the IRAS Working Sheet was inaccurate or unreliable, nor did the valuers engaged by the Plaintiff (the “Plaintiff’s Valuers”) suggest that there was something untoward about it.

26     However, I found the rest of the Defendant’s formula to be problematic.

27     Firstly, there was a slight inaccuracy in the Defendant’s calculation, as applying his formula should result in the amount of $150,410.49, not $150,000. No explanation was given for using the lesser sum, not even an explanation that he chose to round it down for convenience.

28     Secondly, by the Defendant’s own admission, there were no documents or correspondences exchanged between Company X, C1 and himself evidencing how the consideration of $150,000 was actually determined at the time of the transfer.[note: 5]

29     Thirdly, and importantly, I did not accept the Defendant’s reasons for dividing the NAV of his 250,000 shares in two. The Defendant claimed that C1, who was only around 17 years old at the time, was the beneficial owner of half the shares because he used $5,000 of C1’s ang bao monies (that the Defendant had saved up over the years on C1’s behalf) toward the start-up capital of Company X. I found this be a weak and baseless claim:

(a)     There was no documentary evidence showing that the Defendant had taken a sum of $5,000 that belonged to C1, or that C1 was the beneficial owner of half of the shares, whether such evidence took the form of a trust deed, or even contemporaneous emails or messages. The Defendant simply relied on a bare assertion that at the material time, he had a verbal agreement with C1 that he would hold C1’s shares in his name.[note: 6] I noted that this assertion was not even something that C1 himself corroborated on affidavit, despite C1 having filed two affidavits in these proceedings;

(b)     It seemed inconceivable that the Defendant did not have the sum of $5,000 at his disposal at the time, such that he had to rely on C1’s savings. There was also no explanation as to why the Defendant could not have taken this sum of $5,000 as a loan from C1 instead. Similarly, there was no explanation as to why he did not include C1 as a shareholder of the company any earlier, if he was indeed the beneficial owner of half of the Defendant’s shares;

(c)     Further, on the face of the documents titled “Return of Allotment of Shares” dated 1 November 2011[note: 7] and 14 August 2013[note: 8], 75,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 26 October 2011 and 10,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 7 August 2013. The documents indicated that there were further cash payments made to acquire those shares. However, there was no evidence that C1 had put up any further cash payments toward those shares, such that any shares from further allotments should be attributed to him too. While the Defendant suggested that C1 had a 25% interest in the company’s profit and returns, and that a portion of such profits was reinvested over the years, I noted that there was no evidence of C1 receiving any corresponding share of dividends or profits over the years. There was also no evidence proving this arrangement or showing C1’s agreement to this arrangement. The affidavits filed by C1 also did not attest to such an arrangement.

30     Lastly, there was no objective evidence showing what the company’s losses were in 2015 to support how the Defendant arrived at the figure of $29,500. That was simply an estimate that he had decided on his own, with no apparent basis whatsoever.[note: 9] There was also no explanation as to why the sum of $29,500 was only deducted from half of the NAV of the 250,000 shares and was not first deducted from the full NAV before dividing the remainder by two, which would have resulted in a different balance of $165,160.49 instead. This appeared to me to be a contrived attempt at backward reasoning to justify the figure of $150,000.

31     I therefore found that the consideration of $150,000 was not commensurate with the value of the shares. This was also the finding arrived at by the Plaintiff’s Valuers.[note: 10] The fact that the Defendant accepted this amount, which was much lower than its NAV, and which was derived at without any coherent method of calculation, suggested that the transaction might not have been done at arm’s length. I noted that the Defendant never explained that he had accepted a consideration of lower value on account of his relationship with C1, though this might have been understandable, and perhaps even reasonable. Rather, the Defendant was constant in his insistence that the transfer had been done at fair market value. I therefore held the Defendant to this standard in examining the veracity of his claim, and found that he fell short.

Was the Defendant’s explanation for transferring the shares in May 2015 credible?

32     To explain his decision to transfer his shares to C1, the Defendant reasoned that around the time of the transfer, the parties’ relationship was strained and that for a prolonged period of time, he “lost sleep due to the Plaintiff’s behaviour at home”. The Defendant felt that with his increasing workload and his struggle with the English language, he was unable to perform his role as a director properly. The Defendant felt stressed and under pressure and therefore decided to resign and transfer his shares on 19 May 2015.[note: 11]

33     These did not strike me as very compelling reasons for disposing of his shares at the time that he did. Company X had been operating since 2009 and had been profitable over the years.[note: 12] It did not seem to me that the Defendant’s deficiencies with the English language, if any, had been a hindrance to him conducting his business effectively, and it seemed odd that he would see this as a challenge after six years of operating the company.

34     Furthermore, these operational burdens would have arisen from his role as a director, not a shareholder. The Defendant could have simply resigned from his role as director, without having to give up his shares. Rather, the opposite happened, as he sold his shares but had to remain as director for another three years or so. This would have done little to relieve him of the burdens he supposedly felt about the job. It also did not make sense to me that he found his ownership of his shares so stressful, yet so readily passed this apparent ‘poison chalice’ on to his son, without harbouring any similar concerns.

35     Apart from an allusion to the business being a private company, there was no actual explanation as to why the Defendant decided to sell his shares to C1, and not anyone else. There was no evidence that this sale was something he had been considering for some time, nor was there any evidence of any attempt to sell these shares at a higher value to A or to another third party. I noted that the Defendant did not inform the Plaintiff of the transfer of the shares in Company X, and that the Plaintiff only found out on her own much later. If this was a legitimate arrangement with nothing untoward about it, there was no reason for him to have kept the Plaintiff in the dark this whole time.

36     In light of the above, I did not find the Defendant’s reasons to be credible, particularly in the context of the state of the parties’ relationship at the time. The Defendant’s explanation did not resolve my suspicions, but conversely raised further doubts about the transaction, and gave a sense that the Defendant was obfuscating the truth. I therefore found that that the transfer of shares was, on the balance of probabilities, done with the intention of keeping them beyond the Plaintiff’s reach and depleting the pool of matrimonial assets, particularly given the lack of trust between the parties at the time.

Issue 3: The amount that should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets to account for the Defendant’s wrongful dissipation

37     Having decided that the Defendant had wrongfully dissipated his shares in Company X, it remained for me to determine the notional value to be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets. In this regard, I considered the operative date for determining the value of the shares that were dissipated, and whether the full value of these shares as at said operative date should be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets for division.

What is the operative date for determining the value of the dissipated shares?

38     The Plaintiff’s position was that the value of 250,000 shares in Company X should added to the pool of matrimonial assets at their present value. To this end, the Plaintiff argued that the 250,000 shares should be valued at $1,930,000, being what the Plaintiff’s Valuers found to be their value as at 31 January 2023.[note: 13] I noted that 31 January 2023 was a date prior to the interim judgment but was nevertheless the latest available valuation.

39     Without going into the correctness of the Plaintiff’s Valuers’ Valuation Report, I did not agree with the Plaintiff’s position.

40     The Plaintiff’s position was premised on the trite proposition that matrimonial assets are generally valued at the date of the ancillary matters hearing, or as close to the date as possible. However, the court retains the discretion to depart from this where warranted on the facts and where there are cogent reasons to do so (see BPC v BPB and another appeal [2019] 1 SLR 608 at [42] and [43]).

41     In this case, it was not the shares that were being added back into the pool of matrimonial assets, but the notional value of those shares to account for the Defendant’s dissipation. An addition of any amount to the pool of matrimonial assets would have been by virtue of an exercise of discretion to correct the wrongful dissipation, and not by virtue of the Defendant’s ownership of the shares. Accordingly, I was of the view that it was the value of the shares as at the time of dissipation that should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, not the latest value of the shares as though they had remained an asset in the pool of matrimonial assets.

42     As at the time of the hearing, C1 was the legal and beneficial owner of the shares. There was no evidence that C1 held these shares on trust for the Defendant. It would have been artificial and unduly prejudicial to the Defendant to adopt the latest value of the shares. It is anyone’s guess how Company X would have grown over the years had the Defendant remained a 50% shareholder of the company rather than C1, bearing in mind that shareholders are entitled to vote at meetings and thereby influence the company’s business decisions too. It is not the court’s place to dabble in such speculation, and it would be unfair on the Defendant to hold him to such speculative value where he has had no entitlement to any such gain in value from 2015 to 2023. If the reverse occurred and the value of the shares decreased significantly, or if the company had ceased its operation completely, it may be unfair on the Plaintiff if nothing was added back to the pool to account for the Defendant’s dissipation, where the shares were of considerable value at the time of dissipation.

43     In any case, I found that it would be onerous on the Defendant to add the full value proposed by the Plaintiff, which would have been close to double what I had found to be the total value of the pool of matrimonial assets. As there was no evidence that the Defendant had any interest in the shares since 19 May 2015, and similarly no evidence that he received any dividends from the company that had flowed from such interest since then, the Defendant would not have been able to tap on any commensurate gains in the shares over the years. This would have been prejudicial to his ability to satisfy any division order made. I did not think that this would have led to an equitable outcome in this case.

44     It remains to be said that one of the key reasons that led to my finding of dissipation was that the transfer of shares to C1 was done at an undervalue. If the consideration paid was not $150,000, but closer to its NAV instead, I might not have found the transaction to amount to a dissipation but rather a mere liquidation of assets, and consequently might not have decided to add the value of the shares back into the pool of matrimonial assets.

45     I therefore found on the justice of the case that adopting the value of the shares as at the time of dissipation, i.e. in May 2015, would be sufficient to account for the Defendant’s dissipation, whereas it would have been excessive to adopt the latest value of the shares.

Should the full value of the Defendant’s 250,000 shares be added to the pool?

46     As a starting point to compute the value of the shares to be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, I found it appropriate to adopt the NAV as declared in the IRAS Working Sheet, i.e. $359,820.98.

47     As mentioned above, there was no evidence that the information in the IRAS Working Sheet was inaccurate or unreliable. On the face of the IRAS Working Sheet, the NAV of the shares transferred was calculated by deducting the value of the company’s total assets less the value of its total liabilities as declared as at 31 January 2015, divided by two (as the Defendant held 250,000 out of 500,000 shares). Given the dearth of information available as to the company’s finances at the time, the Plaintiff’s Valuers found the NAV method to be the only viable option to determine an estimate of the company’s minimum value.[note: 14]

48     I noted that the Plaintiff had previously issued a summons for discovery of, among other things, financial documents for the financial years ending 31 January 2015 and 31 January 2016, but subsequently withdrew her application. Nevertheless, the financial statements for Company X for the financial years ending 31 January 2017 and 31 January 2018 were in evidence.[note: 15] These statements contained information relating to the company’s net assets for 2016, 2017 and 2018. Based on these statements, the total net assets for these years were respectively valued at $646,539, $531,480, and $523,568. Each of these values were lower than the NAV accepted for the financial year ending 31 January 2015. This suggested to me that the NAV of $719,641.96 (for all 500,000 shares) might not have been too far off, and was certainly not unrealistically low as a representation of the value of the shares as at May 2015.

49     The question that remained was whether I should simply add the full NAV of the dissipated shares, i.e. $359,820.98, back into the pool of matrimonial assets.

50     In this regard, I found that of the total of 250,000 shares, 75,000 were acquired before the marriage. This was evident from the Return of Allotment of Shares lodged on 1 November 2011, which showed that 75,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 26 October 2011, bringing his total shareholding at the time to 150,000 shares. There was no suggestion that any further shares were acquired between the date of the parties’ marriage (2 October 2011) and 26 October 2011. The likely inference was therefore that the Defendant had acquired 75,000 shares prior to the marriage.

51     In my assessment, these shares had not been converted into a matrimonial asset by way of either party having “ordinarily used or enjoyed” the shares, per Section 112(10)(a)(i) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “Charter”), as I did not find that the Defendant working for the company and using any income received from this company toward family expenses to constitute ‘usage’ or ‘enjoyment’. There was also no suggestion that these shares were “substantially improved” on by the Plaintiff, per Section 112(10)(a)(ii) of the Charter.

52     I also did not accept the ‘commingling’ argument run by the Plaintiff. Unlike monies in a bank account, I found that the shares were distinct and separately identifiable, and that there would be no issues tracing and separating the pre-marital shares from those acquired after the marriage. That there might have been some commingling of the dividends received by the Defendant only went so far as to suggest that the dividends might constitute matrimonial assets, but this was not the issue before me. I therefore found that the corresponding value of these 75,000 shares retained their character as pre-marital assets and should be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets.

53     The NAV of the remaining 175,000 was therefore $251,874.686. Of this amount, I found that the sum of $150,000, being the amount paid by C1 to the Defendant as consideration for the transfer of the shares in Company X, should be deducted from the notional value to be added back to the matrimonial pool.

54     This sum of $150,000 was evidenced by an image of a cheque issued by Company Y,[note: 16] which was a sole proprietorship registered by C1 on 15 May 2014.[note: 17] The Plaintiff argued that it was incredible that C1 had the sum of $150,000 in his possession at the time. However, in my view, that it was equally unlikely that C1 would register a business if he had no such enterprise going on at the time, and that it was similarly unlikely for the Defendant and the C1 to have hatched a scheme register this business as a ruse just to execute this dissipation, given that Company Y was incorporated nearly a year prior to the transfer of shares on 19 May 2015. The Plaintiff did not further pursue her application for discovery against C1 and did not provide any concrete evidence to indicate that the monies were not C1’s, or that there were no monies paid out by C1 to the Defendant.

55     While there were no documents showing the Defendant’s receipt of this sum, the Defendant had explained that he was unable to retrieve the relevant bank account statements, given the passage of time.[note: 18] The Plaintiff did not pursue this matter in any application for discovery, and did not specifically question or dispute the receipt of this sum in her affidavit or in her submissions. In these premises, I found on the balance of probabilities that the Defendant had indeed received this sum of $150,000.

56     Consequently, I found that the sum of $150,000 should be deducted from the NAV of 175,000 shares ($251,874.686). I therefore decided to notionally add back into the pool of matrimonial assets the balance sum of $101,874.69.

Conclusion

57     For the reasons set out above, I ultimately found that adding the sum of $101,874.69 back into the pool of matrimonial assets was the most appropriate and equitable redress for the Defendant’s wrongful dissipation of his shares in Company X in May 2015.

XLH v XLI

XLH v XLI
[2025] SGFC 43

Case Number:Divorce Suit No. 5772 of 2023, (Summons No. 587 of 2024)
Decision Date:16 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kevin Ho
Counsel Name(s): Ms Teh Guek Ngor Engelin, SC and Ms Tan Xin Er, Sylvie (Chen Xin'er) (Engelin Teh Practice LLC) for the Plaintiff; Mr See Chern Yan (instructed) (Drew & Napier LLC), Ms Shiao Hong Ho and Mr Choo Yik-Hean Bryan (Quahe Woo & Palmer LLC) for the Defendant.
Parties: XLH — XLI

Family law – Custody – Access to Children

16 April 2025

District Judge Kevin Ho:

Background and Procedural Posture

1       In the present application, ie. FC/SUM 587/2024 (“SUM 587”), the defendant-father (“Father”), seeks inter alia the following orders:

(a)     that he be granted regular weekly access to the parties’ 2 children, [M] and [E] (collectively, the “Children”) from Thursdays 5.00pm to Sundays, 9.00am;

(b)     that he be granted access to the Children for half of their mid-year and end-year holidays; and

(c)     various other orders relating to public holiday access and overseas travel arrangements for the Children.

2       In essence, the Father’s case is that he should be entitled to 50% (or an equal “split”) of the Children’s time. That broadly reflects what he is seeking through SUM 587. His counsel submits that even as early as October 2023 (before divorce proceedings were actually commenced), both parents had an understanding that they should have equal time with the Children, and that there were no safety and/or other concerns which justifies any deviation from this understanding.[note: 1]

3       The Plaintiff-mother (“Mother”) challenges the Father’s application. The Mother’s position is that she is already providing access to the Father and that these arrangements should continue.[note: 2] The Mother – through her counsel – argues that the current arrangement already reflects, broadly, a 50/50 split of the Children’s available time.

4       To complete the picture of the applicable procedural posture, SUM 587 is an interlocutory application filed in FC/D 5772/2023, which are the ongoing divorce proceedings between the same parties. These divorce proceedings remain pending as both parties having filed a claim and a counterclaim praying for a divorce to be granted.

5       Given the various allegations raised by the parties, including the Mother’s concerns with possible use of illicit drugs and the Father’s ability to care for the Children, I found it useful for a Custody/Access Evaluation Report (“Report”) to be prepared by the appointed agency to assist the Court in making the determination on the appropriate access arrangements for the Children. I therefore gave the relevant directions at the first hearing of SUM 587 in October 2024.

6       For the interim period (pending the final disposal of SUM 587), I also made various orders on 9 October 2024 to provide for a more structured and clear access plan for the Father so that both parties and the Children are clear as to when they would see the Father.

7       The Report has since been prepared in February 2025 and I have considered its contents in deciding the appropriate access arrangements to be made in SUM 587. I delivered my brief decision, in writing, to the parties in March 2025, pursuant to r. 670 of the Family Justice Rules 2014.

8       I set out my grounds of decision below.

Preliminary Observations

9       Before I address the substantive orders which I made in the present case, I find it necessary to make several observations as to how the parties (and their counsel) have conducted this matter.

10     Arising from the differences in perspectives between the parents, both parties’ arguments and submissions descended into rather technical (and often unnecessary) disputes. These arguments tended to obfuscate more than they illuminate.

11     For example, the parties argued over whether they had in fact adhered to the alleged understanding where the Father would be given an equal split of the Children’s time. The Father says that he should be given half of all available time whereas the Mother believes that only the Children’s “free” time (which excludes the Children’s “down-time”, activity time, etc.) should be divided.[note: 3]

12     In my view, these arguments are unduly technical and borders on inane. Arguing over whether extra-curricular or activity time should be included misses the larger point which is that the purpose of access time is to enable the access (or visiting) parent to build a bond and establish a relationship with his or her child.

13     Thus, fighting over whether which parent should have parenting time during the hours when a school-going child is in school (or engaged in school activities) may well be a fight over who should be standing outside a school or classroom to await their dismissal. It is an unnecessary, and ultimately pointless, fight. On the other hand, if one becomes overly prescriptive, attempting to carve out every possible “activity” time (or impose requirements as to when and where a child should eat, sleep or play) to incorporate as part of an access order, the ensuing order becomes one where the Court would be effectively carving a child’s life up into blocks of hours and minutes. Such an overly prescriptive access order (which is an enforceable and binding court order) unduly restricts both the parents’ and the children’s lives. It also misses the forest for the trees as the true purpose of an access order is to allow one parent to maintain regular contact with the Children: see BG v BF [2007] 3 SLR(R) 233 at [11].

14     Ultimately, it is incumbent on the parents – being the adults – to act in a practical, sensible and fair manner to ensure that the Children spend sufficient time with both of them and to allow the Children to enjoy the love and attention which both parents want to give.

15     This leads me to the next, and equally important point – the law places an expectation that each parent endeavour to be the bigger and kinder parent for their child. This, as the High Court (Family Division) in VDX v VDY [2021] SGHCF 2 (at [42]) had observed, means that parents:

should strive hard not to mire the family, including the children, in litigation, nor should their resources and the court’s resources be spent on litigation to deal with an emotionally-driven conflict. This will involve some measure of compromise; it may involve being bigger, wiser and kinder – which must be difficult when relationship have broken down, yet this is the legal responsibility placed on all parents.

16     In the present case, it was apparent from the parties’ affidavits and submissions that there are serious trust issues between both parents. This, however, should not be a reason for them to engage in arguments which appeals to emotions rather than facts.

17     To illustrate, the Mother advanced arguments about the alleged danger which the Father might pose to the Children. While some concerns may arise from her genuinely held beliefs, many were wholly speculative.

18     For example, unfortunate arguments revolving the possible use of firearms and/or exposure to gun violence were made by the Mother, through her counsel. The picture which counsel sought to paint was one where the Father is a dangerous gun owner in the United States of America (“US”) – where he grew up with his adoptive family – and that he poses a security risk to the Children given the prevalence of gun-related violence or the accidental discharge of firearms in the US.

19     Indeed, during oral submissions, the Father was alleged to have engaged in some form of linguistic sophistry when he stated in his affidavit that “[he does] not currently own and/or possess any guns in the US”.[note: 4] The Court was then urged to interpret his statement as a tacit acknowledgment that he may own firearms “elsewhere” in the world.

20     Respectfully, these claims were largely hyperbole and not based on any actual, tangible or even admissible evidence. The Mother did not provide any proof of the Father’s alleged gun ownership. Moreover, I accept the Defendant’s counsel’s submission that to “investigate” into the matter would be to pit father against daughter as the Mother’s entire basis for raising this alleged concern arose from what were clearly hearsay statements allegedly made by 7-year-old [M] in passing.[note: 5]

21     That is not conducive to effective co-parenting nor is that reflective of a Therapeutic Justice (“TJ”) mindset.

22     Another example relates to the Father’s alleged consumption of drug substances in the US (where the Father submits is a lawful act). Once again, the Mother attempted to paint the Father as a substance abuser who may put the Children at risk. Yet, there is no tangible evidence that the Father consumed illicit drugs in the Children’s presence.

23     These allegations led to various exchanges between counsel, during the hearing of SUM 587, on politically sensitive (and divisive) issues such as gun ownership, drug abuse and the apparent clash of Western and Asian cultures or values. These exchanges similarly shed little light on the actual issue at hand, viz. what should be the appropriate access orders in this case for this family now that the Children are living in Singapore (a place where neither guns nor recreational drugs are allowed).

24     As the parties continue along their journey through their ongoing divorce proceedings, I encourage both of them and their counsel to avoid making broad or sweeping allegations against one another. The High Court (Family Division) in VYB v VYA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 (at [26] – [28]) reminds us that an adversarial approach (instead of a problem-solving one) undermines TJ, and that a TJ system “involves parties making what they may perceive to be ‘sacrifices’ – letting go of what has hurt them deeply, refraining from doing ‘inflammatory’ acts against the other party, compromising by giving in and co-operating with the other party in some issues, taking responsibility where required and finding the will to recast the future.”

25     Speaking extra-judicially, Justice Teh Hwee Hwee (in delivering Her Honour’s keynote address and CJ Koh Lecture 2024 at the Family Conference 2024) noted that TJ has been explicitly adopted by the Singapore courts and that “[o]ur family justice system aims to help parties and their children heal, enabling them to move forward with their lives despite the breakdown of the marital relationship. It is a non-adversarial, problem-solving system that allows time for grieving and supports healing, restoration, and the recasting of a positive future. [Emphasis added]”

26     More recently, the Family Justice Courts (“FJC”) have launched the Family Justice Courts Therapeutic Justice Model (“TJ Model”) in October 2024. The TJ Model, read in conjunction with the FJC’s Practice Directions 2024, requires parties to court proceedings (and their lawyers) to conduct themselves in a manner that is consistent with the principles set out therein.

27     Part 3 of the TJ Model reminds parties that they “play a central role in the TJ Model. They are to take ownership of the family’s issues and cooperate with each other to find timely and enduring solutions to these issues. Particularly where children are involved, they are to prioritise the welfare of the children above their own and focus on parties’ shared interests and future. This involves being willing to compromise in the spirit of give and take and carrying out agreed or ordered arrangements with a cooperative spirit”.[note: 6]

28     Parties are therefore expected to “[a]dopt a cooperative and constructive approach to find timely and enduring solutions; and resolve disputes as amicably as possible” and “[u]se respectful and constructive language in correspondence, court documents and courtroom communications”.[note: 7]

29     These principles should be borne in the parties’ minds as they navigate their divorce and, more importantly, when implementing the access orders made by the Court in the present application, or in the eventual ancillary matters orders.

Decision

30     I now move on to the substantive issue – ie. what access orders should be made in the present case.

31     It is trite law that when making orders in respect of the custody or the upbringing of children, the Court’s first and paramount consideration is that of the children’s welfare. That is clearly set out in s 125(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed).[note: 8] The Court of Appeal in BNS v BNT [2015] 3 SLR 373 (at [19]) emphasised that this principle ought to override any other consideration.

32     When considering what is in a child’s welfare (which ought to be understood in the widest sense),[note: 9] regard may be had to the various factors including inter alia, the need for stability, continuity of living arrangements, the need for both parents’ to be involved in a child’s life, the maternal bond, and the desirability of keeping siblings together: see ABW v ABV [2014] 2 SLR 769 (at [20] – [23]).

33     I wish to make two more observations in relation to the present case.

34     First, SUM 587 is framed as an application for access orders only and thus it is not necessary for the Court to make orders for the Children’s care and control. That said, it is clear that the Mother currently has de facto care and control of the Children. This is a state of affairs which I find to be appropriate for the Children at present, and nothing in my order should be taken as changing this position.

35     Second, a significant part of the Father’s case rests on the existence of an alleged Contact Time Agreement (or “CTA”) where parties had “entered” into in or around 19 October 2023.[note: 10] The Father submits that this CTA grants him the unequivocal right to have an equal split of the Children’s total time, which the Mother disagrees with, thus giving rise to the dispute referred to at [10] above.

36     While the CTA may be relevant as an expression of one or both parties’ broad intent on the issue of custody and access, it is by no means determinative or dispositive. Section 129 of the WC expressly states that:

Power of court to vary agreement for custody, etc.

129.  The court may, at any time and from time to time, vary the terms of any agreement relating to the custody, or the care and control, of a child, regardless when the agreement was made, despite any provision to the contrary in that agreement, where it is satisfied that it is reasonable and for the welfare of the child to do so.

The purport of this provision is clear – while parents may agree to how a child should be cared for, it is the child’s welfare which should be paramount. Where the terms of the agreement may no longer be suitable, the Court retains the discretion to make the appropriate orders.

37     Moreover, insofar as the Father seeks to argue that the CTA is clear with regard to how the Children’s access time should be apportioned between both parents, I do not agree with his submission. In my view, the CTA – which was, in truth, an exchange of text messages between the parents about the impending divorce – was less of a definitive agreement but a generalised idea of what the Father wanted if the Mother proceeds with divorce proceedings, to which the Mother broadly acknowledged.[note: 11]

38     Ultimately, the Court must have regard to the overall circumstances of the case when deciding the appropriate access orders for the Children, and that includes the contents of the Report which was prepared (and which I found to be highly relevant).

39     As the Court of Appeal had observed in WKM v WKN [2024] 1 SLR 158 (“WKM”) at [74]: “[i]n the process of generating their reports, the professionals would have engaged directly with the relevant persons involved in the child’s life and observed some of their interactions with the child. Their observations serve as crucial insights into the child’s world and greatly assist the court by presenting the realities of the child’s situation. Given their expertise, they are well suited to identify issues, such as excessive gatekeeping behaviour by the parents and even possible signs of abuse…[Emphasis added]”.

40     In the present case, the evaluator had the opportunity to speak with the [M]’s primary school teacher, [M]’s psychologist, and [E]’s preschool principal as well as both parents and the Children. These interactions provided invaluable insights which were immensely relevant and helpful to the Court’s determination of the disputed access issues.

41     The evaluator’s observations are consistent with my findings on the evidence presented to the Court through the parties’ affidavits, including inter alia that:

(a)     The Mother has been the children’s primary caregiver and can continue in this role with the support network she has in Singapore.[note: 12] She continues to be the Children’s care parent.

(b)     Although the Father’s private life (including concerns about possible recreational drug use overseas) may have form a central aspect of the Mother’s worries,[note: 13] I do not find that his private life has affected his ability to provide care for the Children in Singapore. For example, the Mother has not provided any evidence that the Father had engaged in recreational drug use which rendered him in a stupefied state or have caused him to act in a manner which rendered him a danger to the Children.

(c)     Both Children are bright, intelligent, and are performing well in school. Both siblings share a close bond and relationship, and I find it desirable and important that both sister and brother continue to provide support for each other, wherever possible, including when they are with the Father during his access period.

(d)     I also find that the Children share a good relationship with both parents despite the trying time for the family, and that this is heartening. Efforts should continue to be made to ensure that the Children’s relationship with both parents remain strong post-divorce.

42     With these broad observations and findings in mind, I set out below my specific orders:

Pending the full and final disposal of ancillary matters in respect of FC/D 5772/2023 (including any appeals in relation thereto), the Defendant shall have access to the Children as follows:

School Term Access

(a)     During [M]’s school term, the Defendant shall have access every Thursday, from 5.30pm to 8.30pm.

(b)     The Defendant shall have overnight access as follows:

(i)     For the 1st and 3rd week of every month, the Defendant shall have overnight access from Friday, 5.30pm to Saturday 6pm;

(ii)    For the 2nd and 4th week of every month, the Defendant shall have overnight access from Friday, 5.30pm to Sunday 10am.

School Holiday Access

(c)     During [M]’s primary school holiday period in March and September each year, the Defendant shall have access to the Children:

(i)     for the second half of the holiday period from 12 noon on Thursday to 6pm on Saturday for the school holiday in March; and

(ii)    for the first half of the school holiday period from 6 pm on Saturday to 12 noon on Thursday for the school holiday in September.

(d)     For [M]’s June and December school holidays, the Defendant shall have access to both the Children for the first half of school holidays on odd numbered years (eg. 2025, 2027, 2029) and the second half of the school holidays on even numbered years (eg. 2026, 2028, etc.) (“Holiday Access Period”).

(e)     During the Holiday Access Period:

(i)     the Defendant shall have overnight access from 9am every Thursday to 9am on Sunday; and

(ii)    regular (non-overnight access) on Mondays to Wednesdays, from 9am to 7.30pm.

(iii)    The Defendant shall not bring the Children overseas during the Holiday Access Period unless the Plaintiff consents to the said travel arrangements, or by Order of Court.

Public Holiday Access

(f)     The Defendant shall have access to the Children on gazetted public holidays or special holidays/events as follows:

(i)     For the holiday known as “Thanksgiving” celebrated in the United States of America, the Defendant shall have access to the Children from 9am to 7pm on the eve, and actual day, of the Thanksgiving holiday with the Defendant.

(ii)    For the Chinese New Year (“CNY”) holiday period (as celebrated in Singapore), the Children would spend the eve and CNY Day 1 with the Plaintiff.

(iii)    The Defendant shall have access to the Children from 9am to 7.30pm on :

(A)     Christmas eve every odd-numbered year (eg. 2025, 2027, 2029); and

(B)     Christmas day on even-numbered years (eg. 2026, 2028, etc.).

(iv)    Save as set out above, the Defendant shall have access to the Children on alternate gazetted public holidays from 9 am to 7.30pm. To avoid doubt, where a public holiday falls on a non-working day and the following working day is gazetted as being the public holiday date in lieu thereof, the Defendant’s public holiday access refers to the second mentioned date.

Other Orders

(g)     In respect of all of the Defendant’s access period set out above, the Defendant shall be responsible for picking up the Children from, and sending them home to, the Plaintiff’s residence at the beginning and/or end of the access period, save that where the Defendant’s access period starts at a time where the Children are in school or attending to after-school activities, he is at liberty to pick them up from school or class (as the case may be) directly.

(h)     The Defendant shall bring the Children to any school-related, co- and/or extra-curricular activities should they fall within his access period.

(i)     The Plaintiff shall take steps to facilitate the Defendant's aforesaid access and shall not arrange for the Children to enrol or participate in any non-school mandated extra-curricular activities which would take place during the Defendant's Holiday Access Period, without the Defendant's agreement or consent.

(j)     The Plaintiff shall not arrange any overseas travel with the Children which would fall within any of the Defendant's access period.

(k)     There shall be no make-up access if the Defendant chooses to forgo any of his overnight access to the Children.

(l)      The parties are at liberty to vary the aforesaid arrangement by mutual consent, such variation to be recorded in writing.

(m)     Liberty to apply.

43     As the above orders are made in the context of an interim access application filed in pending divorce proceedings,[note: 14] I have prefaced my orders as being applicable until the full and final disposal of the pending divorce proceedings. This is important and serves as a signal to the parties that the conversation over what would be the best access arrangements for the Children and the Father does not end with these orders. Instead, the parties should continue to discuss these matters as co-parents using these orders as a catalyst. It is also for this reason that I have provided a mechanism for the parties to adjust or change these arrangements by mutual consent.

44     For now, I have provided that there shall be no overseas travel with the Children during the Father’s access time. To be clear, and as set out above,[note: 15] I make this order not because I find the Father to be a security threat to the Children.

45     Rather, save for a single trip to the US with [M] a few years ago, the evidence suggests that the Father has not travelled with the Children alone. As I have found it in the Children’s best interests for both sister and brother to be together during access (where possible), extended periods of overseas travel with both Children should be a matter which both parents should continue to discuss and consider as they move on with the present proceedings.

46     I should add that any such further travel arrangements should take into account the Children’s readiness for extended travel and the Father’s plans as to how care would be provided to them. In so doing, the views of [M] and/or her psychologist should also be considered, where appropriate.

47     As for the regular access arrangements, in making these orders, I have – where possible provided the Father with a significant amount access time to provide the Children ample opportunity to bond with their father. I have also considered what both parents had informed the evaluator as being their proposed access plans, including weekly and public holiday access hours.

48     In some cases, such as the Children’s school holidays and public holidays, I have provided for the Father to have about half of the relevant access period (in terms of calendar days or months). This is not because I am enforcing the terms of the so-called CTA (as put forward by the Father and his counsel) nor is a 50/50 split some default position used by the Court. Rather, it is a recognition that where the Children’s time and schedule permits, it is in their interest to spend quality time with him.

49     I wish to reinforce one point – just as I had reminded the Mother not to descend into the minutiae of the Children’s schedule or the allocation of their “free time”, the Father should not be overly fixated with there being some form of overarching concept of “fairness” mandating a 50/50 split in the Children’s time.

50     In his counsel’s written submissions, the Father seeks to highlight how the Mother had sought to “commoditised” the Children’s time by requiring make-up time, or extra hours with the Children as something to be traded and/or negotiated.[note: 16] However, splitting the Children’s time and/or schedule mechanistically to achieve an “equal” division will invariably result in the same commoditisation of the Children’s lives.

51     I thus encourage the Father to use the access time he has with the Children (which is generous) in a manner which builds their relationship through father-child activities and interactions. As I had noted above, there is no real purpose of having an allocated “access” time where the parent is merely engaged in passive acts, such as waiting. The focus should be on quality, not quantity.

52     In a similar vein, I note that both [E] and [M] have additional classes and activities over their regular school curriculum. These may sometimes affect how much quality time each parent has, and an overly mechanistic allocation may affect the Children. For example, the Children’s Chinese and/or tennis class schedule have resulted in some challenges with the Father’s pick-up and return schedules. These are matters which the Mother should look into to ascertain what would be the most practical way to allow the Children more quality time with the Father while not overburdening their rest time. However, I will not be making orders to prescribe a certain schedule. These are parenting matters best left to the parents to work together and resolve.

Conclusion

53     In the circumstances, I will not be ordering any change to the Children’s current de facto care arrangements, and have provided for a more comprehensive interim access arrangement for the Father to see the Children while the divorce proceedings are underway.

54     To support the parties’ healing and to assist them to navigate their journey to co-parent the Children, I encourage them to continue to see their psychologist, Ms [S], to work on their mutual co-parenting skills and support.

55     After considering the parties’ costs submissions, I made no order as to costs.

XKD v XKE

XKD v XKE
[2025] SGFC 32

Case Number:Divorce No 2605 of 2023 (Ancillary Matters)
Decision Date:27 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): C Selvaraj (M/s Apex Law LLC) for the Husband; Grace Chacko (M/s Grace Chacko Law Practice) for the Wife.
Parties: XKD — XKE

Family Law – Care and control – Plaintiff and Defendant each seeking sole care and control of their child – Defendant is a foreigner on long-term visit pass in Singapore which will be expiring soon – Applicable considerations

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Plaintiff’s CPF contributions – Plaintiff working for about 33 years before marriage which lasted for about 12 years

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Defendant working for about four years during the marriage – Single-income marriage for the remaining eight years of the 12-year marriage – Defendant awarded 30% of the matrimonial assets

Family Law – Maintenance – Wife – Plaintiff earning higher income than Defendant – Plaintiff already past his retirement age and has only about three years of working life left – Defendant gainfully employed and can continue to work for about 20 years before reaching retirement age

Family Law – Maintenance – Child

27 March 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

[LawNet Admin Note: 27 March 2025[note: 1]]

1       The parents in this case have each sought sole care and control of their child. The mother is a foreigner on a long-term visit pass (“LTVP”) in Singapore. The pass will expire soon, and it is unclear whether it will be renewed by the authorities. Are such factors conclusive in showing that the Singaporean father ought to have sole care and control of the child? This issue – which has thus far eluded judicial comment – arose in the present case.

2       The Plaintiff is a Singaporean (“Husband”). The Defendant is a Filipino on LTVP in Singapore (“Wife”). They were married in June 2011 and have a 10-year-old son (D.O.B. XX September 2014) (“Son”).

3       After 12 years of marriage, the Husband commenced divorce proceedings in June 2023. Interim judgement was granted in August of the same year.

4       This matter came before me to determine the ancillary matters.

Child custody, care and control, and access

5       I begin with the issues relating to the Son.

Parties’ position

6       The parties have agreed to have joint custody of the child.[note: 2]

7       Each of them however wishes to have sole care and control of the Son.

Applicable principles

8       Given the parties’ position, I will have to determine which of them is a more suitable parent to care for the Son. This requires me to consider which parent can better (a) attend to the child’s emotional, developmental, and material needs, (b) provide for his daily care, and (c) make day-to-day decisions for him: see e.g., XDZ v XEA [2024] SGFC 90 (“XDZ”) at [13].

9       In making such a determination, courts have generally considered the following:

(a)      The parents’ past and present interactions with the child. For instance, which parent has shown greater concern, interest and responsibility for the child? Which parent has been the child’s primary caregiver? Which parent has a stronger bond with the child? See XDZ at [14(a)] to [14(d)].

(b)      The parents’ future caregiving arrangements. For instance, which parent can provide better care for the child? Which parent can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the child? Which parent is more willing to promote a healthy relationship between the child and the other parent? What are the child’s wishes? See XDZ at [14(e)] to [14(g)].

(c)      Adverse considerations. For instance, does any of the parent have an unhealthy lifestyle or outlook which may affect his/her ability to make rational decisions for the child? Has any of the parent acted in a way to intentionally or knowingly harm the child’s interest? See XDZ at [15].

(d)      Other considerations. When making orders of care and control, courts are mindful, for instance, that the continuity of the child’s living arrangements is an important factor for his/her emotional well-being. Courts are also slow to separate siblings from one another. See XDZ at [16].

My decision

Care and control – Considerations

10     Applying the above considerations to the present case, I make the following findings.

Considerations

Findings

Past and present interactions

(a)

Which parent has shown greater concern, interest and responsibility for the Son?

Finding – The Wife

(i) The Wife has shown concern, interest and responsibility for the Son. For instance, to spend more time with the Son, the Wife would walk with him to school and had switched jobs so that she could fetch him home from childcare.[note: 3] The Wife would also go through the Son’s lessons with him.

(ii) There is insufficient evidence to show the extent to which the Husband has shown concern, interest and responsibility for the Son.

(iii) For completeness, I wish to address two points raised by the Wife. First, she claimed that the Husband did not care for the Son as he had stopped his Tamil tuition.[note: 4] The Husband explained that he had done so as he had planned to help the child with the language himself.[note: 5] Given the Husband’s work timings (see [10(b)(ii)] below) and that the Son is likely to be free only in the evening and weekends for tuition, I am not so sure whether the Husband’s plan is feasible.

(iv) Second, the Wife submitted that the Husband had threatened to send the Son to a children’s home. To support this submission, she referred to WhatsApp messages from the Husband where he had stated that “[The Son] will be send to children home …”, “You can ask any lawyer he’s life gone”, and “This mrg I talk to Adrian he too say the same thing. [The Son] will be send to children home. Think carefully 3 of our life gone”. I am not exactly sure what is the context in which these messages were sent – e.g., whether they were threats (as alleged by the Wife) or warnings about the consequences of the Wife seeking a divorce and persuading her not to take that path. As such, I do not give much weight to these messages.

(v) For clarity, the observations in (ii) to (iv) above is not a finding that the Husband does not care for the Son.

(b)

Which parent has been the Son’s primary caregiver?

Finding – The Wife

(i) The Wife is the Son’s primary caregiver. She had stopped working after the child was born to look after him. She was the one who had brought him for his vaccinations and hospital visits.[note: 6] The Wife continued to be the Son’s primary caregiver after she returned to work in 2021: see [10(a)(i)] above.

(ii) The Husband holds a full-time job, working mostly night shifts (8.00 pm to 8.00 am).[note: 7] When working on such shifts, the Husband would leave the home at about 7.00 pm (when the Son is at home) and return home by about 9.00 am the next day (when the child is in school). This means that the Husband will hardly see the Son during weekdays. There is no evidence that the Husband intends to work the day shifts for the sake of his child.

(c)

Which parent has a stronger bond with the Son?

Finding – The Wife

The Wife is likely to have a stronger bond (than the Husband) with the Son. Apart from the Wife being the child’s primary caregiver since his birth, there is also the fact of a 56-year age gap between the Husband (66 years old) and the Son (10 years). This huge age gap may affect how the father and child relate to each other. (The Wife is about 45 years old.)

Parents’ future caregiving arrangements

(d)

Which parent can provide better care for the Son?

Finding – The Wife

(i) Both parties are currently working. The Son is in school during the morning and in after-school student care in the afternoon.

(ii) Given that the Husband will not be at home when the Son returns from after-school student care (see [10(b)(ii)] above), he intends to seek help from his six siblings and their children (who are older than the Son) to look after the child.[note: 8]

(iii) The Wife does not have any relative in Singapore.

(iv) On balance, the Wife appears to be in a better position to care for the Son. First, the Husband will hardly be able to look after the Son during weekdays: see [10(b)(ii)] above. Second, if the Husband is given sole care and control of the Son, his relatives will effectively by the child’s surrogate caregivers. Finally, there is no evidence to show that the Son is close to any of these relatives.

(e)

Which parent can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the Son?

Finding – The Husband

(i) The Husband can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the Son. The latter can live in the matrimonial flat (“Flat”) with the Husband, assuming that it is not sold.

(ii) The Wife is a foreigner and is currently staying in a women’s shelter.[note: 9] She plans to secure a HDB rental flat so that the Son can stay with her. There is a lot of uncertainty regarding (1) whether her LTVP will be renewed (see [12] below) and (2) whether HDB will approve her rental flat application.[note: 10]

(f)

Which parent is more willing to promote a healthy relationship between the Son and the other parent?

Finding – Inconclusive

Both parties appear to be equally willing to promote a healthy relationship between the Son and the other parent.[note: 11]

(g)

The Son’s wishes.

Not determined

I did not conduct a judicial interview with the Son or seek a child evaluation report. These are my reasons.

(i) First, the Son is young – only about 10 years old. The Husband submitted that the Wife had been alienating the child from him. In the circumstances, it is unclear whether the Son can express an independent and informed opinion on which parent he prefers to follow.

(ii) Second, and in any event, I do not think that it is right to place on the Son the onerous burden of having to choose between his parents.

Adverse considerations

(h)

Whether any of the parent had intentionally or knowingly harmed the Son’s interest?

Finding – Both parents

(i) The Wife and Husband has a personal protection order, made by consent, restraining each of them from using family violence against the Son.[note: 12]

(ii) The Husband claimed that he had come to know (after the PPO was granted) from a family service centre counsellor that the Wife had physically and emotionally abused the Son for many years.[note: 13] I decline to give weight to this claim because it is based on hearsay evidence (from the counsellor) and its reliability has not been tested in court.

Other considerations

(i)

Continuity of living arrangements.

Finding – The Wife

At the time of the hearing, the Son is being cared for by the Wife. Awarding care and control to her will ensure continuity of his current care arrangements.



11     Based on the above, the preponderance of considerations points to the Wife as being the more suitable parent to care for the Son.

Uncertainty over the renewal of the Wife’s LTVP

12     That said, there is one major issue if the Wife is awarded sole care and control of the child. Her LTVP expires on 2 April 2025 (i.e., about two weeks after this judgement). It is unclear whether she can renew her LTVP thereafter. This is because she needs a Singapore citizen or permanent resident to sponsor her LTVP renewal application. The evidence suggests that the Husband is unwilling to continue to be her sponsor.[note: 14]

13     If her LTVP is not renewed, the Wife will have to leave Singapore. This can lead to (a) application by the Wife to relocate the Son overseas (so as to be with her) and (b) application by the Husband for the child to remain in Singapore and be placed under his care instead.

14     Does uncertainty regarding the renewal of the Wife’s LTVP, as well as the possibility that she may denied continued stay in Singapore, mean that sole care and control of the Son must be awarded to the Husband? In my view, the answer is no. Let me explain.

(a)     In deciding in whose care and control the Son should be placed, the paramount consideration is his welfare: s 125 Women’s Charter 1961 (“Charter”).

(b)     Whether the Wife will be allowed to remain in Singapore is a relevant factor in deciding whether she should have care and control of the Son. This is because it goes towards the issue of whether she can provide a continuity of his living arrangements in the long term.

(c)     That said, it is settled law that the continuity of a child’s living arrangements is just one of the many factors that must be considered on the issue of care and control. A court must consider and balance all the relevant factors: XDZ at [14] to [16]. If the mere possibility that the Immigration and Checkpoint Authority (“ICA”) may not renew the Wife’s LTVP means that care and control of the Son must be awarded to the Husband, this is tantamount to (i) placing undue weight to the continuity factor and (ii) rendering the other factors in [9] and [10] above redundant when deciding on care and control issues.

(d)      Finally, I agree with the Wife that it will be wrong in principle for me to let ICA’s decision (on whether to renew the Wife’s LTVP) dictate my decision on which parent should have care and control of the Son. This is because the ICA decision is based on immigration policy considerations, whereas my decision is to be based solely on the Son’s welfare and interest.

15     To be clear – the foregoing should not be understood to mean that the non-renewal of a parent’s LTVP is an irrelevant consideration altogether: see [14(b)] above. Rather, the issue is what weight ought to be placed on this factor. In this regard, much depends on the circumstances of each case. For instance –

(a)     If the factors in [9] are finely balanced, then the possibility that the LTVP may not be renewed can tip the balance in favor of awarding care and control to the Singaporean parent.

(b)     Additionally, a child’s age – e.g., whether it is (i) a baby, (ii) schooling, (iii) approaching the age for national service enlistment (in the case of males), or (iv) on the cusp of adulthood – can also affect the weight to be placed on the possibility that a parent’s LTVP may not be renewed.

16     I am mindful that the scenarios in [13] above can be severely disruptive for the Son. In my view, this does not displace the clear evidence that the Wife is better able (than the Husband) to care for the child.

(a)     The Son is still young – only about 10 years’ age – and in his formative years. The Wife (i) has been his primary caregiver since birth, (ii) shares a stronger bond with him, and (iii) is a more caring parent: see [10(a)] to [10(d)] above.

(b)     If the Son is placed in the Husband’s care and control, the child is likely to have a difficult time bonding with his father (given the latter’s work routine and their wide age gap). The Son may also end up feeling like an “abandoned child” if he were passed around from relative to relative to be looked after when the Husband is not free to take care of him. (I note that the Husband did not designate any particular relative who will be responsible for helping to look after the Son if the need arises.)

17     For completeness, I wish to address one other point. The Husband has submitted that the Wife is seeking care and control of the Son for an ulterior motive – to remain in Singapore. I am unable to accept this submission. The Wife’s life will not be easy if she remains in Singapore and have to look after the Son. This is because she will effectively be a single mother who must juggle between (a) caring for her growing child and (b) holding a full-time job. She will probably be doing this without a helper’s assistance: see [10(d)(iii)] above. This hardship will persist for a long time – as it will be a decade before the Son reaches adulthood.

Order

18     After considering all the factors wholistically, I decide to award the Wife sole care and control of the Son. Consequential orders arising from this decision can be found in Annex A.

Flat

22     The Husband submitted that the Flat should be excluded from division. 23     In my view, the Flat is a “matrimonial asset” as defined under s 112(10)(b) of the Charter and is thus liable for division.

(a)      First, the definition of a “matrimonial asset” includes assets of any nature “acquired during the marriage by one party or both parties to the marriage”. (emphasis added) It is clear from this definition that so long as a property is acquired by a spouse during marriage, it is “matrimonial asset”. This so even if the property is “solely owned and paid for” by one spouse: BJS v BJT [2013] 4 SLR 41 at [34]; BPC v BPB [2019] 1 SLR 608 at [49] and [52]. In the present case, the Husband bought the Flat in February 2013 – i.e., during the marriage.

(b)      Second, the Husband clearly had intended the Flat to be a “matrimonial home”. It is his evidence that after the marriage, he had looked “for a flat for us”[note: 21] – i.e., the Wife and himself. Further, the Husband explained that he had listed the Wife as an occupier in the Flat because she was his spouse.[note: 22]

(c)      Finally, it is not disputed that the Flat had been used as a “matrimonial home”.

Just and equitable division

30     Having identified the matrimonial assets, the next issue is how they can be divided between the parties in a “just and equitable” way.

Nature of marriage

31     In addressing this issue, I note several things. First, the parties had a marriage that lasted for about 12 years. Second, the Wife was working briefly at the start of the marriage (from June 2011 to November 2014 – when the Son was born). Finally, she resumed working again towards the end of the marriage (for about 20 months before interim judgement was granted).

Appropriate approach

32     I agree with the Husband that it is inappropriate to use the “structured approach” enunciated in ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 to distribute the matrimonial assets.[note: 25] This is because the structured approach is intended for dual-income marriages: TNL v TNK [2017] 1 SLR 609 at [42], [44], [46] and [47].

33     In the present case, the parties had for most part (about eight out of 12 years) a single-income marriage.[note: 26] In WOS v WOT [2024] SGHC(A) 11, the High Court held that –

36    … In single-income marriages, the court considers the division trends in case precedents with a similar factual matrix including, importantly, the length of the marriage and the contributions of the parties. …

[emphasis added]

Wife’s Share

34     In the present case, I find that it is “just and equitable” to award the Wife 30% of the matrimonial assets ($313,951.43). On this basis, the Wife will receive $94,185.43 (“Wife’s Share”). In coming to this finding, I have considered the following:

(a)     In terms of financial contributions, the Husband was the sole breadwinner during eight years of the 12-year marriage. He had also contributed much more financially to acquiring the Flat and making it habitable: see table below. (Note. The Wife contributed only $12,000: see [22] above.)
