XKY v XKX and another matter

XKY v XKX and another matter
[2025] SGFC 37

Case Number:SS 265 and 280 of 2024
Decision Date:07 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The applicant in person and unrepresented; The respondent in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XKY — XKX — XKZ

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

Family Law – Domestic Exclusion Order

7 April 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       There were two applications before me in SS 265 and 280 of 2024 (“SS 265” and “SS 280”). The parents had taken out applications for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) for themselves and their youngest son in SS 265 and 280 of 2024. In addition to the PPO, a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) was also sought. The respondent is their eldest son [XKX].[note: 1]

2       I heard the trial over the course of three days. Upon conclusion of the trial, I reserved judgment, after parties had made their respective oral submissions. On 21 March 2025, I handed down my judgment, allowing the applications in both SS 265 and 280, and giving the following reasons for doing so.

3       It is well-established law that an applicant for a PPO must establish the following two requirements on a balance of probabilities. First, that the respondent had either committed an act of family violence (as is defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961)[note: 2] or was likely to commit family violence. Second, that the PPO is necessary.

4       I found that XKX was indeed likely to commit family violence. It was apparent from the course of his testimony, that he bore a deep grudge towards his parents and younger brother. XKX recounted how his parents would favour his younger brother – for instance, he shared how his parents had purchased the latest gadgets for his younger brother, but neglected to do the same for him. He also recounted how he would have to shoulder the blame for the fights and scuffles that he would have with his younger brother. Whenever these fights took place, his mother would cane him, but do nothing to discipline his younger brother.

5       Naturally, XKX’s parents felt wronged by his accusation that they had especially doted on or favoured his younger brother over him. The both of them, especially XKX’s mother, sought to challenge XKX’s narrative on this point during the course of XKX’s cross-examination.

6       In assessing the merits of both applications, it is not necessary for me to decide whether XKX’s parents had indeed doted on him, nor do I need to determine whether XKX had a valid basis for holding a grudge against the rest of his family. What was abundantly clear to me was that XKX did hold this deep-seated grudge which left him feeling isolated and all alone in the world as he had no member of his family to confide in, to the point where he only had ChatGPT to turn to.

7       More importantly, however, that grudge which XKX held did lead him to lash out violently against his family members. His father bore the brunt of XKX’s wrath as was evident from the various pictures showing the extent of his injuries. Indeed, XKX did not deny hitting his father, nor did XKX deny getting into several altercations with his parents as well as his younger brother. These altercations demonstrated XKX’s proclivity for violence – for instance, XKX admitted to biting his brother. He also recounted how he had gone into “a frenzy” when his father had, in one incident, grabbed him by the collar – he lashed out blindly and kicked his mother in the leg.

8       As to the necessity of ordering a PPO, the cases tell us that once it is established that the respondent is likely to commit family violence, it follows as a matter of logic that a PPO is necessary to protect the applicant: XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [21(a)] citing Lai Kwok Kin v Teo Zien Jackson [2020] 5 SLR 389 at [39].

9       Leaving aside any presumption, on the facts before me, I found it necessary to order a PPO for the protection of XKX’s parents as well as his younger brother. Determining the necessity of a PPO is, in essence, a risk assessment: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [19]. The court must consider the likelihood of the respondent committing further acts of family violence on the applicant.

10     A PPO is indeed necessary in the present case. XKX still bears a deep resentment towards his parents and younger brother, and he has, through his own account of the incidents in contention, demonstrated a propensity for violence. These are significant red flags pointing towards the necessity of a PPO. While XKX has already moved out to live on his own, and indicated that he wished to cut off any and all ties with his family, the mere physical separation in this case does not suffice to reduce the risk of family violence. Until XKX has learnt to let go of his hate, anger and animosity towards the rest of his family, it is, in my judgment, quite likely that there will continue to be a high risk of family violence.

11     In this connection, and for the same reasons that I have already set out, I also find it necessary to grant a DEO for the protection or personal safety of the applicant. This enforced physical separation is needed to ensure that there are no further acts of physical violence.

12     In summary, both applications in SS 265 and 280 are allowed in its entirety. In addition to the PPO and DEO, I am also ordering that all parties (XKX, as well as his parents and younger brother) go for counselling.

13     On this final note, I conclude with a few words to XKX.

14     While I have made the relevant orders against you, I must emphasise that the purpose of this trial was to ascertain whether a PPO and a DEO should be granted for the protection of your family members. The orders that I have made are not meant to punish you. They are meant to ensure the protection of your parents and younger brother. That much is made clear by the relevant provisions in the Women’s Charter as well as the jurisprudence of the Family Courts (see e.g. WSD v WSE and another matter [2024] SGFC 1 at [1]).

15     I must also remind you of the effect of these orders. You are not to commit family violence on your parents or your younger brother. This includes physically attacking, or verbally abusing them. The breach of these orders is an arrestable offence, for which penalties include a fine or imprisonment: see s 65(10) of the Women’s Charter 1961.

16     In practical terms, this is effect of the DEO which I have ordered: home is now behind you – but a whole world lies ahead. I strongly urge you to use this as a fresh start. Where you go from here is entirely up to you, but nothing is impossible if you are willing to learn and to put in the hard work. Above all, you must work on laying to rest the grievances, resentment and hurt you have accrued over the years for you will not truly be at peace until you have done so.

[note: 1][XKX] had, due to his age, a litigation representative (his aunt) at the hearing before me.

[note: 2]References to the Women’s Charter 1961 in this judgment are references to the version in force before 2 January 2025.

Counsel Name(s): Han Guang Yuan, Keith and Korycinska, Joanna Karolina (Oon & Bazul LLP) for the Plaintiff; Chenthil Kumar Kumarasingam, Thaddeus Oh and Muhammad Matin Bin Abdul Razak (Withers Khattarwong LLP) for the Defendant.
Parties: XKF — XKG

Lasting Power of Attorney – Statutory Declaration – Mental Capacity Assessment – Functional and Clinical Component

3 April 2025

District Judge Shobha Nair:

Introduction

1       The plaintiff filed an application for a declaration that his mother (P) did not have mental capacity when she executed a lasting power of attorney (LPA) on 23 August 2023 and accordingly to revoke the LPA. The second substantive prayer was for the court to declare that a statutory declaration (SD) P made on the same day is invalid, and for the same reason. Section 19 of the Mental Capacity Act[note: 1] (MCA) empowers a court to make declarations as to:

(a) whether a person has or lacks capacity to make a decision specified in the declaration;

(b) whether a person has or lacks capacity to make decisions on the matters described in the declaration;

(c) the lawfulness or otherwise of any act done or yet to be done, in relation to that person.

2       The defendant is the brother of P and the uncle of the plaintiff. He is named as the sole donee of powers under the LPA while the defendant’s son is named as the successor, in the event the defendant is unable to perform his duties.

3       It was not disputed that at the time of the hearing, P did not have mental capacity. Section 17(4) of the Act provides that a court may revoke a LPA if P does not have the mental capacity to do so. Having heard the evidence, I allowed the application. The defendant appeals against the same.

Factual Background

4       The plaintiff is 60 years old and the only child of P. He lives in Australia with his family. The defendant is 90 years old and an American citizen. He lives in the United States of America (U.S). Both the plaintiff and defendant are medical doctors. P is an 86-year-old British National and a permanent resident in Singapore. The defendant, P and another sister lost their parents during World War II and the defendant expressed how he has been very protective of his sisters arising from those early challenges. They appear to have grown up in a very loving environment after their adoption by a couple.

5       Up until 21 July 2023, P was living in a condominium unit in Singapore. On 2 August 2023, she was moved to a transitional care facility under the care of medical doctors. Given the medical challenges P was facing, the defendant visited Singapore in August 2023 to attend to matters relating to 2 properties that were in the name of P. The defendant’s last visit was when P and the defendant’s mother had passed away in 2010.

6       When the plaintiff visited P later in December 2023, he found letters from the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) and discovered that P had a LPA issued on 24 August 2023 and registered on 14 November 2023. He subsequently discovered that P had also made a SD on the same day which effectively acknowledges that two residential properties in Singapore which included the condominium P was living in prior to her admission to the care facility, and ownership of a company which was incorporated in the British Virgin Islands in 1997 belonged to the defendant. P however is the sole director and shareholder of this company but according to the defendant, P was holding it on trust for the defendant. It was the defendant’s position that the company was used to purchase the 2 residential properties and that it was effectively his properties.

7       The plaintiff was of the view that P could not have had the mental capacity to execute the LPA and SD and sought declarations that these documents were not valid arising from such incapacity. He based his position on his interactions with P and medical records dating back to 2017. In 2017, P started to exhibit signs of cognitive impairment. In 2020 she was diagnosed with dementia by a geriatrician at a local hospital. On 13 July 2023, doctors at the same hospital were of the view that P had moderate dementia. On 21 July 2023, she was admitted to another hospital after a fall and remained there till 2 August 2023. A doctor from the hospital’s psychological medicine unit informed that P had no mental capacity to manage her affairs, and she was transferred to a transitional facility at the Singapore Expo Hall. On 8 September 2023, a cognitive neurologist (Dr A) from the hospital, saw and diagnosed P with Alzheimer’s disease. Over a 3-month period from September to December 2023, P saw a senior psychiatrist consultant (Dr B) at the hospital she was attended to prior to her fall. Dr B expressed that she had grave concerns about the capacity of P especially with regards her ability to manage her financial affairs. On 15 December 2023 the same cognitive neurologist who diagnosed P with Alzheimer’s disease on 8 September 2023 was of the view that P had no mental capacity to take care of her personal and financial affairs.

8       It was the position of the defendant that the SD and the LPA are properly executed documents. The SD was made before a Commissioner for Oaths (CFO) and practising lawyer of about 20 years. A consultant psychiatrist (Dr C) who met P on 1 December 2022, 22 August 2023 and 24 August 2023 was of the view that P had the mental capacity to do so. Dr C also met with a female relative of P and the son of the defendant to obtain more information on P on 29 November 2022 and 15 August 2022, respectively. A consultant geriatrician (Dr D) and consultant neurologist (Dr E), both in private practice, had given evidence to explain certain positions with respect to mental capacity assessments generally and to opine on the evidence of the doctors called by the plaintiff, specifically. Neither had the opportunity of assessing P.

Relevant Laws

9       With the enactment of the MCA in 2008 and encouragement in recent years by the OPG Singapore residents to make a LPA, many have taken the step to do so. A LPA provides the opportunity to exercise one’s autonomy in choosing the person or persons one would like to manage one’s personal welfare and financial matters, if and when one loses capacity to do so. Much like the choice of an executor of a will, a donor’s choice of donee is rooted in trust. The making of a LPA must therefore always be reflective of the choice of the donor who can only make that choice with cognitive awareness and an understanding of the powers he is vesting in a donee. A LPA is only activated when the donor is medically assessed to have lost mental capacity.

10     Given that the contention in this case was that P had no mental capacity to make the LPA and SD, it must be shown that P was unable to make those decisions and that the inability was caused by a mental impairment. These refer to the functional and clinical components of assessment.[note: 2] It is important to appreciate that suffering from a neurodegenerative disease does not mean that a person lacks the mental capacity to make decisions. One must look at the individual at the time the decision was made and the nature of the decision itself. This important guidance is provided at paragraph 4.3.2 of the Code of Practice: MCA (September 2023) issued by the OPG.

11     The requirements for capacity to be determined are provided in s 5(1) of the MCA against the backdrop of s 3 of the Act which refers to the presumption of capacity.[note: 3] Under the provisions of s 5(1), P must have been able to understand the information relevant to her decisions, be able to retain it, use or weigh that information as part of the process of making the decision and then to communicate the same. A failure to establish any one of these would require a conclusion of mental incapacity. Expert evidence on P’s mental impairment is critical insofar as assisting the court with an understanding of the nature of the impairment and its effects on cognition. The functional aspect and more particularly, the question of whether the provisions of s 5(1) of the MCA are met are well within the ability of a court to assess even without the assistance of clinicians.[note: 4]

Functional and Clinical Components

12     The plaintiff spoke of the cognitive difficulties his mother appears to have been facing[note: 5] since 2020. Although having a 70% shareholding in a company and benefitting from the rent obtained from the company’s ownership of a 3-storey commercial property which was leased, she failed to encash cheques for such rental income in 2020. The plaintiff claimed to have also assisted P in filing her income tax returns between 2021 and 2023 because she was unable to do so. He also came to learn that P had opened a joint account with 2 individuals who appear to be distant relatives of P and a sum of $200 000 was withdrawn from an account P held with her sister and placed into the new account with these 2 individuals. In 2023, when the plaintiff visited P in Singapore, P could not recall having opened this account. P had fallen in her home in July 2023 and was hospitalised. She was assessed by a doctor to lack mental capacity and had to be moved to a care facility on 2 August 2023. Her cognitive frailty was therefore observed although not clinically assessed at that point in time.

13     The defendant claimed to have had a close relationship with P and suggested that the relationship between P and the plaintiff was not as strong. I did not doubt that P had great affection for the defendant. He too however, has had little direct interaction with P, given that prior to his visit in 2023, he had come to Singapore 13 years ago. In the time he was here in 2023, the LPA and SD were executed, raising concerns about the timing of such an exercise and the reason why it was done without engaging the plaintiff who is the only child of P. Depending on the nature of the decision that needs to be made, engagement with key members of P’s immediate family is a prudent step in understanding the capacity of P to make those decisions.

14     In this case, the only doctor who assessed the mental capacity of P shortly before the LPA and SD were executed on 24 August 2023 and who then certified her capacity to make those documents was Dr C. With the benefit of the assessment done just 2 days prior to execution of documents, his assessment must and was given considerable weight. He is a qualified doctor with vast experience. The issue centred on the adequacy of the manner of such assessment as it related to the decision by P to execute the 2 documents in question.

15     The CFO before whom P affirmed her SD is a lawyer of 20 years. He stated in his affidavit[note: 6] that he could not recall the situation at the time the SD was signed by P before him. He however was of the view that he would not have enabled the execution if he felt P did not have the capacity to sign it. Little turns on the evidence of the CFO given his inability to remember P and any interaction that he had with her prior to the signing.

16     It was Dr C’s position that P had the mental capacity to execute both the LPA and the SD. I could not safely conclude this for the following reasons:

(a)     The Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) that was conducted on 22 August 2023 showed significant difficulties with respect to time, attention and recall ability. The score of 20/30 obtained on this examination suggests only mild impairment but as generally accepted by all the medical professionals, the score is of less significance than what P found challenging during the examination and its relevance to the type of document executed. I was mindful that in having patients with dementia respond to questions, the medical professional would engage at a level which makes the patient comfortable and responsive. There is no need for grammatically correct sentences and even gestures are often used to communicate. P’s inability to recall 3 simple objects 3 minutes after she was shown those items made any suggestion that she had the ability to retain rather complex information related to the SD and LPA such that she was able to use the information and communicate her decisions thereafter, difficult to accept.

(b)     The contents of the SD were read to P by Dr C. The contents are by no means simple to understand for a person of advanced age, known to suffer from a neurodegenerative condition. It states inter alia:

“I do not hold, nor have I ever held any rights, title and interest in the property situated at XXX (property UEC) and YYY (property NR). To the best of my knowledge and belief, my brother…is the true and only owner of ZZZ (Company R)”.

P then asserts that she was “willing to sign any document to ensure” her brother “remains or becomes the only owner” of the properties and company. The author of these words appears to be concerned about a potential contest to his rights to the named assets. The question is not so much about his entitlement to the same but if it were appropriate to have P endorse such wording as hers.

P was not aware, according to Dr C, of the existence of property NR and Company R. It was the defendant’s position that property UEC was purchased to house their late mother and P who was giving care to their late mother. It was his position that after the passing of their mother, P continued to stay there and the defendant paid for all her expenses as this was what their late mother wanted the defendant to do for P. His explanation with respect to property NR is simply that it was rented out and the rental income was used to pay management fees and the like. It is unclear why the defendant needed to buy this particular property and leave it in P’s name unless there were some restrictions related to his foreign status. So too remains unexplained, why the shares in Company R was held by P solely and the reason behind P holding this on trust for the defendant.[note: 7] Even if I were to ignore the fact that there is little evidence to support the position of the defendant’s entitlement and accept that P was eager to ensure the defendant’s entitlement to the assets, the lack of knowledge of the existence of the assets which were in her name makes any declaration that she had no rights in the same unacceptable. Dr C merely informing her of the existence of property NR and that it belonged to the defendant is clearly unsatisfactory. A vulnerable person is in a space where things told by a trusted source is often accepted readily. If it relates to a family member who is loved, the readiness is understandable. I did not doubt P’s love for the defendant. I did doubt her awareness of the contents of the SD. Given that there was no engagement of P’s son who is the sole heir to her estate in the absence of a will, declarations of this nature during a time of vulnerability should be approached with some degree of caution.

(c)     P had no knowledge of her directorship or shareholding in Company R. In fact, when Dr C asked P if she were a shareholder, she was not aware. This lack of awareness is crucial to any determination of the validity of the SD. One cannot give away rights to ownership if one is not even aware of having those rights. Dr C did not question P about her directorship. He appears to have rooted his opinion on P’s ability to execute the SD on the sincerity he detected in Ps desire to let the defendant retain ownership or control of property UEC which she was allowed to stay in. While it is incumbent on the medical professional to assist his patient to appreciate the facts without inadvertently substituting judgment on behalf of the patient,[note: 8] P in this case was essentially signing a document based on information that Dr C obtained from the defendant. Given that this document essentially places ownership of assets in the hands of the defendant, reliance on information supplied by the defendant himself in the context of the lack of knowledge by P on the nature of assets in question, is unsafe. It bears repeating that the lack of engagement of P’s son suggests the need to block challenges to asset ownership. If anything, it should raise the need to engage and have a clear perspective on the family dynamics. Clearly not all family members need to be engaged. Given that the plaintiff is P’s only child, I was of the view that his involvement was important. In fact, the defendant’s son is named as a replacement donee in the event the defendant is not able to be perform his duties. If the nature of the relationship guided the appointment, it was not explained as to why the nephew is someone P was comfortable in appointing.

(d)     In relation to the LPA, I had similar concerns. P appears not to know the extent of her own estate. Other than potential interest in properties UEC, NR and Company R, her estate is relatively vast with 21 known bank accounts,[note: 9] term deposits, a securities portfolio of more than S$1.6 million, pension, Central Provident Fund (CPF) payouts and a 70 % shareholding in a company that owns a commercial property. I did not expect P to know every asset that she had but I do consider it necessary for her to show an understanding of at least some of the significant assets in her name. It appears to be the case from Dr C’s evidence,[note: 10] that trust in an individual to be the donee, is sufficient. While trust is fundamental, an awareness of what one has as assets which is entrusted to another to manage is imperative. Counsel for the plaintiff referred to The Public Guardian v RI and Ors[note: 11] in this regard, where Justice Poole stated in the context of those facts that:[note: 12]

“RD may have understood that he was signing something important, that it was to do with money and that RI and RO were to look after his money for him, but the evidence tends to show that he had no understanding of their powers”.

Similarly in the case before me, without any understanding of the breadth of one’s estate, it appears implausible that P knew much about the powers she was vesting in the defendant. At one particular part of the LPA, she even went on to endorse the ability of the defendant to sell or transfer her residential property without approval of the court. It appears odd that someone who insisted that she had nothing would need to say this. It is more likely that the LPA form, the details of which were not filled up by P, was a reflection of nothing more than the trust P had in the defendant to continue helping her with her needs, rather than a reflection of any awareness of the scope of the powers or the assets that were left with him to manage for her.

Counsel for the defendant submitted that in Re DT (UK)[note: 13] the court had found that the donor of powers had the ability to indicate who should have the power of attorney in spite of his diagnosis of dementia and more crucially, in spite of the court-appointed doctor’s position that the donor did not have any awareness of his financial situation. In DT however, the application was by the Public Guardian to revoke an Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA) which was executed by the donor on account of suspicion of a breach of duty by the donees. The donor had executed the EPA in 2007 a year after he had suffered a head injury. The question before the court was whether the donor could take care of his own matters and if he did not have the mental capacity to do so, the revocation of the EPA was sought to enable the Suffolk City Council to step in as deputy for DT. The question was not whether DT had the mental capacity at the time the EPA was executed. In finding that DT wanted the donees (his sons) to continue with their powers as, the EFA was retained. It is important to understand the context the facts of DT were set within.

Counsel for the defendant also referred to the evidence of a court -appointed doctor in TEB v TEC[note: 14] who opined that “I think I have re-emphasised the point again and again that you don’t have to be perfect cognitively to execute the LPA OPG, because if you had to be perfect, then I’d guess that probably about a third of Singaporeans above the age of 60 who have hypertension, diabetes and high cholesterol, including possibly some in this room, will not be able to execute an OPG LPA.”[note: 15] In contrast to another doctor who was of the opinion that a person making a LPA must understand the legal document, the court-appointed doctor said “…how many of us can understand the insurance legal documents or many legal documents that are put to us?...Again, it must be seen in the context of the OPG LPA. Do I recognise someone I love? Do I believe that that person will put my interests first? Can I choose them to decide whether or not, to help me, to help the doctors decide whether I should get the care I need?...if you understood what the policy intent of this…fully funded by the Singapore government, as part of our overall plan for ageing populations. It was meant to make it accessible and affordable for all Singaporeans”.[note: 16]

It is my view that while perfection is certainly not called for, greater caution must be exercised in the context of individuals with neurodegenerative diseases executing a LPA, given their vulnerability. In fact, what the LPA form says and what appears to be understood by some medical professionals are at odds. In section 8 of the LPA[note: 17] Dr C certified that:

(a) The donor understands the purpose of the instrument, including his/her intention to appoint the persons named as donee (s) and replacement donee (s) and powers granted to donee (s) and replacement donee(s) set out on pages 3-7.

(b) There was no fraud or undue pressure; and

(c) There is nothing else that would prevent this LPA from being created.

Section 4 of the LPA falls within pages 3-7 mentioned in (a) above. Yet, Dr C did not read or explain Section 4 of the LPA which relates to “Other Powers” that were given to the donee. He took the position that some of the powers are not important to be read back. I do not agree. A LPA unlike an application for deputyship, is executed at a time when the donor is deemed to have capacity. It is important therefore that all matters on the form are to be read and explained and not just ones that the certificate issuer deems more appropriate. The wording on the LPA itself calls for this. This need is especially critical when the donor is a person known to have a neurogenerative disease. The standard of care is high, a standard that can only be met if all parts of the LPA form are sufficiently explained in the context of establishing that the donor is aware of the breadth of one’s estate and the powers in relation to that estate that is being vested in the appointed donee.

The court-appointed doctor in TEB v TEC explained that the focus should be on whether a donor is close to the donee and trusts the latter to care for him. In the case before me, while it can be accepted that the defendant is close to P, it does not explain the choice of the defendant’s son as the replacement donee. Dr C certified that P understood the intention in appointing the defendant’s son but nothing supports this. Either P went along with any suggestion that was made to her or she did not understand it but endorsed it anyway. Either way, more questions arise from the choice. The defendant’s son lives abroad. Even the choice of the defendant may have been made without knowledge of important circumstances. The defendant shared with Dr C that he had undergone challenging medical treatment. He is 90 years of age. Did P truly appreciate the challenges that the defendant is likely to face if he were to continue with her care? I was of the view that she did not because she was not engaged in such discussions. The reality is that the defendant’s son would likely take over P’s care.

(e)     Dr C indicated that he had met with a “niece” of P on 29 November 2022 without P’s presence. The reference to “niece” in Dr C’s report appears to be a mistake as she was described by the defendant to be a cousin.[note: 18] On 1 December 2022, P was brought to see Dr C by this “niece”. The “niece” described P’s relationship with the plaintiff as not a close one. P shared that her son meant no harm to her but that they were not close as he was largely cared for by his grandmother when he was growing up. The “niece” according to the defendant, is part of a network of support for P as the defendant lives in the U.S. Rather unfortunately, no one from this support network could take care of P when she was discharged from the hospital after her fall in July 2023. On 15 August 2023, Dr C met the defendant and his son without P. No meeting took place with the plaintiff. P’s sister was also not engaged as P had indicated that they were not close. While it is appreciated that P’s sister who is advanced in age may not be able to provide information to Dr C that may be helpful to his assessment, reaching out to P’s son was an important step that should have been taken. He is P’s only child and there was no reason for the defendant not to reach out to him for purposes of informing him of his decision to have P assessed. The defendant, by bringing in his own son in the event the defendant was not able to care for P, spells a desire to keep the plaintiff out. For an important decision like the execution of a LPA and SD, transparency is needed and secrecy avoided. There was no indication that the plaintiff did not care for his mother. There were regular phone calls and visits by the plaintiff once a year. Geographical distance between P and her son, some difficulty in the relationship between P and her daughter-in-law,[note: 19] were all possible reasons for the perception of lack of care. In fact, Dr B suggested possible paranoid beliefs which is common in dementia. Dr C’s other reason for not engaging the son was that he was living in Australia[note: 20], a fact equally applicable to the defendant and his son who live in the U.S. This case therefore involves immediate family members who do not live in Singapore, which therefore provides sufficient reason to engage all and ascertain the accuracy of the defendant’s entitlement to the properties mentioned in the SD, the breadth of P’s estate and the observations of the family with respect to P’s capacity in recent years. Perhaps engagement would have resulted in the family considering the feasibility of professional deputies to manage P’s large estate given indications of cognitive decline documented by medical professionals from 2020, approximately 3 years before the execution of the SD and LPA.

17     Although the plaintiff chose to rely on the medical opinion of 2 doctors, I did not give weight to the evidence of Dr A who was of the view that P could not have had the mental capacity to execute the SD and LPA in August 2023 for the very reason highlighted earlier in these grounds with reference to Dr C’s assessment. Dr A saw P on 8 and 15 September 2023 but had limited interaction, relying largely on low scores on mental tests administered by his neuropsychologist. I could not therefore accept the basis of his position that P likely lacked mental capacity as at August 2023.

18     What I did accept as evidence of relevance and value was that of Dr B. She had seen P on 3 occasions, namely, 18 September 2023, 14 December 2023 and 18 December 2023 and put in considerable time and effort in understanding the mental state of P.[note: 21] She administered both the Abbreviated Mental Test (AMT) where P scored 1/10 indicative of cognitive decline and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) recording a score of 14/30. She explained that “I wouldn’t pay excessive reliance on whether the score is 20/30 or 14/23. What is important for the clinician, which I’m answering here in court, it’s very important for the clinician to make that clinical judgment and not be excessively reliant on screening tools and scores because they do not replace judgment.”[note: 22] She had on P’s second visit stated that P was incapacitated and suggested a court appointed deputy to manage her finances.

19     Both Dr B and Dr C had the benefit of speaking and assessing P’s capacity. It is recognised that a key difference is that Dr C assessed P just 2 days prior to the execution of the LPA and SD were executed. It bears repeating that I agree with the submission that the assessment should therefore be given considerable weight. Dr B saw P over 3 months (from September to December 2023) with a more complete examination on the second visit. I am of the view that it was still a period in sufficient proximity to the time of document execution. I was inclined to give Dr B’s assessment due consideration given the areas of concern with respect to how Dr C concluded on P’s capacity with reference to the 2 documents. If the nature of the documents were less complex, the determination of capacity by Dr C may well have been sufficient. If there were any other documentary evidence or evidence from a person in regular contact with P who may have shed light on P’s long held intentions and understanding of the extent of her estate, the determination may also have been different.

20     It was the position of Dr B that the considerations that a person in P’s position would have to take into account in the making of a LPA was not simpler than when making a will.[note: 23] She saw both as involving financial decision-making capacity. The exchange during re-examination was as follows:[note: 24]

Q:     So can I just ask you to explain why you say that -- can you elaborate on why you say LPA will come under complex tasks? What is it about the decisions that one has to make when signing the LPA makes it such a complex task?

A:     Because it’s being – having understanding in terms of the finances and choosing an appropriate person as donee. But we’re looking at – we’re also looking at impairments in terms of impaired financial skills, which we see in dementia, so it would be important to piece that information: is the patient showing signs of impairments in terms of decision-making/judgment/reasoning, before they make appropriate choices. For LPA, to make that appropriate choice in terms of giving powers for the person, in terms of choice of donee, they would be able to process all of this, so it doesn’t come under a simple task.

It was Dr B’s position that merely trusting a person to be a donee is insufficient as the complexity of the task of making a LPA requires an understanding of financial matters which she did not seem to have even during the assessment by Dr C. The need for this understanding is implicit in the way the LPA form itself is drafted, calling for all information to be read and understood.

21     The defendant called on 2 more doctors. The evidence of Dr D, a consultant geriatrician [note: 25] and Dr E, a consultant neurologist[note: 26] was helpful insofar as it provided an understanding that differences in opinion amongst the doctors who assessed P may be a result of the mood of P on the day or days she met the different doctors, as well as any other medical condition which may have impacted her level of attention or responsiveness during those days. However, the fact that they did not meet with P makes any opinion they have on the propriety of the assessments by Dr C of little value to the determination of the mental state of P on 24 August 2023. Indeed, such reviews should be avoided.[note: 27] A proper assessment of mental capacity must certainly arise from private interaction between doctor and patient, sufficient knowledge of the personal and medical history of the patient including an understanding of family dynamics, utilisation of screening tools such as the MMSE and MoCA, results from blood work and the imaging of the brain, where appropriate. While Dr C was the only one who had the opportunity to interact with P around the time of the document execution, the nature of the documents that is in question call for a high degree of care where the person executing it was by Dr C’s own diagnosis, suffering from a major neurocognitive disorder. In fact, the defendant’s own witness Dr D, said during cross-examination, that the making of a LPA involves “multiple levels of processing, so it’s different. Choosing a drink is a one-off decision with very little downstream implications. So to me it is clearly different…in signing an LPA, as you would know, there are different facets, whether it’s in terms of welfare, whether it’s with regards to managing my finances, whether it’s with regards managing my health issues, so I will be interested if a patient comes to me to see if the patient understands what he or she is doing and why he or she makes a particular decision.[note: 28] This observation aligns with Dr B’s position.

Conclusion

22     The defendant’s interest in the 2 residential properties and business entity, which compelled him to have P execute the SD is not an issue in these proceedings. Should there be a contest with respect to ownership or entitlement to these assets, it would be for a different time and a different court.

23     When one makes a LPA or a SD, it is an expression of one’s autonomy. It should not be interfered with unless there is good reason to do so. In the context of persons who have neurodegenerative conditions, it would be prudent to have them make a LPA to appoint someone they trust, to care for them and to manage their properties before the condition worsens. The appointment is particularly challenging as there are indeed good days and bad days, times of clarity and times of confusion. The standards to be adopted in assessing such a person’s understanding of relatively complex documents such as a LPA and a SD must be sufficiently high. Even if one were to trust another to manage one’s property and personal matters, a reasonable awareness of the extent of one’s estate and a reasonable understanding of what powers are being vested in a donee must be present. P in this case did not know very much apart from the fact that she was grateful to her brother for allowing her to stay at one of his properties. She allowed the defendant to do what he wanted with immoveable properties without court approval when she was not aware of what these properties were. The only child she has was not consulted even though there is no significant disagreement between mother and son and there has been reasonable contact between the two even as he lives abroad with his family. There was no reason why the defendant’s son was appointed as a successor donee. I am mindful of the fact that the wisdom ought not to be questioned. What I am concerned with is the inability to extend the reason behind her choice of her brother to her brother’s son.

24     The assessment of Dr C was given due weight. He was the one who assessed P closest in time to the execution of the documents. The ability of P to act is always time and decision specific. I was mindful that she did not need to know everything about her estate but the lack of knowledge in this case was troubling. The tenor of the LPA and SD was complex, requiring better understanding than was displayed by P when assessed by Dr C. The capacity of P to execute the documents did not meet the requirements of s 5(1) of the MCA. Dr C’s assessment was viewed against Dr B’s assessments a short period after the documents were executed. Her explanations tied in with Dr D’s evidence on the nature of a LPA and the need to move away from thinking it is a simple document requiring simple decisions.

25     Applications have been filed by both parties separately for appointment as a deputy of P’s personal welfare and financial matters. Parties have also attempted to resolve matters through the appointment of a professional deputy, which is in my view prudent, given P’s large estate and the fact that both parties live abroad. This has not however been agreed to. Even if P does not have any interest in the properties and companies that formed part of the subject matter in these proceedings, her care may be better handled by a professional deputy in Singapore.
