html:
XKR v XKS

XKR v XKS
[2025] SGFC 36

Case Number:Divorce No 4034 of 2019, FC/SUM 2661/2024
Decision Date:28 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Jason Gabriel Chiang
Counsel Name(s): Ms Tan Hui Qing (Harry Elias Partnership LLP) for the Mother; Father in person
Parties: XKR — XKS

Matrimonial Proceedings – Procedure – Without Prejudice – Exceptions to Without Prejudice

28 March 2025

District Judge Jason Gabriel Chiang:

Introduction

1       The privileged nature of “without prejudice” (“WP”) correspondence should be respected. The Courts, however, might be prepared to pierce through such privilege in certain exceptional circumstances. In this case, it was alleged that the WP communications in question showed unambiguous impropriety and/or that it was tantamount to blackmail, such that the Court should disregard parties desire to negotiate a settlement and admit such correspondence into evidence. The Defendant Father (the “Father”) filed such an application for the Court’s consideration in FC/SUM 2661/2024 (“SUM 2661”). Having measured parties’ arguments on this novel point of law, I found that the Father had not discharged his burden of proving his case for such evidence to be admitted. The Father, dissatisfied with my decision, filed his appeal.

Facts

The parties

2       The Plaintiff Mother (the “Mother”) and the Father (the “Parties”) are both Singapore citizens. The Mother is of Ukrainian descent and the Father is of Indian descent. Both of them are presently in their 40s and they got married in Singapore in 2015. They have 2 children of the marriage, a boy and a girl, who are in Primary schooling (the “Children”). The Mother also has 2 children from her prior marriage, an adult daughter and a teenager son, who had been jointly cared for by the Parties before their separation.

Background to the dispute

3       The Parties have been embroiled in matrimonial proceedings since late 2019 and I have been their docketed judge since early 2020.

Relevant history of the proceedings

4       Parties first approached the Family Justice Courts in August 2019, whereby the Mother had initiated Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) proceedings against the Father in relation to all four (4) children and herself. The Mother then shortly after, initiated divorce proceedings against the Father.

5       The PPO proceedings were subsequently resolved by consent, with the Father consenting to a PPO made in favour of the Mother, but with the PPO proceedings in relation to the four (4) children being withdrawn. Counselling had also been ordered for Parties in relation to this.

6       With regard to the divorce proceedings, interim judgment was granted by consent in January 2020. For a marriage that had lasted about 5 years, the Parties have been involved in legal proceedings for about an equivalent amount of time. Parties were both initially represented by legal counsel, however, after the initial phases of the divorce, the Father started representing himself.

7       Both Parties filed for interim custody, care and control and access application for the two (2) children of the marriage. After a Custody Evaluation Report had been conducted, interim care and control was awarded to the Mother, but the Father obtained significant access time of close to half of each week with the Children (from Sunday 9 am to Wednesday 9 am). Parties also retained joint interim custody of the 2 Children. Thereafter, Parties filed applications for the variation of children orders: the Father was seeking shared care and control and other terms and the Mother sought to tweak some terms of access. While shared care and control had not been ordered, the access terms were adjusted to facilitate coparenting. Counselling was also ordered for parties to facilitate co-parenting. Such children orders were made on 8 June 2020 (“2020 Interim Order”), 21 January 2021 (“2021 Interim Order”), and on 30 June 2022 (“2022 Interim Order”).

8       As Parties had a dispute in relation to a company that both Parties were involved with, the divorce proceedings, save for children issues, had been stayed in favour of High Court civil suit proceedings on 15 February 2021.

9       Parties eventually reached a Settlement Agreement on 20 December 2022 (“Settlement Agreement”) which included the resolution of the matters in the High Court civil suit, and the Ancillary Matters in divorce. This Settlement Agreement included a term whereby parties were to record a consent order in relation to custody, care and control and access, which maintained the interim orders previously made. Shortly after the Settlement Agreement and after the High Cour civil proceedings had been withdrawn pursuant to the Settlement Agreement, there were alleged issues with compliance.

10     On 3 February 2023, the Father took out a further application to vary care and control: seeking shared care and control and further adjustments in relation to the terms for contact time (the “2023 Variation Application”).

11     At a case conference on 21 February 2023, the Father indicated that he intended to honour the Settlement Agreement insofar as they pertained to the issue of division of matrimonial assets and the equal apportionment of parties’ share of the children maintenance they would pay for. However, the Father sought to be heard on the issues of custody, care and control and access and the quantum of the Children’s reasonable expenses. The Mother took the taking up of the Variation Application as a breach of the Settlement Agreement. Time was given to Parties to consider whether this repudiated the whole of the Settlement Agreement and how they intended to proceed. In any event, given the Father’s position, timelines had been fixed for the filing of Affidavits for the Ancillary Matters after the conclusion of the hearing of the 2023 Variation Application.

12     On 24 April 2023, I denied the Father’s request in the 2023 Variation Application for the variation of the orders to grant Parties shared care and control. However, I varied some terms of access to address issues in coparenting that had arisen (“2023 Interim Order”), which included the following:

“(q)     During each parent’s contact time with the Children, they shall allow the Children to spend up to 1 hour per day (in aggregate) following-up with the necessary practice, rehearsal and/or homework for co-curricular activities organized by the other parent. Each parent shall be at liberty to provide the necessary equipment, instruments and/or material to the other parent for such practice, rehearsal and/or homework and shall facilitate such activities.”

13     On 26 April 2023, the Father sought to make further arguments in an email to the Court. The Father subsequently officially filed Further Arguments on 5 May 2023 and supplemented it with a further filing on 12 May 2023. The Mother objected to these further arguments and filed a response on 15 May 2023. A hearing was fixed on 29 May 2023 for me to consider whether or not to allow any such further arguments. On 29 May 2023, I denied the Father’s request for further arguments and then he filed an appeal on 9 June 2023 (“Variation Appeal”) within 2 weeks of that.

Parenting Co-ordination

14     As part of the 2023 Interim Order, a Parenting Coordinator was also appointed to for an initial period of 8 months with the costs to be shared equally between Parties. As there were some logistical issues with the choice of Parenting Coordinator, a further order was made for the appointment of a different Parenting Coordinator (the “PC”) on 10 July 2023. Hence, it took some time for Parties to commence parenting coordination and their 1st meeting with the PC was conducted on 31 August 2023.

15     At a further case conference on 18 September 2023, the Father indicated that he had a positive experience during the 1st session with the PC and was seeking for the Ancillary Matters and the Variation Appeal to be held in abeyance, pending the completion of the parenting coordination. While the Mother was fine with the adjournment of the matter, she was desirous of a Draft Consent Order to be entered into based on what parties agreed. However, the Father was not keen on this. The matters were thus adjourned to 28 November 2023.

16     At the case conference on 28 November 2023, based on the counselling report received and Parties’ updates to the Court, there appeared to be positive progress. Thus, matters were further adjourned to another case conference on 19 February 2024, at which, Parties confirmed that parenting coordination was going well and that the only outstanding issues for the Ancillary Matters were for the children custody, care and control and access orders. Additionally, while Parties agreed to an equal sharing of children maintenance, what such reasonable maintenance (in terms of quantum and permissible items) was yet to be determined. The Father was desirous of seeking the PC’s assistance to resolve all of these outstanding issues. It was clarified that this was not within the original mandate of the PC, but that Parties were at liberty to engage the PC privately to try to mediate the matter and reach an agreement. The Father then indicated that he would be withdrawing his Variation Appeal.

17     On 14 March 2024, a counselling report was received and on 20 March 2024, the PC provided reporting on the progress of Parties. Hence, a review hearing of these matters was conducted on 25 March 2024. It was updated that Parties agreed to the Father’s withdrawal of the Variation Appeal with no order as to costs and a notice of discontinuance was being filed. Parties also updated that they had arranged for a mediation session to be conducted, on 9 April 2024, with the PC, as an accredited family mediator. Good progress was noted in the various reports and confirmed by Parties. The PC recommended a further term of parenting coordination, which Parties were agreeable to. I thus made a further interim order to tweak some wording on access terms for better clarity, to further appoint the same Parenting Coordinator for a further 8-month period and for parties to attend further counselling (“2024 Interim Order”).

18     However, subsequent to the 2024 Interim Order, the PC had to attend to some urgent family matters that had only just arisen, which prevented her from conducting the mediation session with Parties on 9 April 2024. Parties updated this to the Court in the next case conference on 25 April 2024 and sought further time to try to resolve matters amicably. Hence, the matter was adjourned for another case conference on 15 July 2024.

19     On 15 July 2024, the Father sent an urgent email to indicate that he was unable to attend the case conference as he had to bring Parties’ son to the hospital. He updated that due to the PC’s personal circumstances, she was unable to conduct the mediation session and Parties had decided to engage another senior family law practitioner from her firm, who was actually the 1st choice as a parenting coordinator (the “Mediator”), to conduct the mediation on 1 August 2024. The Mother’s counsel attended the case conference and confirmed the same. The matter was thus adjourned to 5 August 2024.

Parties’ disputes after a term of successful parenting coordination

20     On 5 August 2024, the Mother filed a notice of acting in person before the case conference. At the case conference, Parties:

(a)     updated the Court that the mediation did not proceed as planned. The Mother claimed that the Father had unilaterally cancelled mediation and that Parenting Coordination could no longer continue;

(b)     The Father claimed that this was not completely accurate. He recounted that Parties had met on 3 May 2024 at the Mother’s solicitor’s office to discuss an amicable resolution of the matter. Then on 17 May 2024, the Mother and Father met personally without lawyers to make proposals, but they could not reach an agreement. Then on 22 June 2024, Parties attended a joint counselling session. The Father claimed that certain agreements had been reached at this counselling session. On this basis, the Father volunteered to write in on this. He first wrote to the PC on 27 June 2024 and then forwarded the email to the Mediator on 28 June 2024. This email purportedly included the alleged agreements reached in counselling. A day before the planned mediation, on 31 July 2024, the Father claimed that the Mother sent in a Mediation Statement which reneged on the purported agreed terms. Such correspondence was all done on a WP basis. Hence, the Father decided to call off the mediation as the agreed terms were not being honoured;

(c)     The Mother informed that Court that while the PC had certain family matters to deal with, she had offered to continue to help with their family situation, but that the Father refused such offer of parenting coordination. The Father’s position was that it was unconscionable to make the PC continue with the sessions due to her family medical emergency. The Mother claimed to have offered to appoint someone else as a Parenting Coordinator, but this was refused too. On the issue of the counselling session mentioned by the Father, the Mother claimed there was no purported agreement, but just that there were 2 conditions as to how to discuss the matters in mediation. It is notable, that the Mother did state that there were 2 agreements initially, but when asked to clarify, she explained that they were conditions for mediation and not agreements on issues as alleged by the Father. The Mother stated that the Father had used certain language against her in the counselling session that the counsellors felt that it was no longer safe for there to be any further joint counselling sessions to be conducted with the Father and her;

(d)     The Court informed Parties that there was applicable case law on whether the Court can consider WP correspondence on an alleged agreement, and this could be heard with the Ancillary Matters. Parties were asked to consider the law on this;

(e)     The Father then first broached the issue that the Mother had purportedly used blackmail and statements that were not in the best interest of the Children in the WP correspondence. He was insisting that this needed to be deal with separately and before the Ancillary matters hearing. He was thus directed to file a summons application in this regard. This was unless there was an agreement between Parties to let such evidence in but that would have involved the Mother waiving such privilege. In response to this, the Mother confirmed that she would not be waiving any such privilege.

(f)     Given the conflicting recount of events provided by the respective Parties, the Court indicated that we would be checking with both the counsellors and the PC to confirm their positions on these allegations; and

(g)     I also directed that if the matter was not resolved, that the Father was to file and serve his summons by 19 August 2024, with the Mother would have to file and serve her reply affidavit by 2 September 2024 and the Father to file and serve his final response affidavit by 16 September 2024, in preparation of a hearing of the matter fixed on 23 September 2024.

21     On 6 August 2024, the Mother sent an email to the Court insisting that the PC appointed in March 2024 continue on and that the Father was in breach of the 2024 Interim Order. The Court replied on 7 August 2024 that the Father should be sent the email as well and that Parties were reminded not to litigate by correspondence. On 12 August 2024, the Mother reappointed her solicitors and filed a notice of appointment.

22     As the Court received an update from the counsellors, an urgent case conference was fixed on 15 August 2024, to see if providing an update on this would help clarify matters for Parties. At this case conference:

(a)     I updated the Parties that the counsellors’ position was that in the joint face-to-face session with the Father and Mother: “[t]he children's care and control matter was mentioned in the session by Father, who wanted shared care and control. There was no discussion and agreement on this matter as they were encouraged to discuss it in the mediation session.”;

(b)     Notwithstanding this, the Father maintained that an agreement had been reached during this session. The Father also indicated that he was still intending to file the application for the admission of the alleged WP correspondence that had went beyond the scope of any purported agreement on the basis that there was improper conduct of the Mother (and not Mother’s counsel) in such WP correspondence;

(c)     As the Mother’s counsel was unsure what the alleged WP correspondence that the Father was referring to, she suggested that the Father could write to them to identify it so that they could take instructions and hopefully resolve the matter amicably on whether such evidence could be admitted, without agreeing that it was blackmail or improper conduct;

(d)     Hence, I gave the following directions:

(i)       The Father was to send correspondence to the Mother’s Counsel on a WP basis on this and the Mother was to reply by the next day to state whether there was an agreement on admitting the alleged correspondence or not. If there was no agreement, the previously set directions for the filing of the summons by 19 August 2024 and the directions for the follow-up filings would still stand;

(ii)       Affidavits of Ancillary Matters were to be filed by 26 September 2024, in the event that Parties agreed to the admission of the correspondence in question; and

(iii)       Parties were to write in by 22 August 2024 to update the Court on whether there was any agreement to the admission of the correspondence, and whether more time was needed;

(e)     The Mother’s Counsel then updated that the PC was actually willing to carry on with the parenting coordination sessions and that this updated status was as of 6 August 2024. The Father indicated that if the PC’s situation had improved, that he would be happy to continue with the parenting coordination. In the circumstances, I asked Parties to check with the PC and confirm whether the parenting coordination was to proceed and to write in to the Courts by 22 August 2024 on this issue. I also thus adjourned the timeline for filing of any summons in relation to the issue of admission of WP correspondence to 22 August 2024 in the event that there was no agreement on proceeding with parenting coordination and holding matters in abeyance pending the outcome of that.

The circumstances relating to SUM 2661

23     On 21 August 2024, the Father filed SUM 2661 with a supporting affidavit, which did not address whether he was in agreement to proceed on with parenting coordination with the PC.

24     On 22 August 2024, the Mother filed an Other Hearing Related Request (“OHRR”) to the Court stating that on 15 August 2024, the Father had written to the PC copying the Mother, seeking clarification on her continuing with parenting coordination sessions. On 19 August 2024, the PC responded to inform parties that she has “since resumed [her] zoom meetings in between [her] medical appointments and [her] visits to San Fransisco”. The Mother sought clarification from the Court in the OHRR as to whether the timelines for the summons should be held in abeyance notwithstanding that the Father had filed SUM 2661. Then later in the evening on 22 August 2024, the Father sent an email to the Court stating, amongst other things, that:

“… 3. With limited time to think with this sudden development, the Court suggested, and parties agreed that if parenting coordination resumed, then timelines for the summons for adducing "without prejudice" evidence would be stayed. This made sense at the time.

4.    However, given the evidence let ad [sic] paragraph 23 - 43 of my affidavit filed yesterday under FC/SUM/2661/2024 there is no basis to delay timelines. The evidence shows that the Plaintiff has no interest in achieving the objectives of parenting coordination but more keen on wasting everyone's time while running a coordinated charade while trying to restart legal proceedings against me in the civil arena.

5.    The Plaintiff should not be given multiple chances to sweep evidence under the carpet while readjusting her story.  Therefore, I submit that the timelines for FC/SUM/2661/2024 should stand.”

25     The Court replied urgently on 23 August 2024 to both Parties’ correspondence that:

“The contents of the Plaintiff’s OHRR are noted. The Parenting Coordinator has indicated a willingness to recommence the Parenting Coordination Session over Zoom and the Court has also corresponded with the Parenting Coordination on the sought clarification. In the circumstances, kindly file a further OHRR or letter to Court to confirm whether both the Plaintiff as well as the Defendant agree to continue with such Parenting Coordination Sessions. Upon the receipt of such confirmation, the timelines provided for contested proceedings on 15 August 2024 would be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the Parenting Coordination and the hearing on 27 September 2024 will be vacated. This would also include staying the Defendant’s FC/SUM 2661/2024 until the conclusion of the Parenting Coordination, for further directions on the summons or for the summons to be withdrawn at such time.

However, the Defendant has sent an email on 22 August 2024 at 6.16 pm stating a change in position that he is now desirous of proceeding with FC/SUM 2661/2024. If there is no agreement on keeping timelines for contested proceedings in abeyance for Parenting Coordination, the previous directions shall stand and the hearing on 27 September 2024 shall proceed, unless otherwise directed. The Court will take parties’ conduct in proceedings into consideration for any decision on the outstanding matters.”

26     On 30 August 2024, the Mother filed a further OHRR that Parties were agreeable to continue with the parenting coordination sessions with the PC and that one had been scheduled for 2 September 2024 and thus SUM 2661 should be held in abeyance. The Court replied on 31 August 2024 that given the Father’s position taken in his 22 August 2024 email, that the Court required confirmation from the Father that he is in agreement to hold SUM 2661 in abeyance and sought that the Mother’s counsel confirm this. There was no reply on this. I also directed a Court Officer to contact Parties on the matter on 10 September 2024. In this regard, the Father informed the Court that he was desirous of the hearing on 27 September 2024 to stand.

27     On 20 September 2024, the Father filed his Written Submissions, Bundle of Authorities and a Notice of Intention to refer to affidavits filed in prior summonses. Later, also on 20 September 2024, the Mother then filed her reply affidavit in SUM 2661. Then on 24 September 2024, the Mother filed her notice of intention to refer to affidavits from prior summonses. A day after, on 25 September 2024, the Mother also filed her written submissions and bundle of authorities.

The 1st initial hearing of SUM 2661 & the admission of the Mother’s Affidavit filed late

28     SUM 2661 was first heard on 27 September 2024. At this hearing, the Father took objection to the Mother’s Affidavit as it had been filed out of time. He stated that he had asked the Mother’s Counsel, on Friday, 13 September 2024, whether they were ready to exchange submissions at the stipulated time. They only indicated back that they would be filing their reply affidavit on Tuesday, 17 September 2024 and that if there were issues, to take it up with the Court at this hearing. The Father complained that they had provided no explanation for their delay and had not requested for an extension of time. Even though the Mother indicated that she would be filing a reply affidavit, it is noted that the Father still went ahead to file his written submissions before having sight of the Mother’s reply affidavit on 20 September 2024.

29     I questioned whether the Mother had taken sight of the Father’s Written Submissions before filing her reply affidavit. The Mother’s counsel indicated that his Written Submissions had been forwarded to the Mother by one of her colleagues at about 3.19 pm on 20 September 2024, but that the Mother’s reply affidavit was finalized before reviewing these Written Submissions and nothing was altered before the affidavit was executed. The remotely executed affidavit was sent back to the Mother’s counsel at 4.31 pm. The Mother’s counsel also informed the Court that she had not reviewed the Father’s Written Submissions before the filing of this affidavit. I accepted the Mother’s Counsel on this explanation. On the face of the Mother’s affidavit, there did not appear to be any portion that was a direct reply to the Father’s arguments in the Written Submissions and the Father could not point to any specific point that he believed was a direct reply. The Father however, included in his Written Submissions a whole portion of about 6 paragraphs (about 1 out of 13 pages) on the argument that based on a civil proof of standard, that given that the Mother failed to adduce any evidence, the balance was tipped in the Father’s favour for SUM 2991.

30     The Mother’s counsel explained that there was some confusion on their end as to whether SUM 2661 was proceeding as planned or not, given that the Father had indicated on 15 August 2024 that he was willing to proceeding with parenting coordination with the PC and thereafter the PC confirmed her willingness to continue facilitating matters for Parties. Additionally, Parties had attended a parenting coordination session on 2 September 2024. A further session had also been arranged on 8 September 2024, which eventually did not proceed purportedly because the Father reneged on certain alleged agreements and the Mother felt that it was no longer fruitful to proceed with Parenting Coordination and sought that the Court make further decisions on the matter. It was only on 13 September 2024, when the Father sent correspondence to the Mother’s Counsel to check whether Parties were on track for the exchange of submissions, did the Mother’s Counsel check back with the Mother and realized that the parenting coordination was no longer proceeding. Only then did they start preparing the work to file the Mother’s reply affidavit. This was however, notwithstanding the Court’s repeated replies to correspondence to get the Father’s confirmation on holding timelines in abeyance and the Court Officer’s call on 10 September 2024.

31     I asked the Father whether the prejudice caused by not having the opportunity to review the Mother’s reply affidavit before the filing of his Written Submissions could be cured by allowing him to file his final response affidavit and thereafter to be able to file further submissions and for a costs order to be made in his favour. The Father could only highlight that his “tactical advantage” would be gone if I were to direct this.

32     In the circumstances, I found that the appropriate step to best serve the justice of the case would be to allow the Mother’s Affidavit and adjourn the hearing to 6 November 2024 and give directions for the Father to file his final response affidavit by 9 October 2024 and then for Further Written Submissions which could include rebuttals to be filed by either side by 30 October 2024. I relied on the judge-led approach to cure the irregularity of the Mother’s late filing of her reply affidavit, as there were certain positions taken after the last hearing on whether Parties would proceed with further parenting coordination instead of pursing this summons, which could have led to some confusion and a delay in compliance with timelines.

33     The Father duly filed his final response affidavit on 9 October 2024 and thereafter filed his 2nd set of Written Submissions and a Bundle of Authorities on 30 October 2024. The Mother opted not to file any further Written Submissions.

The 2nd Hearing of SUM 2661 & Decision

34     Parties then appeared on 6 November 2024 for the full hearing of SUM 2661 for half a day. Even though I had already decided on the issue of the admission of the Mother’s Affidavit, the Father sought to rehash his arguments. I allowed him to make brief statements for the record but refused to change my position on the admission of the Mother’s Affidavit. The Father exceeded his allotted time for brief statements and had to be reminded to wrap up so that the substantive issues could be fully ventilated in the hearing. As Parties took the full half day to complete their oral submissions, I reserved judgment.

35     I had initially intended to go through my decision with Parties on 13 January 2025 where a hearing had been fixed for decision and costs arguments. However, upon Parties’ requests, I agreed to deliver my decision by way of a Registrar’s Notice prior to this hearing. I originally indicated that the judgment would be released in the week of 16 December 2024, however, as I had taken ill before then, I only managed to release the Brief Grounds of Decision on 31 December 2024. Parties were kept updated on the delay in the release of this decision. As disclosed to Parties in the Brief Grounds of Decision, I dismissed SUM 2661 in whole with reasons provided, which are also largely reproduced in this judgment.

The appeal & costs hearing for SUM 2661

36     On 6 January 2025, the Mother requested for an extension of time to file costs submissions by 9 January 2025 instead of 6 January 2025 as previously directed as the Brief Grounds of Decision had only been released on 31 December 2024. The Court replied on the same day agreeing to this extension of time.

37     The Father then proceeded to file his Notice of Appeal, FC/RAS 1/2025 (“RAS 1”) on 8 January 2025 on the basis that he was “[a]ppealing against the whole decision made in FC/SUM 2661/2024 to (1) disallow evidence to be admitted and (2) allowing the Plaintiff late filed affidavit into evidence.”

38     On 9 January 2025, the Mother filed her written costs submissions, but no written costs submissions were submitted by the Father.

39     I then saw parties to hear the issue of costs on 13 January 2025. After considering the arguments, I awarded the Mother costs of S$3,000 for the dismissal of SUM 2661 and a further disbursement of S$125.80 on a standard party-and-party basis. However, for the costs wasted for the adjournment of the hearing on 27 September 2024, I awarded the Father, who was unrepresented, costs of S$500 to cover his disbursements and him seeking a consultation with a lawyer and his LawNet access to obtain case law that was wasted in having an adjournment. I also granted liberty to Parties to set off between these 2 costs orders. So, effectively the Father was due to pay the Mother a sum of S$2,625.80. The decision on costs is elaborated below at paragraphs 69 to 85.

The parties’ cases

40     In SUM 2661, the Father applied for “[a]n order that the [Father] be at liberty to rely on the written proposal the [Mother] issued the Defendant on 31 July 2024 marked “without prejudice” in this action, on the ground that the “without prejudice” marking is vitiated under the blackmail and/or unambiguous impropriety”.

41     The Father alleged that in the lead-up to mediation scheduled on 1 August 2024, the Mother made proposals in WP correspondence on 31 July 2024 that in the Defendant Father’s opinion would “unwind existing court orders as well as reverse all the progress made with the parenting coordination sessions” and that such proposals would ultimately “be harmful to the Children who are aged 8 and 6.5 years old presently”.

42     The Mother’s position was that SUM 2661 was wholly unmeritorious and should be dismissed with indemnity costs. The Mother alleged that the Father was “simply trying to use a backdoor approach to introduce WP correspondence for case building purposes and this runs contrary to the efforts made by the Wife in good faith to try resolve all the Ancillary Matters amicably in the interests of the children”.

Issues to be determined

43     Given the Father’s position stated in RAS 1, the 2 central issues to be determined in this decision are:

(a)     Whether the Court should have allowed the Mother’s Affidavit to be admitted, even though it was filed out of time; and

(b)     Whether the Court should pierce through the WP privilege to admit WP correspondence from the Mother on the basis that it was unambiguous impropriety and/or blackmail.

Preliminary Issue: Admission of the Mother’s Affidavit filed late

44     As stated above, this matter was 1st heard on 27 September 2024. where the Father raised issues about the Mother having filed her reply affidavit out of time after the Father had filed his 1st Written Submissions. His argument was that the Mother’s affidavit should be wholly expunged and, on that basis, given that she adduced no evidence to refute the Father’s case, there was nothing to controvert his position stated and SUM 2661 should be granted in his favour.

45     After hearing parties’ arguments, I accepted that the Mother’s counsel’s representation that she had not reviewed his Written Submissions prior to finalizing the Mother’s reply affidavit. I held that the appropriate remedy would be to allow the Father to file his final reply affidavit and then both sides be given the opportunity to file further submissions, which would include rebuttals. I relied on the judge-led approach to cure the irregularity of the Mother’s late filing of her reply affidavit, as there were certain positions taken after the last hearing on whether parties would proceed with further parenting coordination instead of pursing this summons, which could have led to some confusion and delay in compliance with timelines. In this manner, the Father was not prejudiced and that any delay could be compensated in costs, if any. This allowed the matter to be heard substantively after the filing of the relevant affidavits and submissions.

46     In the case of BRZ v BSA [2020] SGHCF 17, the High Court clarified at [24] that the Court has the power to cure irregularities under rule 10(2) of the Family Justice Rules 2014, and should only not exercise this when:

(a)     curative approach would result in prejudice;

(b)     where the nature of the error is serious or fundamental that it cannot, in principle, be validated;

(c)     where the mandatory nature of the rule breached may be construed as excluding cure;

(d)     where the rule is sufficiently comprehensive to govern non-compliance; and

(e)     where the substantive application, if made, would have failed.

47     In this case, there was no issue relating to the limbs stated above at (b), (c) and (d). With regard to (a) and (e), the prejudice caused to the Father was cured by his ability to file a final response affidavit and further submissions and also for costs wasted due to the delay in the hearing to be compensated by a costs order. If a substantive summons had been filed for this, I would have also similarly reached the same decision. Hence, I found exercising the judge-led approach in this manner to cure the late filing of the Mother’s Affidavit to be fair and just in the circumstances of the case and to allow the actual dispute to be fully ventilated, instead of allowing the Father to have, in his words, a “tactical advantage”.

48     The Father was notified of the Mother’s intention to file her reply affidavit late prior to his filing of his 1st set of Written Submissions. Yet, he still filed and served his Written Submissions before the Mother filed her reply affidavit. There was nothing on the face of the documents that the Mother had been able to plug any gaps in her evidence by reviewing the Father’s 1st Written Submissions prior to the filing of her reply affidavit. I accepted the Mother’s counsel’s representation on when the submissions were sent to the Mother and when the executed affidavit was sent back to the Mother’s Counsel. Within this brief window of time, there was little opportunity to adduce new evidence to be stated in the affidavit, and moreover, the Mother’s Counsel had informed the Court that the affidavit had been finalized before the Father’s 1st Written Submissions having been filed. The Father also could not point to any particular portion of the Mother’s reply affidavit that suggested that it was in response to his 1st Written Submissions.

49     Additionally, while the Mother should have been more proactive in seeking the Father’s confirmation on whether timelines for SUM 2661 were being held in abeyance, the Father’s waffling position on parenting co-ordination was confusing. The Father had proceeded with parenting coordination even though he had already filed SUM 2661, but eventually ceased any further sessions, even though such further parenting coordination was mandated by the 2024 Interim Order and timelines for SUM 2661 were meant to be held in abeyance if Parties were engaging in such parenting coordination. The Court seeking that the Mother to confirm whether the Father was agreeable to hold timelines in abeyance was due to the conflicting positions that the Father took, which also made it unclear to the Court as to whether the hearing of SUM 2661 was proceeding or not. Hence, I had to direct the Court Officer to contact the Father on 10 September 2024 to clarify this point.

The Law on WP Privilege

50     With regard to the crux of Sum 2661, the Father relied on the case of Unilever Plc v The Procter & Gamble Co [2000] 1 WLR 2436 (“Unilever”) where the United Kingdom (“UK”) Court of Appeal (“CA”) in the Chancery Division laid out 8 exceptions to when a WP proposal would have its privilege removed and made admissible and relied specifically on the 4th exception that “the exclusion of the evidence would act as a cloak for perjury, blackmail or other “unambiguous impropriety””. The Singapore Court of Appeal in Quek Kheng Leong Nicky and Another v Teo Beng Ngoh [2009] SGCA 33 (“Nicky Quek”) adopted this ruling that the admission of WP communications is subject to a number of exceptions as set out in Unilever. In Nicky Quek, the Singapore CA went on to analyse the exception where WP communications are admitted to determine whether there was a compromise reached, and if so, what were the terms of such compromise. The 4th exception to prevent blackmail or other “unambiguous impropriety” had yet to be analysed in any reported cases.

51     The CA, however, in Ernest Ferdinand Perez De La Sala v Compañia De Navegación Palomar, SA & Ors [2018] 1 SLR 894 (“Ernest Ferdinand”) observed that this exception would be a vexing question, which the CA did not find it necessary to rule on, in that case, given that there was insufficient evidence of a genuine intention to negotiate. The CA did opine that it would be a balancing act where, albeit in reference to correspondence between lawyers, “[o]n the one hand, the integrity of the legal profession, and fairness to the parties with whom solicitors deal, requires that no amount of ingenuity of language be permitted to cloud the court’s view of what is, in substance, an improper threat or other improper communication”, and “[o]n the other hand, it may be unduly stifling to free and robust negotiation between disputants if any mention of possible criminal or reputational consequences could defeat “without prejudice” privilege”.

52     The Mother argued that SUM 2661 should be dismissed in light of Section 139B of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “WC”) that evidence of anything said, any document prepared, or information provided in the course of any attempt at reconciliation or mediation, counselling or family support program under Division 4 of the WC would not be admissible in any court. In this regard, I would have to agree with the Father that this did not mean that the common law precedence on the exceptions to WP privilege would not apply. As correctly pointed out by the Father, prior to the introduction of this portion of the WC, WP correspondence was also excluded by section 23 of the Evidence Act 1893 (“EA”). The cases of Nicky Quek and Ernest Ferdinand were both examined with the backdrop of section 23 of the EA. The Family Courts have also consistently considered the exceptions of WP privilege, particularly when it comes to circumstances where a party alleges that an agreement had been reached through such WP correspondence. In the alternative, the Mother argued that, pursuant to the holding in Ernest Ferdinand, WP correspondence would only not be protected by WP privilege if they were shown not to be bona fide and this threshold was a high one.

53     This case thus turned on whether Unilever’s 4th exception to WP Privilege was applicable. The Father cited the case of Motorola Solutions Inc v Hytera Communications Corpn Ltd [2021] EWCA Civ 11 (“Motorola”), where the UK CA analysed what amounted to an “unambiguous impropriety” for the exception to apply.

54     In Motorola, the claimant had obtained a judgment for sizeable damages against the 1st defendant in the United States and sought a domestic freezing order in the UK. The claimant alleged that there was a real risk of dissipation of assets on the basis of the evidence of statements allegedly made by the 1st defendant’s former chief financial officer during WP settlement meetings to the effect that if the claimants obtained a judgment in the US proceedings which was unacceptable to the 1st defendant, then the 1st defendant would take steps to transfer its assets away from Western jurisdictions in order to make enforcement of the judgment difficult. The judge at 1st instance held that such a threat, if made, amounted to an “unambiguous impropriety” and thus the exception applied. This was even though the 1st defendant denied making the threat, it was deemed sufficient to render the statements admissible that there was a good arguable case that they had indeed been made as alleged. However, the UK CA allowed the 1st defendant’s appeal. It was observed that:

(a)     the “unambiguous impropriety” was only applied in truly exceptional cases where the WP privilege was abused and there was no scope for dispute about what had been said – this would be a circumstance where the statement had been recorded or it was in writing; and

(b)     in determining whether this exception applied, it was wrong in principle to ask whether one party’s disputed evidence, if true, demonstrated an unambiguous impropriety, or on an interim application, to ask whether there was a good arguable case of such impropriety. Instead, it was necessary to ask whether the evidence established an “unambiguous impropriety”.

55     The UK CA held that although a threat to transfer assets to a third party otherwise than in the ordinary and proper course of business in order to render a judgment unenforceable might in some circumstances amount to an “unambiguous impropriety”, whether it would do so would depend on the facts of the particular case. Hence, the judge at 1st instance was “wrong to hold that it was sufficient for the admission of the statements that the claimants had established a good arguable case as to what was said at the meetings in question and wrong to have gone on to pose the question whether, if the claimants’ evidence as to what was said was true, that amounted to unambiguous impropriety; that, on the facts, the evidence did not establish an unambiguous impropriety such as to give rise to the exception to the without prejudice rule; and that, accordingly, the without prejudice statements should not have been admitted and the freezing order fell to be set aside”.

56     The evidence presented in Motorola entailed a photograph of a flipchart on which the 1st defendant’s former chief financial officer had illustrated his remarks showing 2 options: “appeal” and “retreat” in the event of an unacceptable verdict at trial. The UK CA accepted that on face value, there was an allegation of the 1st defendant threatening to move assets out of the claimant’s anticipated reach. However, the “retreat” strategy was presented as an alternative to an appeal (which itself was perfectly proper) and that the specific courses of action identified as part of the retreat strategy (i.e. reduce cash of subsidiaries and introducing a shorter payment or credit terms) involved no impropriety and had legitimate business purposes. Additionally, it was held that even if the 1st defendant did cease business in western jurisdictions, it would open the field to the claimant, who might be expected to welcome such a retreat). Hence, the UK CA found it difficult to see why this should be characterised as improper.

57     Moreover, while the 1st defendant’s evidence did not dispute the words on the chart, their account was not consistent with the claimant’s. The UK CA held that if the claimant’s evidence was plausible, the 1st Defendant’s evidence was at least equally so. On the state of the evidence, it was found that it was impossible to say that the evidence established an unambiguous impropriety.

58     The Father argued that the summary of the principle holdings in Motorola for the 4th exemption in Unilever to apply to this case was that:

(a)     there cannot be any scope for dispute about what had been said [about the blackmail or unambiguous impropriety], either because the statement had been recorded or because it had been in writing; and

(b)     that, in determining whether the exception applied, it was wrong in principle to ask whether one party’s disputed evidence, if true, demonstrated there was a good arguable case of such impropriety and that rather, it was necessary to ask whether the evidence established an unambiguous impropriety.

59     Hence, in this case, given that this is the Father’s application, he bore the burden of proof to prove his case beyond a balance of probabilities that the statement made was incontrovertible (provided in recording or written form) and that the evidence provided must show that there was “unambiguous impropriety”. It is noteworthy that this opinion by the UK CA is only persuasive and not binding as there has been no pronouncement of adoption of this in any higher court in Singapore. However, as noted by the UK CA, allowing WP correspondence to be admitted on the basis of the Unilever’s 4th exception, would be exceptional.

60     The question is whether the circumstances in this case rise up to the level required that made it so exceptional that such WP correspondence should be admitted on this premise.

The Law Applied to the Case

61     With regard to whether there were incontrovertible statements made, I agreed with the Father that there was written documentation of what the purported WP Proposal by the Mother was. The question was whether such proposals amounted to blackmail and/or unambiguous impropriety.

62     In the case of Ernest Ferdinand, the CA appeared to suggest that unambiguous impropriety would include an “improper threat or other improper communication”, such as, potentially a “mention of possible criminal or reputational consequences”. Hence, threatening to initiate criminal proceedings or the embarking of a defamation campaign against someone if they were not to agree to certain terms in WP correspondence could very well amount to unambiguous impropriety, which the Courts should not protect under a WP privilege. In the Motorola case, it was alleged that a threat was made to pull out of the relevant markets such that the other party would not be able to enjoy the fruits of a favourable decision. However, even in that case, the UK CA did not find that there was sufficient evidence to show that the statements made were unambiguously improper.

63     In this case, the correspondence in question was a proposal made by the Mother that the Father was of the view was not in the Children’s best welfare. Specifically, the proposal appeared to seek a rolling back of certain orders made for the follow-upon activities assigned by the 1st parent while they are with the 2nd parent (i.e. the 2023 Interim Order, the relevant portion having been produced at paragraph 12 above). There does not appear to be any allegation of a threat, thinly veiled or otherwise. The Mother’s proposal, even if it was contrary to the prior orders relating to the follow-up for the Children’s studies and cocurricular activities, would represent an attempt to vary the prior orders. It is commonplace in a large number of cases involving children issues for proposals to be made to vary access or custody orders for the Children. Each side that makes a proposal may view their proposal to be in the best interest for the Children, and could, in certain circumstances, amount to differing parenting styles of parties.

64     As discussed with Parties in the hearing on 6 November 2024, there could, however, very well be a circumstance in family proceedings where perhaps, in a relocation application, a party threatens to take the children away from the other parent, regardless of how the Court decides, in an attempt to extract further concessions from the other parent, where this would be similar to the types of threats described in cases such as Motorola, i.e. whereby one party is threatening to deny the other party the fruits of successful litigation in an attempt to gain more favourable terms. However, this was absent from this case. The Father argued that the Courts should not apply that level of the test in Motorola to the current case, as the claimant in Motorola was seeking a freezing account, whereas none was being sought here. Instead, when questioned on what the applicable test should be in the context of such children issues cases, the Father posited that if the Court had after reviewing the evidence, determined certain shortcomings and limitations and thereafter addressed that through an order of court to correct such issues, making proposals to dismantle such previously made orders would be unambiguously improper. This is unless, evidence can be shown that such proposals would be in the best interest of the children.

65     The Father argued that as the Mother had failed to explain why her statements were not an unambiguous impropriety, that the Court should side with him to apply this 4th exception from Unilever to admit such WP proposals into evidence. That appears to shift the burden to the Mother, when it is the Father, as the applicant, who has to prove his case on the basis of a balance of probabilities. Moreover, if this were to be the requirement, that would necessitate all WP proposals made by a parent to state the reasoning of such proposals. This is not something that has been practised and the introduction of such a requirement may unnecessarily encumber WP negotiations.

66     Furthermore, in testing the applicability of such a test proposed by the Father to a typical case, where, for example, the Court may have ordered joint custody of the children, which has been widely accepted to be in the best interest of the children in most cases barring any exceptional circumstances, and a parent may propose to the other parent in WP correspondence to seek a variation of such prior orders to grant them having sole custody. According to the Father’s test, this WP proposal, in and of itself, would amount to unambiguous impropriety, unless the party can evidence that it is made in the best interest of the children. If that were the case, then the filing of an application to vary joint custody to sole custody in most cases would be deemed “unambiguously improper” by the Father’s standard and consequentially, the making of any WP proposal prior to making such an application would also be deemed as “unambiguous impropriety”. I agree with the Mother that based on this rather low bar of a test, it would unreasonably open up the floodgates to admit a wide variety of WP proposals on children’s issues and would stifle the intent behind encouraging parties to try to reach amicable resolution of matters through WP correspondence. As acknowledged in Ernest Ferdinand, the application of the 4th exception in Unilever would require exceptional circumstances, and what the Father has set out, would definitely not be exceptional circumstances.

67     The Court may very well not agree with the proposals that a party makes in relation to the custody, care and control and access to the Children, however, the making of such proposals to each other in WP correspondence, even if it seems to the other parent not to be in the best interest of the Children, cannot amount to “unambiguous impropriety”. What one party believes to be in the best interest of the children may not be what the Court ultimately decides is such best interest of the children.

68     In the circumstances, I found that the Father had failed to discharge his burden of proving that the purported proposals made by the Mother amounted to unambiguous impropriety and/or blackmail such that they should be admitted into evidence, notwithstanding that they had been made in the context of WP correspondence.

Costs

Parties Arguments on Costs

69     The Mother sought that the Court make an order for costs against the Father on an indemnity basis. She argued that the Father had improper motivations and that his conduct, in general, was to just to frustrate the Mother and prolong proceedings.

70     The Mother highlighted the CA case of BTN v BTP [2021] 4 SLR 603 (“BTN”) that held at [8] the usual course is to award a successful litigate party and party costs on a standard basis and costs on an indemnity basis is dependent upon there being exception circumstances to warrant a departure from the usual course. As pointed out at [15] of BTN, examples of exceptional circumstances include:

(a)     Where the action is brought in bad faith, as a means of oppression for other improper purposes;

(b)     Where the action is speculative, hypothetical or clearly without basis;

(c)     Where a party’s conduct in the course of proceedings is dishonest, abusive or improper; and

(d)     Where the action amounts to wasteful or duplicative litigation or is otherwise an abuse of process.

71     The Mother also further relied on the High Court decision of VVB v VVA [2022] SGHCF 1 (“VVB”), where the Honourable Justice Debbie Ong held that an award of costs is one way for the Court to signal that “adversarial stances are not acceptable in a family justice system that adopts therapeutic justice”.

72     Additionally, the Mother referred to the case of CSW v CSX [2022] SGFC 47 (“CSW”), whereby the Learned District Judge Patrick Tay held that improper motivations are relevant to costs, including costs on an indemnity basis. This includes applications for PPO which are oftentimes driven by a mix of motivations, some proper and others improper.

73     Applying such case law, the Mother argued that:

(a)     The Father had no basis for his application, it was wholly unmeritorious as evident from the outcome of the application determined by the Court;

(b)     The Father’s conduct in pursuing SUM 2661 was simply a backdoor approach to introduce WP documents for case building purposes i.e. to gain an advantage in the Ancillary Matters proceedings on the issues of custody, care and control and access. SUM 2661 not only ran contrary to efforts by the Mother to resolve the Ancillary Matters in good faith but was clearly taken out for improper purposes and an abuse of process;

(c)     Given that the contents of the WP settlement proposals and the arguments by the Father about the Mother purportedly blackmailing or conducting herself with unambiguous impropriety, which was denied, even taking the Father’s case at its highest that he was able to satisfy the Court that these allegations were made out, such allegations would have ultimately no relevance to the Ancillary Matters and the children’s issues. These proceedings were therefore wasteful and an abuse of process; and

(d)     The Father’s ultimate aim was also to frustrate the Mother, cause her to incur unnecessary time and costs and delay the conclusion of the Ancillary Matters.

74     Moreover, even though the Father was in person, the Mother emphasized that the Court should not afford him too many liberties. In the circumstances, the Mother was seeking costs of S$12,000 with disbursements of S$125.80. I sought the Mother’s arguments on the appropriate quantum if costs were to be ordered on the standard basis. She argued that costs of S$3,500 with additional disbursements would be appropriate in the circumstances.

75     The Father objected to costs orders being made on an indemnity basis and proposed that a costs order of S$1,500 with additional disbursements would be appropriate in these circumstances, and that the Court should grant him a costs order of S$1,000 for the costs of adjourning the hearing on 27 September 2025 for further filings. Hence, the nett result that the Father was seeking was a costs order of S$500 with additional disbursements to be paid to the Mother.

76     The Father claimed that SUM 2661 involved a novel point of law, and while it was determined that his case did not meet the standard required that it was not taken out for any proven ulterior purposes. Additionally, it was the Mother who was late in complying with timelines for the filing of the affidavit and thus delayed matters further.

77     The Mother countered that they had been trying to save costs by only proceeding to do further work when it was finally confirmed that the Father was unwilling to continue with the parenting coordination. The Mother pointed out to the various applications taken out by the Father for variation of orders for children’s issues and now SUM 2661 as well as the various High Court civil proceedings to exemplify his deleterious conduct to frustrate the Mother.

Decision on Costs

78     Having considered Parties’ arguments, I held that the circumstances of the case did not rise up to the level necessitating the making of a costs order on an indemnity basis. I found that there was insufficient evidence that had been presented to prove that the Father had taken out SUM 2661 with ulterior motives. The Father’s case involved a novel issue of the exceptions to the WP privilege. That being said, while the issue in law was novel as there had been no reported decisions really expounding on this exception cited in Unilever, the Father’s case fell far short of any alleged unambiguous impropriety or blackmail required to attract such an exception. However, falling short of the required standards, does not prove that the Father knew that he had no case and had pursued SUM 2661 for other ulterior purposes. Moreover, had the Father been successful in admitting such evidence, it may have had some relevance on the issues of whether the Father or the Mother was more appropriate to have care and control or to have shared care and control. Overall, I could not say that the Father’s conduct was so improper to attract indemnity costs. While the Father had taken out multiple summons applications, this was the 1st summons taken out by the Father since 2023. And while there could have been an overall delay in proceedings, such costs should be considered for the hearing of Ancillary Matters and not specifically for this summons.

79     For the adjournment of SUM 2661 from 27 September 2024 to a hearing on 6 November 2024, the benchmark for the adjournment of a special half day hearing would be between S$500 to S$1,500. This is usually awarded on the basis of the cost of legal representation. In this case, The Father was in-person but had argued that he spent about S$700 for LawNet access and consulting lawyers on his case over meals. However, even if I were to accept that, the cost expended on that cannot be wholly attributable to the costs of the adjournment. The costs that should be considered would only be the wasted costs in not being able to argue the case on the basis that the Mother had failed to provide any evidence which did form a relatively substantial portion of the Father’s 1st Submissions. Additionally, there was also some further work that perhaps needed to be done to consider the Mother’s reply affidavit after it had been filed.

80     I could appreciate there was some confusion on the Mother’s part as the Father took the position that he was open to attend parenting coordination sessions, which should have held timelines in abeyance, but at the same time he was also insisting that SUM 2661 to be heard according to the previously set timelines. However, it should have been clear to the Mother that the Father’s filing of the application and subsequent correspondence indicated that he no longer agreed to hold timelines for SUM 2661 in abeyance. Additionally, the Court’s replies to the Mother’s OHRRs and the call by the Court officer on 10 September 2024, should have further highlighted the need to work expeditiously on the Mother’s reply affidavit for the hearing of SUM 2661.

81     Moreover, even if we consider that the Mother was hoping to save costs for further parenting coordination sessions to proceed, by 8 September 2024, where the Father no longer was willing to proceed with the 2nd parenting coordination session, the Mother should have duly updated her counsel on the need to start work on the reply affidavit and not wait till a few days after to inform her lawyer of this when the lawyer had to call her up to take instructions.

82     Taking that all into consideration, I found that the costs order of S$500 (all in) for this adjournment of the 27 September 2024 hearing was appropriate.

83     With regard to the costs for SUM 2661 itself, the benchmark costs for a substantive half-day hearing would be between S$800 to S$4,000. In this regard, I noted that the Mother’s request for a costs order of S$3,500 was not unprecedented as I had made a similar costs order in favour of the Mother on the dismissal of one of the Father’s prior variation applications.

84     In this case, while there was not as much spent on the evidence, there was a novel point of law that needed to be delved into and the Father also rehashed arguments on the admission of the Mother’s reply affidavit to have them placed on the record, when its admission had already been previously decided. He also exceeded his allotted brief amount of time to just state his position for the record and insisted on carrying on.

85     Taking into account the totality of the work done for the hearing, I awarded costs of S$3,000.00 for the dismissal of SUM 2661 and disbursements of S$125.80 payable by the Father to the Mother. The nett result of considering both costs orders, which I gave Parties the liberty to set off, was a sum of S$2,625.80 was payable by the Father to the Mother.

Conclusion

86     Overall, while the Father presented a novel point of law to consider in relation to a less common exception to the WP privilege, the Father’s case fell far short of any alleged unambiguous impropriety or blackmail. Even though the Father was not formally trained in legal analysis, the history of proceedings and his access to case law and lawyers to consult should have guided him to be more circumspect in the type of applications to proceed with. It is evident that Parties have been embroiled in matrimonial litigation for an extended period of time and there appears to be some level of inequity that the Mother has to incur further legal costs to defend against the Father’s applications, when the Father pursues such applications, in-person, which are ultimately deemed as unmeritorious and delay proceedings even further.

87     It is sad that the progress achieved in working towards coparenting for almost a year in the parenting coordination sessions was done away when the PC was momentarily unavailable to assist Parties due to her personal circumstances, which were indeed very serious and warranted her taking time off. I do have to commend the PC for her work on this case but have deliberately left out her name to give her and her family privacy and space in their time of adversity.

88     The ordering of parenting coordination in this case was a measure taken after multiple prior interventions were unable to get the Parties to effectively coparent. Regardless of the current state of their relationship, as parents, the Parties need to find a way to coparent appropriately. Neither party can only insist on their way being the absolute right way and discount the other parent’s views. I can only hope that Parties will consider the best welfare of the Children moving forward, find a way to cooperate for the sake of the Children and not needlessly take out applications which would invariably prolong proceedings. The overall conduct of Parties, including any refusal to proceed with parenting coordination sessions with the PC ordered by the Court, even after she had made special arrangements to accommodate Parties, will be considered in the subsequent Ancillary Matters hearing.
