XKH v XKI

XKH v XKI
[2025] SGFC 34

Case Number:Divorce No 2360 of 2021 (Summons No 3461 of 2024)
Decision Date:21 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Allen Chong
Counsel Name(s): Paul (Cross Street Chambers) for the plaintiff; Yong Hong Kit Clement (Beyond Legal LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XKH — XKI

Civil procedure – Privileges – Without prejudice privilege

21 March 2025

Judgment reserved.

Assistant Registrar Allen Chong:

Introduction

1       The present application in FC/SUM 3461/2024 (“SUM 3461”) is the plaintiff’s application to expunge paragraphs and phrases in the defendant’s affidavit[note: 1] (the “Impugned Paragraphs”), which was filed in support of his summons application in FC/SUM 3028/2024 (“SUM 3028”). SUM 3028 is, in turn, an application to vary an earlier court order (vide FC/ORC 3595/[xx]) to insert amended clauses to said order concerning make-up access, school holiday and overseas access and other matters.

2       According to the plaintiff, the Impugned Paragraphs ought to be expunged because they reference communications made in the course of without prejudice meetings between the parties and with their respective solicitors in attendance.[note: 2]

3       Applications to expunge references in affidavits which ought to be excluded as a matter of law under doctrines such as without prejudice privilege are routinely encountered in the Family Justice Courts. As to the issue of without prejudice privilege, it is uncontroversial that communications between parties which are made on a without prejudice basis in the course of negotiations for a settlement are inadmissible: Quek Kheng Leong Nicky and another v Teo Beng Ngoh and others and another appeal [2009] 4 SLR(R) 181 (“Nicky Quek”) at [22]. Nonetheless, I issue my written judgment to the extent that it contains useful discussions on the scope of without prejudice privilege and the applicability of the “delay exception” to the present proceedings. Specifically, I discuss the proper limits to the application of the delay exception, finding that a workable touchstone for when this exception may be invoked is that of relevance, ie, is delay even a relevant question such that without prejudice communications should be admitted to provide an explanation for said delay?

The existence of a distinct privilege in the matrimonial context extending to communications received in confidence with a view to matrimonial conciliation

4       As a preliminary matter, I am cognizant that the present case is raised in the context of matrimonial proceedings. I am also aware that there is a suggestion in the literature that the basis of privilege over communications in the course of negotiations in matrimonial disputes stems from an analogous privilege rather than without prejudice privilege per se as it has developed in the civil cases. I refer to the observations of the learned author of Ian Dennis, The Law of Evidence (Sweet & Maxwell: 2017, 6th Ed) at para 9-043:

Finally, an analogous privilege protects communications with a conciliator in matrimonial disputes. [citing Pais v Pais [1971] P. 119; Re D (Minors) [1993] Fam. 231.] This again is founded on public policy considerations; the law is concerned to encourage spouses to settle their differences and achieve reconciliation if possible, and additionally there is an important concern with the welfare of any children involved. The law here is still in the process of development and may not have exactly the same scope and limits as the usual “without prejudice” privilege.

[emphasis added]

5       Indeed, the existence of this analogous privilege was referred to by Walker LJ in Unilever Plc v Procter & Gamble Co [2000] 1 WLR 2436 (“Unilever”) at 2445:

(8)    In matrimonial cases there has developed what is now a distinct privilege extending to communications received in confidence with a view to matrimonial conciliation: see In re D. (Minors) (Conciliation: Disclosure of Information) [1993] Fam. 231, 238, where Sir Thomas Bingham M.R. thought it not

“fruitful to debate the relationship of this privilege with the more familiar head of ‘without prejudice’ privilege. That its underlying rationale is similar, and that it developed by way of analogy with ‘without prejudice’ privilege, seem clear. But both Lord Hailsham of St. Marylebone and Lord Simon of Glaisdale in D. v. National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children [1978] A.C. 171, 226, 236 regarded it as having developed into a new category of privilege based on the public interest in the stability of marriage”

6       That said, parties are content to rest their submissions on without prejudice privilege as it has developed in the line of civil cases. In this connection, I note also the comments of the learned author of Colin Passmore, Privilege (Sweet & Maxwell: 2020, 4th Ed) (“Colin Passmore’s Privilege”) at para 10-269 as to why this analogous head of privilege in matrimonial contexts even falls to be considered as an exception to the without prejudice privilege. Walker LJ’s rationale for including this head of privilege as an exception to without prejudice privilege was left unexplained, and the author found the inclusion of this privilege as an exception strange as “it is clear that this mediation privilege will be enforced save in the most exceptional cases.”

7       As such, I proceed on the basis that without prejudice privilege applies in the present case. Even if the applicable privilege is that of the analogous privilege arising in the matrimonial context, I assume that it would be similar in scope.

The paragraphs and/or phrases sought to be expunged

8       The Impugned Paragraphs sought to be expunged are as follows:[note: 3]

Impugned Paragraphs

Extract

(in italics and bold)

Whole of paragraph 7

On 29 April 2024, the Plaintiff and I, together with our respective lawyers engaged in a Without Prejudice meeting (the “WP Meeting”) where the Parties came to a settlement on the PPO matter. On 16 May 2024, the PPO Suit was withdrawn upon me giving a written undertaking not to commit family violence against the Plaintiff and the Child. At the WP meeting, Parties also negotiated on the child-related issues post-divorce.

Phrase in paragraph 8

On 31 July 2024, I commenced a by-consent variation application (FC/SUM 2421/2024) to vary the Order of Court FC/ORC 740/[xx] dated 13 January 2022 and the Order of Court FC/ORC 5775/[xx] dated 13 December 2022 based on the terms that Parties could agree upon at the WP Meeting.

Whole of paragraph 14

Although I had requested for a make-up access clause to be included into the terms of settlement for the by-consent variation application during the WP meeting, the Plaintiff was not agreeable.

Phrase in paragraph 27

While I had initially agreed to varying clause 1(1) to clause 1(k) at the WP Meeting in order to provide a more predictable schedule for the Child and the Plaintiff, I believe that this factor has to be balanced with my ability to actually have access with the Child especially in light of the unforeseen circumstances that are out of my control. This is why I believe that a suitable middle ground would be the inclusion of a make-up access clause.

Whole of paragraph 39

Importantly, I note that this was not something that Parties could agree on at the WP Meeting.

Whole of paragraph 49

I note that while this was a clause that Parties had discussed on during the WP Meeting, we were not able to reach an agreement on the same.



9       As to the Impugned Paragraphs, the plaintiff’s case is that these paragraphs reference the contents of without prejudice negotiations and as such should be excluded.

10     To this, the defendant’s case at its core is two-fold:

(a)     First, the relevant paragraphs merely inform the Court and provide the context to the variation application by only raising the fact that without prejudice negotiations had taken place regarding a personal protection order in FC/SS 2207/[xx], which the Plaintiff took out against the defendant, that the parties had settled the matter after the negotiations and that the parties had also negotiated on certain divorce issues. According to the defendant, the relevant paragraphs have been carefully drafted such that the contents of the meeting are not disclosed in the affidavit.

(b)     Second, and in any event, the defendant is relying on what he refers to as the “Delay/Acquiescence Exception” as recognised by the English Court of Appeal in Unilever ([5] supra) which allows for the admission of without prejudice communications to explain delay or apparent acquiescence. The defendant submits that the Impugned Paragraphs should not be expunged as they are needed to explain why there was a delay in filing the variation application in SUM 3028.

As the defendant is not relying on the acquiescence limb of the exception, I deal only with the exception's delay limb, which I refer to as the “delay exception”.

Issues to be determined

11     From the above, two issues arise for determination:

(a)     Do the Impugned Paragraphs fall to be protected under the without prejudice privilege?

(b)     Does the delay exception apply to the Impugned Paragraphs to nonetheless allow for their admission as evidence?

Issue 1: Do the Impugned Paragraphs fall to be protected under the without prejudice privilege?

12     I begin by analysing whether the Impugned Paragraphs even fall to be protected under the without prejudice privilege.

Paragraph 7 is protected by without prejudice privilege

13     Paragraph 7 of the Impugned Paragraphs is as follows:

On 29 April 2024, the Plaintiff and I, together with our respective lawyers engaged in a Without Prejudice meeting (the “WP Meeting”) where the Parties came to a settlement on the PPO matter. On 16 May 2024, the PPO Suit was withdrawn upon me giving a written undertaking not to commit family violence against the Plaintiff and the Child. At the WP meeting, Parties also negotiated on the child-related issues post-divorce.

14     The defendant argues that without prejudice privilege does not apply to paragraph 7. The paragraph seeks to merely inform the Court and provide the context for the variation application in SUM 3028 that without-prejudice negotiations took place regarding the personal protection order suit and that the parties settled this suit after the negotiation meeting. The paragraph does not go so far as to reference the contents of the negotiations.

15     From paragraph 7, it is clear that two facts are referenced: (a) that the parties had engaged in negotiations on a specific date, 29 April 2024, and (b) that the parties had negotiated on the topic of child-related issues post-divorce. I refer to these facts as “7(a)” and “7(b)” below for my analysis in the next section.

References to dates of negotiations are protected by without prejudice privilege

16     As to 7(a), an issue arises as to whether the dates of negotiations are protected under the rule of without prejudice privilege. While references to the date of a negotiation that took place are admissible, this appears to be rationalised as falling within the exception to without prejudice privilege rather than such dates falling outside the scope of the privilege altogether.

17     In Walker v Wilsher (1889) 23 Q.B.D. 335 (“Walker”) at 338, a case frequently cited for the proposition that without prejudice communications can be admitted in rebuttal of a suggestion of delay, Lindley LJ held:

No doubt there are cases where a letter written without prejudice may be taken into consideration, as was done the other day in a case in which a question of laches was raised. The fact that such letters have been written and the dates at which they were written may be regarded, and in so doing the rule would not be infringed.

[emphasis added]

18     To my mind, this statement is ambiguous. It is unclear if Lindley LJ’s statement is premised on the position at law that the dates of negotiations having taken place do not fall to be protected by without prejudice privilege or that such dates fall to be protected by without prejudice privilege but would otherwise attract the delay exception.

19     Some clarity may be sought from the case of The Leasing Number 1 Partnership v Commissioners for Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs 2015 WL 7693020. This is a case originating from the First-Tier Tribunal Tax Chamber, a tribunal in the UK dealing with appeals against decisions made by Her Majesty’s Revenue & Customs (“HMRC”) relating to issues such as income tax, corporation tax and customs duty. In that case, HMRC sought costs after the appellant partnerships withdrew their appeals. HMRC needed to prove the partnerships had acted unreasonably during the proceedings to succeed. HMRC argued that the partnerships could have and should have withdrawn their appeals much earlier and that failing to do so was unreasonable. The partnerships countered that it was reasonable to maintain their appeals whilst engaged in settlement discussions with HMRC. HMRC acknowledged that the negotiations and correspondence with the partnerships had taken place during that period but contended that this communication was without prejudice and thus inadmissible as evidence in the costs application. It was in this context that Judge John Brooks dealt with the issue of issue to determine whether the partnerships were able rely on the negotiations and correspondence to demonstrate the reasonableness of their behaviour. In doing so, His Honour considered the exceptions to the without prejudice rule as laid down by Walker LJ in Unilever ([5] supra). His Honour held thus:

Mr Maugham contended that the circumstances of this case fell within the fifth of the exceptions of Robert Walker LJ [ie, the exception relating to delay/acquiescence] as such evidence would explain the delay, which HMRC allege was unreasonable, by the Partnerships in withdrawing their appeals.

It is clear that the discussions and correspondence between HMRC and the Partnerships were a serious and genuine attempt to compromise the dispute between them and therefore was on a without prejudice basis. It is also clear that there was no agreement between the parties that such evidence be admitted as is often the case...in respect of costs... However, given the obvious restriction on the ability of the Partnerships to demonstrate their reasonableness in not withdrawing their appeals sooner if they were prohibited from relying on negotiations and correspondence between them and HMRC and that this evidence was sought to be adduced to explain delay I considered that it did fall within the...exemption in Unilever and directed that although such evidence could be admitted it should be limited to the fact that there had been correspondence and negotiations between the parties and the dates, but not the content, of such correspondence and negotiations.

[emphasis added]

20     From the excerpt above, Judge Brooks appears to have proceeded on the basis that not only did the correspondence and negotiations between the parties fall exceptionally to be admitted under the delay exception, but also the dates of such negotiations and correspondence. If this is the implication of this decision, I find that negotiations dates fall to be covered by without prejudice privilege. I appreciate this might be a draconian finding given the practice in many cases where parties refer the court’s attention to the fact and dates of negotiations having taken place, particularly negotiations in the Family Dispute Resolution Division of the Family Justice Courts for the purposes of matrimonial proceedings. In my view, this practice is justified on the basis that parties have agreed unanimously to waive the application of without prejudice privilege over such information – eg, by way of non-objection.

21     I thus proceed on the basis that the defendant’s reference to the fact that the parties had engaged in negotiations on a certain date, 29 April 2024, falls to be protected under the scope of without prejudice privilege.

References to topics of discussion in negotiations are protected by without prejudice privilege

22     As to 7(b), a question is raised on whether the fact that parties had negotiated on the topic of child-related issues post-divorce falls to be protected by without prejudice privilege.

23     Before the English Court of Appeal’s seminal decision in Unilever ([5] supra), there was some debate about whether the privilege only protected admissions made during negotiations. Unilever adopted a broader view, holding that the without prejudice rule protects the entirety of genuine settlement negotiations, not just specific admissions. This means that even statements that are not direct admissions, but form part of the negotiation process is generally inadmissible. The rationale behind this is to allow parties to speak freely and explore settlement options without fear that parts of their discussions might be dissected and used against them later. As observed in Unilever, parties cannot speak freely if they have to constantly monitor every sentence: Unilever at 2449. This broad protection aims to foster open and honest dialogue conducive to settlement.

24     The High Court, in its detailed grounds of decision in CSO v CSP and another [2023] SGHC 24 (“CSO”) (at [49] to [76]), has held that the broad approach in Unilever applies in Singapore. I need not traverse the same reasons save to state that CSO, being a High Court authority, is binding on this Court. I accordingly adopt the broad approach to without prejudice privilege in determining whether the topics of discussion at negotiations fall to be protected.

25     In this connection, the court will objectively construe a communication as a whole in the context of the factual circumstances to determine if without prejudice privilege attaches: Cytec Industries Pte. Ltd. v. APP Chemicals International (Mau) Ltd. [2009] 4 S.L.R.(R.) 769 at [16]. This implies that the entire substance of the communication is under scrutiny for privilege. While the cases do not appear to explicitly state that the topics of discussion are separately privileged from the content, it is logical that revealing the topics discussed during without prejudice negotiations could in some cases indirectly disclose the parties' positions, potential concessions, and the nature of the dispute they were trying to resolve. This could undermine the very purpose of the privilege, which is to encourage open and honest dialogue aimed at settlement without fear of later repercussions in court. For example, if it were permissible to disclose that the “topic” of a specific financial adjustment was discussed, even without revealing the amounts or offers, it could still reveal a party's willingness to consider that aspect of the dispute, potentially prejudicing their position should negotiations fail.

26     The view that references to topics of discussion are protected is consistent with the rationale underlying the broad approach, which is to further the public policy objective of encouraging settlements. The broader approach’s protection over the whole of without prejudice communications should thus readily be extended to confer protected over the topics of discussion.

27     This finds some support in the High Court case of CSO, where in considering the applicability of the “Delay/Acquiescence Exception” (as it is referred to there), Andre Maniam J appears to have proceeded on the assumption that negotiations on the topic of payments to be made (and not the contents of this discussion) is protected by without prejudice privilege (see CSO at [27] and [33]). Since the question of whether the exception applies is logically posterior to the question of whether without prejudice privilege applies in the first place, His Honour’s consideration on the exception's applicability would thus suggest that the reference to the topics of a discussion can be protected by without prejudice privilege. For context, I reproduce His Honour’s analysis at [33] of his grounds of decision:

33    In the present case, the first defendant could minimally rely on the narrow form of the Delay/Acquiescence Exception to say that in the period of 17 to 21 February 2020, the plaintiff and the first defendant were engaged in “without prejudice” negotiations regarding the payments to be made by the first defendant to the plaintiff. That would go some way towards rebutting the plaintiff’s second Assertion that the first defendant had not taken issue with the plaintiff being paid the retention money.

[emphasis added in italics]

28     Therefore, I find that the defendant's disclosure that they had negotiated on child-related issues after the divorce falls within the protection of the without-prejudice privilege.

Paragraphs 14, 39 and 49 are protected by without prejudice privilege

29     The paragraphs sought to be expunged are as follows:

Impugned Paragraphs

Extract

(in italics and bold)

Whole of paragraph 14

Although I had requested for a make-up access clause to be included into the terms of settlement for the by-consent variation application during the WP meeting, the Plaintiff was not agreeable.

Whole of paragraph 39

Importantly, I note that this was not something that Parties could agree on at the WP Meeting.

Whole of paragraph 49

I note that while this was a clause that Parties had discussed on during the WP Meeting, we were not able to reach an agreement on the same.



30     As to paragraphs 14, 39 and 49, the defendant’s case is essentially that these paragraphs set out the topics and not the contents at the meeting and thus fall outside the ambit of without prejudice privilege.[note: 4] As I have held above concerning paragraph 7, the topics of discussion fall under the protection of without prejudice privilege. In any event, these paragraphs clearly must be read together with the preceding paragraphs, and their inclusion may thus even be said to be a direct reference to the parties’ points of disagreement during the negotiations. This would undoubtedly fall to be protected by without prejudice privilege.

Paragraphs 8 and 27 are protected by without prejudice privilege

31     To recapitulate, the impugned portions of paragraphs 8 and 27 are as follows:

Impugned Paragraphs

Extract

(in italics and bold)

Phrase in paragraph 8

On 31 July 2024, I commenced a by-consent variation application (FC/SUM 2421/2024) to vary the Order of Court FC/ORC 740/[xx] dated 13 January 2022 and the Order of Court FC/ORC 5775/[xx] dated 13 December 2022 based on the terms that Parties could agree upon at the WP Meeting.

Phrase in paragraph 27

While I had initially agreed to varying clause 1(1) to clause 1(k) at the WP Meeting in order to provide a more predictable schedule for the Child and the Plaintiff, I believe that this factor has to be balanced with my ability to actually have access with the Child especially in light of the unforeseen circumstances that are out of my control. This is why I believe that a suitable middle ground would be the inclusion of a make-up access clause.



32     On the face of paragraphs 8 and 27, I have little difficulty finding that they are protected communications because they reference the contents of negotiations. While not directly setting out what was agreed upon at the meeting, paragraph 8 indirectly alludes to the contents of the terms agreed to during the meetings when it stated that the by-consent variation application was “based on” these agreed terms. Similarly, paragraph 27 also goes into the defendant’s reasons for why he had initially agreed to varying Clause 1(1) to Clause 1(k).

33     For completeness, I deal with the defendant’s submission that he has chosen to waive his privilege vis-à-vis paragraph 27.[note: 5] The defendant contends that he has waived his privilege to disclose that, during a without prejudice meeting, an agreement was reached to modify Clause 1(1) to Clause 1(k). However, I find that such unilateral waiver is not permissible. In United Overseas Bank Ltd v Lippo Marina Collection Pte Ltd [2017] SGHC 140 (“Lippo Marina”) at [104], Aedit Abdullah JC (as he then was) endorsed the view that without prejudice privilege is shared by all parties involved in the negotiations. Consequently, without prejudice privilege can only be waived if all parties to the settlement negotiations agree. This principle is based on the rationale that allowing any single party to unilaterally use or disclose privileged information would undermine the “safe haven of confidentiality” afforded by the privilege: Lippo Marina at [106].

34     To summarise, I find that all the paragraphs and/or phrases referred to in the Impugned Paragraphs are subject to without prejudice privilege. The remaining question is whether the defendant can rely on the delay exception to admit them into evidence.

Issue 2: Does the delay exception apply to the Impugned Paragraphs to nonetheless allow for their admission as evidence?

Relevance is the touchstone for the invocation of the delay exception

35     As held in CSO ([24] supra) at [77], the exceptions to without prejudice privilege set out by Walker LJ in Unilever ([5] supra) at 2444–2445—which includes the delay exceptions—were accepted as part of Singapore law by the Court of Appeal in Nicky Quek ([3] supra) at [23]. Thus, whether the broad approach in Unilever to the scope of without prejudice privilege is the position in Singapore, the same exceptions accepted in Nicky Quek apply.

36     The novel question for this court’s consideration is: What are the limits to applying the delay exception? The reported cases and academic commentary do not go much further than stating that without prejudice communications may be admitted to explain delay or apparent acquiescence. Is it the case that simply because delay might conceivably be raised as an issue at a hearing, a party is thereby conferred the license to pre-emptively include references of without prejudice communications to pre-empt any concerns of delay on his part? Yet, as a matter of judicial economy and logic, there must be limits to the admission of without prejudice communications in such circumstances. Else, without prejudice communications could almost always be admitted under the guise of explaining away any concerns of delay, real or imagined.

37     To answer the question of what limits is appropriate for the scope of delay exception, I find it helpful to survey the cases where without prejudice communications have been admitted allowing a party to explain their delay include:

(a)      Applications to strike out for want of prosecution. This is a primary example where the delay exception is frequently invoked. Courts consider whether there has been an inordinate and inexcusable delay in progressing a case, and the fact (and sometimes the content) of without prejudice negotiations can be presented to explain periods of inactivity: see Family Housing Association (Manchester) Ltd v Michael Hyde and Partners [1997] 1 WLR 354.

(b)      Cases where allegations based on laches are raised. When a party is accused of laches in causing unreasonable delay that prejudices the other party), the fact and timing of without prejudice negotiations may be relevant to demonstrate that the delay was due to genuine attempts to settle and not a lack of diligence. The court may review the correspondence to ascertain the attitude of the parties with regard to the progress of the case and which party, if any, was responsible for the delay: Jeffrey Pinsler, Evidence and the Litigation Process (LexisNexis, 7th Ed, 2020) at para 15.010. It is also apparent from the excerpt of Lindley LJ’s observations in Walker above at [17] that it has been the practice of the English courts since at least 1889 that where the question of laches is raised, without prejudice communications may be raised in response.

(c)      On an issue of delay in amending a patent. Similar to general arguments of laches, if there's a delay in seeking to amend a patent or pursuing other claims, and this delay is challenged, evidence of without prejudice negotiations aimed at resolving the underlying issues may be admissible to explain the reasons for the delay. The case of Redifusion Simulation Ltd v Link Miles Ltd [1992] FS.R. 195. illustrates this. The plaintiff sought to amend its patent, and the defendant objected based on the plaintiff’s delay in the making of the application. The plaintiff responded by referring to discussions during prior without prejudice ADR that it intended to apply for leave to amend to explain the delay. The judge hearing the defendant’s motion to strike out the relevant passages from the plaintiff’s affidavit that the plaintiff’s case for including the passages was “arguable”, leaving the question of admissibility to the trial judge.

38     The survey of the case law above point to relevance as being the touchstone for the invocation of the delay exception. Some guidance may also be found from Walker LJ’s remarks in Unilever that occasionally, fuller evidence is needed to give the court a fair picture of the rights and wrongs of the delay: Unilever at 2444–2445. Thus, a potential touchstone could be found in the court’s assessment of whether such evidence is needed. Or stated more directly, is the issue of delay relevant such that evidence of without prejudice communications is required to explain away such delays? I find this to be a workable criterion for cases where the delay exception may be invoked. In this connection, I echo the views of the learned author of Colin Passmore’s Privilege at para 10-210 that the exception should be “confined to applications where delay is relevant – which means, in practice, that the occasions on which it can be used are few” [emphasis added].

39     When then can delay be said to be relevant? While it is not possible to particularise exhaustively the myriad circumstances in which the touchstone of relevance could potentially be satisfied, I am of the view that it can minimally be said that delay would be relevant in cases where the question of delay has been put into issue. That relevance includes a situation where the question of delay has been put into issue is supported by the High Court case of CSO.

40     In CSO ([24] supra), the plaintiff had made two assertions by way of a supporting affidavit in the context of the plaintiff’s application for an injunction against the first defendant from receiving payment on the basis that the first defendant’s call on a guarantee was unconscionable. Of the two assertions, the assertion which is material for our purposes of our discussion of the delay exception was that the first defendant did not take any steps to extend a letter of credit (“LC”) which the first defendant had procured in favour of the plaintiff, pursuant to which certain sums would be paid to the plaintiff for the plaintiff’s performance of a supply contract (CSO at [13(a)]). In the face of this assertion, Maniam J found (at [34]) that that was an appropriate case where fuller evidence was needed to give the court a fair picture of the rights and wrongs of the delay (or inaction). The plaintiff had made the assertion that the LC had not been extended because the first defendant had not taken any steps to extend it. Thus, and more materially, Maniam J found that the fact of the plaintiff having put the allegations of delay into issue meant that this warranted a response from the first defendant (at [36]):

Given that the plaintiff had put in issue the reason for the LC not being extended (ie, the rights and wrongs of the delay/inaction), the first defendant should be allowed to respond by showing that in the course of “without prejudice” negotiations it had proposed to extend the LC, but the plaintiff had opposed that extension, and that is why the LC was not extended. If the first defendant were limited to referring to the dates and fact of negotiations about payments, the court would not have a fair picture of why the LC had not been extended

[original emphasis in italics; emphasis added in bold and italics]

41     To my mind, the fact that the plaintiff had put into issue the question of delay was what created the nexus of relevance between the question of delay and a party’s reliance on without prejudice communications in explanation of said delay. If such a question was not even put into issue, it is difficult to see how delay would be of relevance to require the admission of without prejudice communications.

42     Without circumscribing the myriad of ways in delay can be put into issue, I am able to at least say that delay would be put into issue where an allegation of delay is inherent within the nature of the application itself such as applications to strike out for want of prosecution, or where the question of delay has been raised by the other party (or, as one may reasonably foresee, the Judge).

The question of delay is not relevant in SUM 3028 to allow for the admission of without prejudice communications

43     In the present case, the defendant’s case for why reference should be made to the Impugned Paragraphs is two-pronged:

(a)     First, on 31 July 2024, both parties filed a by-consent variation application vide FC/SUM 2421/2024 (“SUM 2421”). However, a mere two months later, on 23 September 2024, the defendant filed SUM 3028, a contested variation application. Given the short interval between these two applications, the defendant deemed it prudent to provide an explanation to the court by way of his affidavit in SUM 3028 to explain the rationale behind this subsequent filing. The explanation lies in the fact that the parties had convened for a without prejudice meeting in the interim.

(b)     Second, a District Judge had, an earlier case conference on 22 October 2024, queried “why are there so many summonses in this case?” This is really a submission that the question of delay has been put into issue by the Judge and which therefore requires an explanation by the defendant.

44     I cannot see how the question of delay had been put into issue. I agree with the plaintiff that there was no live question of delay that required any explanation. From my understanding of the plaintiff’s submissions, the plaintiff does not take issue with any delay on the part of the defendant. To the contrary, the plaintiff has insisted that there was no delay. It was evident that the defendant had wasted no time in taking up the variation application vide SUM 3028 on 23 September 2024 less than two months after the earlier by-consent variation application in FC/SUM 2421/2024 filed on 31 July 2024. Defendant counsel’s reliance on CSO (at [28]) that “delay” included not only belated action but also complete inaction also did not find favour with me. Again, I struggle to see how there was a delay which required the defendant’s explanation in the form of inaction, even in the broad sense endorsed in CSO.

45     The defendant’s submission stands on firmer footing when he refers to the remarks of the DJ on 22 October 2024 “why are there so many summonses in this case?” to suggest that the question of delay had taken on relevance since it had been put into issue by the Judge. I would record that the notes of evidence of the case conference are not before me as evidence for the purposes of this application. As such, I do not have the full context as to why the DJ made the remarks that she did and whether her comments were intended to raise any concerns of delay, which called for an explanation from the defendant. In any event, I struggle to see how the remarks, which appear to be directed at the number of summonses filed in the divorce case, raise a concern regarding any delay in the filing of SUM 3028 specifically. I do not think the admission of without prejudice communications is necessary for the defendant to respond.

46     In light of the above, I do not find that the defendant can avail himself of the delay exception to admit the Impugned Paragraphs, which are covered by without prejudice privilege.

Conclusion

47     I allow the present application in SUM 3461 and order that the Impugned Paragraphs be struck off and/or expunged from the defendant’s affidavit filed on 23 September 2024 in support of SUM 3028.

48     The defendant is directed to file the affidavit excluding the Impugned Paragraphs by 26 March 2025. If parties cannot agree on costs, cost submissions are to be filed and served by 2 April 2025 by way of an “Other Hearing Related Request”. These submissions are limited to 3 pages each.

49     I thank parties for their submissions and assistance.

[note: 1]Supporting Affidavit of [XKI] dated 23 September 2025.

[note: 2]Plaintiff’s supporting affidavit in SUM 3461 at para 5.

[note: 3]FC/SUM 3461/2024.

[note: 4]Reply affidavit of [XKI] at paras 12, 18 and 21.

[note: 5]Defendant’s Closing Submissions dated 18 February 2025 in SUM 3461 at para 23.

XJD v XJE and others

XJD v XJE and others
[2025] SGFC 24

Case Number:FC/OSM 310/2023
Decision Date:14 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Shobha Nair
Counsel Name(s): Applicant in Person; Darren Ng Zhen Qiang, Lee Lyi Shyuenn, Marina Chin Li Yuen and Teo Su Ning, Gillian (Tan Kok Quan Partnership) for the 1st Respondent; Muk Chen Yeen Jonathan and Tan Kah Wai with intern Liew Xi Ting (LVM Law Chambers) for the 2nd and 3rd Respondents; Tan Jun Hong (instructed) and Tan Shen Kiat, Litigation Representative (Kith and Kin Law Corporation) for the 4th Respondent.
Parties: XJD — XJE — XJF — XJG — XJH

Mental Capacity Assessments – Functional and clinical components – Declarations – Estoppel

14 March 2025

District Judge Shobha Nair:

Introduction

1       The applicant initially sought a mental capacity assessment of his mother, the 4th Respondent (P), to be conducted by “an independent geriatric neurologist with relevant experience in the care of elderly patients suffering from Alzheimer’s disease to ascertain her capacity to give valid consent as of 5 September 2022”[note: 1], the day before she renounced her rights as executrix of her late husband’s will. The request for such an assessment was also made in a previous set of proceedings in HC/OA 637/2023 (OA 637). The request in OA 637 was primarily refused because P was not made a party to those proceedings. Under the provisions of a will, P’s late husband appointed P and the 1st Respondent who was a close friend, as executrices of his will.

2       After medical evidence was given for the hearing before me, and a week before submissions were due, the applicant sought to amend the originating summons to include a declaration that the renunciation P made on 6 September 2022 is null and void. I permitted it as I was of the view that the amended prayer was rooted in the evidence of the medical experts and the respondents had the opportunity to address this sufficiently.

3       While the core issue in this case was the mental capacity of P at the time she renounced her rights to administer the estate of her late husband, it in effect sought to have this court ignore or review the decision of the court in OA 637, which a Family Court clearly was not in a position to do. Further, any declaration that P had no mental capacity to renounce her rights to administer her late husband’s estate would necessarily mean that P had no capacity to therefore administer the estate. The applicant was of the view that such a result should have no bearing on the need to declare her lack of capacity. The futility of the request however, threw light on his motivations.

4       Having heard from all parties, I dismissed the application against which the applicant appeals.

Facts

5       P is the mother of the applicant (her son) and the 2nd and 3rd respondents (her daughters). P participated in proceedings as the 4th respondent and was represented by a litigation representative, a lawyer in private practice. The 1st respondent is a close friend of the deceased, a friendship dating back to the 1970s. The applicant appeared in person but I was informed that he has a law degree and worked in the UK for some years. He was as a result, well able to root his arguments in established principles of law.

6       P’s husband passed away on 3 August 2022. His will was executed in 2014, and as mentioned, he appointed P and the 1st respondent as executrices and co-trustees. The will was read on or around 22 August 2022 and it was the position of the applicant and the 2nd and 3rd respondents that their mother was too old to engage in the administration of the estate and that consequently, the 1st respondent should take on the role solely. P accordingly renounced her rights on 6 September 2022. Probate was extracted on 23 November 2022.

7       Separately, the applicant commenced an action against the 1st respondent in OA 637[note: 2] to invalidate the appointment of an individual as liquidator of a company his deceased father and the larger family had shares in. He also sought to invalidate a special resolution passed on 16 March 2023 to wind up the company. The premise of the application was that P lacked capacity to sign the letter of appointment and director’s resolution on 2 February 2023 and a proxy form which was signed on 9 May 2023, authorising the 1st respondent to vote on her behalf at an extraordinary general meeting. The applicant also sought that the High Court order an assessment to be conducted to determine P’s mental capacity. The High Court was of the view that the relevant evidence did not support the applicant’s assertion that P lacked mental capacity to sign the documents in question and further, that a medical assessment could not be ordered as P was not party to the proceedings. The medical evidence that was presented in OA 637 was provided by Dr PT who was the only one who had met P and conducted formal assessments of P’s capacity on 16 December 2022, 16 February 2023 and 6 February 2024. The applicant appealed against the decision of the High Court, and these were dismissed recently. One of the positions that was taken by the applicant in the appeal is that another doctor well qualified in geriatric psychiatry, Professor K, had reservations about the assessments of Dr PT and accordingly sought to adduce the report of Professor K. This was dismissed by the Appellate Division of the High Court (AD) referring to the futility of a “desktop review” of P’s mental capacity.[note: 3]

8       The document under scrutiny in the case before me was P’s renunciation of 6 September 2022. The documents that were the subject matter in OA 637 were executed in 2023. The decision of the High Court, affirmed on appeal, accepted Dr PT’s evidence that P had mental capacity to execute the 2023 documents. This meant that the applicant in the case before me was effectively asking for a reconsider the same issue and medical evidence, save that the document in question was executed at a different time. It did not escape the respondents’ attention that this was an earlier document, making the exercise appear to be a second bite of the cherry. The Family Court has no jurisdiction to review the same material to address the same issue before the High Court.

9       I appreciated however that P was not a party to the proceedings in OA 637 which therefore prevented an order for a medical assessment.[note: 4] In the proceedings before me, P was made a party and hence the need for a medical assessment was a prayer this court was presented with to consider. I also appreciated the fact that the document in question is different from that which was before the High Court. In the context of fluctuations in capacity that is common in dementia, further information that the applicant may have wanted to produce to the court and which may throw light on P’s state of mind as at 6 December 2022 was therefore allowed.

Legal Principles

10     When the Mental Capacity Act (Cap 177A, 2010 Rev Ed) (MCA) was first enacted, it was with a view to expressing in legislation, the need to respect the autonomy of individuals to make their own decisions. Family members or caregivers need to refrain from quick assumptions of a complete lack of capacity especially amongst the elderly, every time there are memory lapses or unusual behaviour. S 3(2) provides for the presumption of autonomy rather than a presumption that one lacks it as a result of a particular condition.[note: 5] Insofar as dementia is concerned, paragraph 4.3.2 of the Office of the Public Guardian “Code of Practice: Mental Capacity Act” (September 2023) provides that “mental capacity must be assessed on a case by case basis and cannot be assumed based only on the person suffering from a particular medical condition”. This practical guide is of great significance as it is common for those who care for or know of persons who have neurocognitive disorders to conclude, sometimes too quickly, that the person lacks mental capacity and cannot make any decision for himself.

11     In the event a person loses mental capacity, steps may be taken by a family member to obtain an order to be appointed as a deputy to ensure that the life of that person continues to be well supported by the deputy, always bearing in mind the need to observe the dignity of that person.

12     S 5 of the MCA provides a framework to determine capacity or a lack thereof. An individual must be able to understand information related to the decision that needs to be made, retain the information, use or weigh the information as part of the process of making the decision and communicate the decision. One need not have to communicate in perfect grammar or complex sentences, nor does the retention of the information be for a long period [s 5(2)]. S 19 of the MCA empowers a court of law to declare that a person has or lacks mental capacity. The serious nature of such a declaration was expressed by the court in the seminal case of Re BKR[note: 6]. The test for capacity includes both the functional and clinical components. A court would need to evaluate the evidence with respect to an individual’s ability to decide and her cognitive ability to make a decision. In other words, if a person cannot make a decision (functional component) because of a mental impairment (clinical component which would be contingent on appropriate assessments by medical practitioners preferably in the field of psychiatry), a declaration of a lack of capacity may be made. But not otherwise.

13     It was not disputed in this case that dementia becomes worse over time but that its fluctuating nature allows for some decisions to be made and relied upon, while some others would necessitate greater scrutiny and may be unsafe to endorse. It is time and decision specific.

Did P have functional capacity?

14     P renounced her right to act as executrix of her husband’s will on 6 September 2022. This was done after the applicant, the 2nd and 3rd respondents met with the lawyer who drafted their father’s and learnt that P and the 1st respondent had been appointed executrices and trustees of the deceased’s estate. The 2nd and 3rd respondents claimed that it was at this meeting that they and the applicant agreed that it was impractical for P who was about 81 years of age at the time to take on such an onerous role. The 2nd and 3rd respondents claimed that the applicant did not state that P lacked mental capacity. The applicant however expressed that he had in fact voiced reservations about P’s mental capacity. I am of the view that the position expressed by the 2nd and 3rd respondents was a more accurate reflection of the position of all the siblings for the following reasons:

(a)     The applicant said that on 11 August 2022, he expressed that P did not have the mental capacity to renounce her rights in relation to an application for letters of administration which was taken out in Malaysia to administer the deceased’s Malaysian estate. At that point in time, the will was not retrieved. Even though he claimed that he was of this view in relation to Ps capacity, he signed on documents giving his consent to the application for a grant of letters of administration to be taken out by the 2nd respondent. His evidence was that he did so thinking that the documents he signed would have no legal effect since P had no capacity.[note: 7] I could not accept the explanation. It appears that the applicant while unsure of the capacity of his mother to forgo her rights to a Grant was comfortable enough to endorse documents enabling his sister to proceed with the matter. He revoked the consent only on 28 October 2022 well after the father’s will which dealt with Singapore assets was made known.

(b)     The applicant met with the 1st respondent at a dinner around the same day the will was read and no firm position was expressed in relation to P’s capacity.

(c)     Soon after the will was read, a WhatsApp chat group was set up by the 1st respondent who indicated to the siblings that given P’s frail state, she may not be in a position to perform her duties well. The 2nd respondent was advised to ascertain this and to assist in having P attend before a lawyer to ensure that P was capable of making the decision to renounce. The applicant did not voice any objection on record. He claims that he had conversations about his concerns but if true, the tenor of such conversations and the exact concerns remain unknown.

(d)     The 1st respondent is not a beneficiary of the will and had nothing to gain from taking on this responsibility solely. As an executor and trustee, he owes fiduciary duties to the beneficiaries – the applicant being one of the beneficiaries - and would be accountable to them beyond obtaining probate.

(e)     Between 26 and 30 August 2022, communication between the 1st respondent and the 2nd respondent on arrangements for the renunciation to be signed was made on the chat group to which the applicant was privy and who took no issue. His repeated assertions that he expressed discomfort verbally is not supported by the evidence and even if he did have reservations, he did not act on it before the renunciation was in fact signed. This is likely because he too believed that his mother was expressing her desire not to be involved in the complex task of administering their father’s estate. The renunciation was made before a Notary Public in Penang after it was ascertained by the Notary that P understood what she was signing.

15     The evidence suggests that the first time the applicant raised objections to the renunciation signed by his mother was in an email addressed to the 1st respondent on 30 November 2022. This was after the extraction of probate and soon after the 1st respondent informed the siblings of the proposal for the sale of the deceased’s home (property). This property is one where P and the applicant had stayed in before P moved to Penang in 2019 and which the applicant currently stays with his family. Under the provisions of the will, P, the applicant, the 2nd, 3rd respondents and a child of the applicant stand to benefit from the proceeds of any sale of this property. The applicant made a proposal to his siblings for the property to be leased to him for a period of time and that the estate could collect the rent from him if he failed to leave the property after the proposed period. The 2nd respondent said that she would speak to P about it. The applicant appeared comfortable with the 2nd respondent asking for the views of P, a position that is incongruous with the view that P lacks mental capacity to make decisions for herself.

16     The challenges with respect to the disposal of the property raises the probability that the applicant was rather more concerned about having to move out than his mother’s capacity to renounce her rights as executrix/trustee. In fact, in his very first affidavit he sees the validity of the 1st respondent’s appointment as sole executor to be dependent on P’s capacity to give a valid renunciation.[note: 8] Even if I were to accept the applicant’s position that P had no mental capacity to renounce her right, the result will be that the 1st respondent will act as the sole executor and trustee as P would not be in a position to perform her duties. The 1st respondent in the discharge of his duties, would need to ensure that all the beneficiaries receive their shares and that the property is sold to have this materialise. There is no evidence that the 1st respondent believed that P was cognitively unable to renounce. As stated in the Code of Practice, one cannot equate having a neurodegenerative disease with cognitive inability to make all decisions. Much depends on the state of health at the time in question to make the specific decision in question. Given that the 1st respondent was not in regular contact with P, to suggest that he knew P had no capacity to renounce her rights or that he had an ulterior motive in securing full control of the administration of his late friend’s estate, is unsupported.

P was represented in these proceedings by a litigation representative (LR). The LR, a practising lawyer, has a duty to court to inform on the way instructions were obtained and the responses of P to questions asked. Two interviews were conducted on 5 July 2024. The first was at P’s residence in Penang from 10.15 a.m. to 11.30 a.m. and the second at a beach resort from 4.30 p.m. to 5.15 p.m. The change of location was on account of renovation work at P’s residence. It was the position of the LR that P had at the time of the interviews expressed a clear position that she did not want to have anything to do with the administration of the estate of her late husband as it would involve travelling and activities she was not able to comfortably attend to.[note: 9] This indication was accepted as most of the questions that were posed by the LR were answered correctly. P was able articulate the following: that she has 3 children; the order of their births; where they reside; the date of the interview by pointing to it on a calendar; that she was a widow; that she used to live in Singapore; the address of the Singapore home and that she was being cared for by the 2nd respondent. She knew that her late husband had assets in Singapore and Malaysia – this was informed without any verbal prompts or visual references.[note: 10] She did make a few mistakes which appear insignificant, for example, in identifying the number of grandchildren during the second interview and the gender of all the grandchildren during the first interview. She was however largely consistent with her answers during both interviews. She articulated her responses in Mandarin and appeared relaxed. Given that these interviews were held in July 2024, the cogency of her answers as informed by the LR, supported the position that her renunciation in 2022 was made with cognitive awareness.

The Clinical Component

17     The applicant essentially relied on reports by various health care professionals prior to the mental capacity assessment of P by Dr PT on 6 September 2022 as well as the opinion of Professor K on the manner of Dr PT’s assessment, to advance the argument that his mother could not have had the capacity to renounce her rights.

18     It was the applicant’s position that the 2nd Respondent knew that P was on follow up reviews with a doctor at a hospital in Singapore and that she chose not to reveal this. It was also his position that their late father had informed the 2nd respondent to consult doctors in Penang on the cognitive changes he observed of P while he was alive. The 1st respondent confirmed that this was true.

19     The applicant referred to Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans done by a radiologist on 23 October 2019 where large lesions, moderate cortical atrophy, severe volume loss of hippocampus, substantial parietal atrophy and bilateral periventricular white matter lesions were observed. On 30 October 2019 a doctor at a hospital in Penang conducted the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) in which P scored 27/30. The MoCA is a screening tool that evaluates cognitive function. On 11 September 2021, a geriatrician and physician in Penang diagnosed P with Alzheimer’s vascular dementia. Psychosis and mood symptoms of dementia were observed and medication given to regulate these. The MoCA reading was 17/30. On 24 December 2021, an occupational therapist had documented a score of 15/30.

20     The applicant submitted that the biological markers and the images of the brain scan especially of the hippocampus which regulates memory and cognition, proves that P was not functioning normally. This was not disputed by Dr PT who is the only doctor who assessed P’s mental capacity. He shared by drawing an analogy to a famous politician in Malaysia whom he had treated, that one could look normal but the brain scans show that functioning is impaired. The applicant then cited medical literature to show the impact of severe loss of volume of the hippocampus. This and Professor K’s opinion that severe loss of volume in the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe atrophy suggests that dementia in P was no longer mild, were accepted. What I do not accept are as follows:

(a)      All the medical documentation prior to Dr PT’s mental assessment of P were produced in OA 637 and the Court in dismissing the suggestion that P had no capacity to sign on the documents which were the subject matter of that hearing, said “However none of the above reports…demonstrated the impact of the mother’s dementia on her decision making or cognitive abilities”.[note: 11] The applicant did in essence, what he was cautioned not to do and that is, to attempt to relitigate the matter with the same material presented to the High Court. The applicant submitted that the answers Dr PT gave under cross-examination in the matter before me reveals inadequacies and inefficiencies which justify a declaration that P did not have the required capacity to issue a renunciation.

(b)     Dr PT is a consultant neuropsychiatrist and Head of Neurobehavioral Medicine at a hospital in Penang. Any suggestion by the applicant that he is not qualified has no basis.[note: 12] He has many years of experience and is by no means a doctor who was callous in his assessment. The only person that performed a mental capacity assessment is Dr PT. This was conducted on 16 December 2022, which is approximately 3 months after P had renounced her right to be an executrix of her late husband’s will. The fact that this assessment was to determine testamentary capacity does not detract from the fact that capacity was established. The ability to execute a will is by no means simple and requires sound executive functioning.

(c)     The applicant expressed scepticism of the impressive scores that P received on the MoCA (26/30) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) in which she scored 28/30. Professor K stated and in fact Dr PT accepted, that the leap of 9 to 10 points between 2021 and 2022 is impossible from a medical standpoint. Again, there was no dispute. The result in 2022 mirrored somewhat the 2019 reading of 27/30. While the applicant spent considerable time dissecting this, I did not believe that the assessment of Dr PT hinged on the scores. With respect to the low scores on the MMSE and MoCA in 2021, Dr PT spoke of how patients suffering from dementia may not cooperate and malinger, especially in the context of depression.[note: 13] Professor K also stated that he recognised that decisions are time and issue specific and that clinical assessments are important, not simply mental state scores. The only one who met with P for purposes of assessment was Dr PT. In hearing him, he appeared to be confident of his interactions with his patient and his assessment of capacity arising from that interaction. While I agree with Professor K that the act of indicating whether one wants to renounce one’s rights to administer an estate is not a “yes” or “no” answer, I do not believe that P was being pressed to give such an answer without understanding, retaining, weighing and communicating her decision to renounce. In fact, her high MoCA scores in 2019 of 27/30 came after the brain scans which show severe loss of volume in the hippocampus and which the applicant argues would prevent cognitive ability. If one were to accept the applicant’s position on brain atrophy, the MoCA readings would have produced a much lower number even in 2019. It did not, lending to the argument that the interaction between physician and patient in this case would be key.

(d)     Would Dr PT have benefitted from knowing of previous MoCA scores and medical reports? The answer must certainly be in the affirmative. It may have driven him to do further investigations. To suggest however that the diagnosis that was made was wrong would not, without more, be a fair conclusion. The applicant insisted that Dr PT’s lack of knowledge of previous medical reports and tests should bring into question the assessment that he made. Again, I do not believe this in and of itself disqualifies reliance. It can certainly be equally argued that if a doctor is informed of previous reports, he may take the convenient route of quickly aligning with those views. Clearly it would be dangerous to take either position. I had no reason to doubt the evidence of Dr PT who assessed P. Some key aspects of communication need to be noted. She was asked to write a sentence with a noun and a verb and she wrote very clearly that she wanted to divide her property into 3 equal parts for her children.[note: 14] Dr PT gave in evidence that P wrote the sentence without any cue[note: 15] dismissing the suggestion that P lacked clarity in expressing her position. Further, the assessment of Dr PT was aligned with the views of the LR who interviewed P in 2024.

(e)     The MoCA and MMSE are simplistic tools and the scores meant to direct further investigations. Even if the test scores produced by Dr PT were discounted, I would have to accept that the earlier lower scores were accurate. This would be difficult to do in light of the fact as mentioned above, 2019 MoCA scores were high even though brain scans conducted prior to the MoCA being administered would suggest that the high 2019 score was implausible. Yet, it exists. Professor K’s position that the scans and medical reports show that P was suffering from moderate to severe dementia which would prevent a decision to be made on renunciation is difficult to accept. It is not clear exactly where P’s dementia was on the spectrum and the impact of any decision on renunciation. It bears repeating that Professor K did not have the benefit of assessing P. The interaction between Dr PT and P, the articulation of the interaction he had with P when he gave his evidence and the LR’s expression of P’s position in relation to estate matters of her late husband shows cogency sufficient to keep the renunciation in place.

(f)     Professor K confirmed that he would not be able to conclude on P’s capacity as at 5 or 6 September 2022. In fact, he was not aware that when the MoCA test were conducted prior to P’s first appointment with Dr PT in 2022, she was suffering from depression which he acknowledged may have had an impact on the 2021 scores. When P saw the doctors in Penang on 2019 and in 2021, she scored 8/15 and 7/15 on the Geriatric Depressive Scale (GDS), respectively. The applicant minimised the potential effect of depression by submitting that it could not have played a very significant role given that the 2019 MoCA score of 27/30 was better with a higher depression score than the 2021 MoCA of 17/30 when she was less depressed.[note: 16] It bears repeating that this is the same concern with respect to the incongruence between the brain scans in 2019 and the high MoCA score in 2019. It would need some conjecture to rationalise these various pieces of evidence. What is clear from Professor K’s own evidence however is that how cooperative a patient is and his or her state of physical and mental health are factors to consider when rationalising the scores. While Professor K’s explanations were clear and his views rooted in vast knowledge and experience, he did not have the benefit of assessment, and he did not have the benefit of interaction with P on 6 September 2022. It would be unsafe from a legal standpoint to allow for theoretical assessments in an area which calls for personal and practical ones.

Is there a need for further medical assessment?

21     The prayer of the applicant for a medical assessment to be conducted by a geriatric neurologist to ascertain the capacity of P insofar as it sheds light on her capacity in September 2022 is an exercise in futility.

22     In proceedings of this nature, there are often requests for repeated assessments to be conducted until the answer that a party seeks is obtained. While clearly there is a need to test the methods and conclusions obtained or presented by medical practitioners, there are also some limits that need to be observed. One is when there is absolutely no value is proceeding with further assessments which put individuals with neurocognitive diseases through further discomfort.

23     The regime in this area is to protect those who have lost autonomy, and not to subject them to further tests for purposes of litigation which brings no value to him. It is also important to ensure that in seeking the truth, that medical professionals are not unfairly subjected to criticism as was seen in the applicant’s unnecessary reference to Dr PT as a “dangerous man”.[note: 17]

24     Even if a medical assessment today is conducted today and it reveals that P does not have mental capacity, it will not assist this court on whether she had capacity in September 2022 to renounce her right to administer her late husband’s estate. Professor K acknowledges this.

Conclusion

25     The applicant sought to reopen similar issues that were before the High Court in OA 637. While the applicant certainly has a right to be fully heard if indeed there was evidence obtained to cast fair doubt with regards the work of Dr PT in relation to his September 2022 assessment, I was of the view that what was presented failed to show a lack of professionalism and competency on the part of Dr PT in coming to the conclusion that P had mental capacity as at 16 December 2022.

26     While I had no doubt that Professor K was assisting the court and that his views and opinions are valid theoretically, the nature of the MoCA and MMSE as simple screening tools, the incongruity of the brain scan results and the results of the 2019 MoCA, the lack of knowledge of the circumstances that P faced during each of these tests (including the fact that she presented with depression in 2021) and the fact that Professor K did not assess P, collectively lend towards the point the AD had made in the appeal against the decision in OA 637 - that is, there is little relevance in having doctors comment on the work of other doctors without the opportunity of meeting, understanding and assessing the patient – the very cornerstone of medical practice.

27     The LR’s evidence that P was able to make a decision as it related to renunciation, is material. In OA 637, P was not a party to proceedings. For the matter before me, she was a participant and had the opportunity to inform the LR in clear terms, her lack of desire to administer the estate of her late husband.

28     The need for further medical assessment is clearly an unproductive exercise. To declare that P lacked capacity in renouncing her right to be an executrix and trustee is to ignore the net effect of such a position. It would be to leave the estate matters in the hands of the 1st respondent, the very position which came about as a result of the renunciation. More importantly, it will not assist in any understanding of her mental state on 6 September 2022.

29     The applicant appears to have concerns about moving out of the property he resides in and with the role of the 1st respondent as executor and trustee. Any legitimate concern can be addressed through a proper application in a probate court. The application in this court is misplaced.
