Costs

50     I heard parties on costs subsequent to the delivery of my brief grounds. The Wife asked for costs on an indemnity basis at $20,000, on the basis that a without prejudice offer had been made to the Husband on 4 December 2023, after mediation and exchange of financial documents, which was less favourable in terms of the division percentage than what had been granted by this court. Counsel for the Wife argued that the matter had been protracted unnecessarily by the Husband, with the hearing of these ancillary proceedings spanning three sessions, and a total of 19 affidavits filed by both parties in the course of these proceedings.

51     Counsel for the Husband strenuously objected to any costs being ordered, and contended that parties could not agree because key items were outstanding and disputed, including the valuation of the matrimonial home. He also noted that additional affidavits from the domestic helper were filed at the last minute.

52     I considered parties’ submissions and noted that while the usual costs order in ancillary proceedings is for parties to bear their own costs, costs may nevertheless be ordered against a party who had been unreasonable and had caused delays and further costs to be incurred (WRX v WRY [2024] SGHC(A) 22, at [75]). In the present case, I took the view that the order of costs should be set at a level that would sufficiently instil discipline in proceedings and avoid unnecessary litigation. This case could have been resolved as far back as December 2023, when a more favourable without prejudice offer had been made to the Husband. Instead, the Husband chose to dispute individual line items and payments to a minutiae of detail, which added unnecessarily to the complexity and duration of these ancillary proceedings. It also bears noting that the Wife prevailed on a significantly greater number of contested issues in these proceedings than the Husband. For these reasons, I ordered the Husband to pay costs to the Wife, fixed at $10,000 (all-in).

Conclusion

53     The ancillary orders are granted as follows:

Division of matrimonial assets

1.    By Consent, paragraphs (a)-(d) are ordered as follows:

a.    In relation to the payout from PruEduSave Policy No. XXXX6162, the Husband shall pay the sum of S$15,831.50 to the designated bank account of PTK upon the commencement of her overseas education in Australia. The Husband shall pay the outstanding sum of $831.50 to PTK within 1 week from the date of this Order.

b.    Upon maturity of AIA Smart Growth 18 Policy No. LXXXXX4480, the Wife shall transfer all monies received from the said policy to PTK’s designated bank account. The Wife shall provide evidence of monies received and amounts transferred to PTK.

c.    Parties agree that proceeds from insurance policies PruEduSave Policy No. XXXX6162 and AIA Smart Growth 18 Policy No. LXXXXX4480 will be paid to PTK and utilised towards her outstanding student loan incurred (S$34,500) in 10 September 2024. The total payout from the Husband’s PruEdusave Policy No. XXXX6162 and the Wife’s AIA Smart Growth 18 Policy No. LXXXXX4480 ($21,745 as of present) will approximate the outstanding student loan.

d.    The Husband shall pay to the Wife the sum of S$1,000, representing the cash benefit received by him from the Wife’s Prudential Insurance Policy No. XXXX6964 within 2 weeks from the date of this Order.

2.    In relation to the payouts from AIA Insurance Policy Nos. LXXXXX0975 and AIA LXXXXX0991, the sum of S$11,810.17 shall be paid by the Husband to KS forthwith. If the Husband can show proof that these specific payments have already been made, he is at liberty to apply to resolve this. For the avoidance of doubt, no finding is made that payment has been made by the Husband.

3.    The Parties’ matrimonial assets shall be divided in the proportion of 57.25% (Wife) and 42.75% (Husband).

4.    The abovementioned division shall be implemented as follows:

a.    The matrimonial flat at [address redacted] (the “Matrimonial Flat") shall be sold on the open market within 6 months of the date of this Order. The sale proceeds shall be applied as follows:

(1)    To make full payment of the outstanding housing loan.

(2)    To pay all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the Matrimonial Flat.

(3)    The net sale proceeds shall be divided in the following manner: 57.25% to the Plaintiff and 42.75% to the Defendant.

(4)    Each party shall be responsible to refund their respective CPF contributions and accrued interest to their respective CPF accounts from their share of the net sale proceeds, in accordance with the CPF legislation and requirements. In the event of any shortfall, the refund shall be considered a partial refund.

(5)    The sum of S$55,964.55 shall be deducted from the Husband’s share of the net sale proceeds on completion and paid to the Wife.

(6)    Parties shall have joint conduct of sale of the Matrimonial Flat.

(7)    Pending completion of sale of the Matrimonial Flat, parties shall pay, in equal shares, all outgoings related to the Matrimonial Flat, including but not limited to the housing loan, utilities, broadband services, management and sinking fund charges and property tax. Neither party shall terminate services to the Matrimonial Flat under their respective names.

5.    The Motor Vehicle bearing motor registration No. SLE XXXX (the "Motor Vehicle") shall be sold on the open market within 2 months of the date of this Order. The sale proceeds shall be applied as follows:

a.    To make full payment of the outstanding loan to the financial institution.

b.    To pay all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the Motor Vehicle.

c.    The net sale proceeds shall be divided in the following manner: 57.25% to the Wife and 42.75% to the Husband

d.    The Wife shall have sole conduct of the sale of the Motor Vehicle and the Husband shall hand over the Motor Vehicle and car keys in working condition, in his possession to the Wife within 2 weeks of this Order. Should the Husband elect to transfer ownership of the Motor Vehicle to his sole name, he shall notify the Wife within 1 week of this Order, pay her S$14,704.09 and solely discharge the outstanding hire purchase loan within 2 weeks of this Order. Failing which, the Husband shall hand over the Motor Vehicle and car keys to the Wife as stated herein.

e.    Pending sale of the Motor Vehicle or transfer of the Motor Vehicle to Husband’s name, Husband to continue to pay for hire purchase instalment and all costs related to Motor Vehicle.

6.    The OCBC Savings Account XXX-XXX397-001 (“the Joint Bank Account”) shall be closed within 7 days from the day of this Order with the balance to be split 57.25% to the Wife and 42.74 to the Husband.

7.    The Wife shall be entitled to S$150,000 of the Husband’s CPF monies pursuant to section 112 of the Women’s Charter (the “Ordered Amount”).

8.    The CPF Board shall transfer, from the monies standing to the credit of the Husband in the following CPF account(s) of Husband, the amount(s) specified as follows to the Wife’s CPF Account:

Husband’s CPF account(s) to transfer from

Amount to Transfer

Ordinary Account

$150,000



9.    This Order is made subject to the Central Provident Fund Act (“CPF Act”) and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder made in respect of Husband’s CPF monies, property and investments. The CPF Board shall give effect to the terms of this Order, in accordance with the provisions of the CPF Act and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder.

10.    Unless expressly provided for in the CPF Act, nothing in the Orders herein shall be taken to affect the Board’s charge on the matrimonial home or any other immovable property owned by one or both of the parties and which is the subject of this Order of Court. The Board shall determine the requisite refunds to be made to the respective parties’ CPF accounts upon the sale, transfer, assignment or otherwise disposal of such immovable property in accordance with the CPF Act and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder.

11.    The shortfall, if any, between the Ordered Amount and the payment received by the Wife from the Board or transferred to the Wife’s CPF account is a debt due from the Husband to the Wife and is recoverable as such.

The Wife shall retain the Rainbow Vacuum Cleaner, Thermostar Avantgarder Steam Cleaner and the Elken Water Purifier, purchased by her.

12.    Each party shall retain all other assets in their sole names.

13.    The Registrar / Assistant Registrar of the Family Justice Courts under s 31 of the Family Justice Act 2014 is empowered to execute, sign, or endorse all necessary documents relating to matters contained in this Order should either party fail to do so within seven days of written request being made to the party.

14.    The Parties, including the Board, shall be at liberty to apply for further directions or Orders generally.

Maintenance

Wife

15.    There be no maintenance for the Wife.

Children (PTK)

16.    The Husband shall pay the Wife outstanding maintenance payment for PTK for the period April 2023 to December 2024 amounting to S$20,816.22. Payment to the Wife’s designated bank account forthwith.

17.    PTK’s living expenses for her overseas education in Australia are fixed at A$2,049 and accommodation costs currently at A$1,556 for every four (4) weeks, subject to adjustment if revised (collectively “the said overseas expenses”). The Husband shall pay his share of the said overseas expenses directly to PTK’s designated bank account as follows on the 12th day of each month:

a.     From January 2025 to December 2026: 55% of the said overseas expenses monthly, or when the course concludes, whichever is earlier.

b.     From January 2027 onwards (should the course not be concluded):50% of the said overseas expenses monthly.

18.    In addition, the Husband shall pay his share of PTK’s major and ad hoc expenses for the entire duration of her tertiary education, including but not limited to school fees, clothing in excess of A$100, school-related expenses in excess of A$100, airfare (returning back to Singapore and to Australia), furniture, furnishings, one-off purchases such as a laptop, mobile phone, costs of opening bank account in Australia, medical, and dental expenses. Payment shall be made directly to PTK’s designated bank account as follows:

a.     From January 2025 to December 2026 (or when the course concludes, whichever is earlier): 55% of such expenses within seven (7) days of the Wife providing supporting documents or invoices.

b.     From January 2027 onwards (should the course not be concluded): 50% of such expenses within seven (7) days of the Wife providing supporting documents or invoices.

19.    For the avoidance of doubt, parties shall continue to pay for PTK’s maintenance when she is back to Singapore for holidays and pay in the proportion as ordered for her monthly mobile phone subscription, medical and dental expenses in Singapore.

Costs

20.    The Defendant is to pay the Plaintiff costs fixed at $10,000 (all-in).

html:
VEV v VEW

VEV v VEW
[2025] SGFC 26

Case Number:Divorce No 3162 of 2018, Summons No 3216 of 2024 & 3397 of 2024
Decision Date:12 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Jen Koh
Counsel Name(s): Plaintiff/Husband (In Person).Defendant/Wife (In Person).
Parties: VEV — VEW

Co-parenting issues; Sharing of time with children, Make-up access

12 March 2025

District Judge Jen Koh:

Introduction

1       The Plaintiff shall be referred to as the “father” and the Defendant shall be referred to as the “mother”.

2       The mother filed an appeal against orders made on 4 December 2024 with regard to 3 prayers of 2 different summonses:

(i)     She appeals the dismissal of her prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024. In this prayer, the mother sought a one-off school holiday with the children at her sole election during 2025 in lieu of her entitlement to the children for a one-off school holiday on 4 October 2024.

(ii)     She appeals the orders made in favour of the father in prayers 6 and 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024. Prayer 6 of the father’s summons deals with the same subject matter as the mother’s prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024. The father sought an order that in consideration of the mother having the children for a school holiday on 4 October 2024 and in accordance with the parties' agreement of 1 October 2024, the father would be entitled to an additional single-day school holiday at a time of his choosing (including in 2025) on giving reasonable notice to the wife. I granted an order in terms of the father’s prayer, leading to a dismissal of the mother’s prayer 6 in FC/SUM 3216/2024.

(iii)     In prayer 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024, the father sought make up access in consideration of the fact that the children were with the mother on 31 August and 1 September 2024. He sought make up access on an additional public holiday at a time of his choosing and an additional Sunday at a time of his choosing on giving (including in 2025) reasonable notice to the mother. I granted an order in terms of this prayer.

Brief background

3       The parties were married on xx July 2011, and they have 2 children, a daughter who will be turning 10 years old in 2025 and a son who will turn 8 years old this year (‘the children’).

4       The father is about 52 and is a Barrister/Mediator/Arbitrator. The mother is about 42 years of age, and she also has a law degree as well as a master’s in law. She is currently a teacher in an international school. The parties are citizens of the United Kingdom (“UK”) with the father holding dual citizenship with Australia and the mother holding dual citizenship in Ireland.

5       The parties relocated to Singapore in February 2012, some 6 months after their marriage. The parties have lived in Singapore since February 2012. The parties are permanent residents of Singapore. Both children are attending local schools.

6       The husband filed a writ for divorce in July 2018. Interim judgment was granted on 5 March 2019. The contested ancillary matters (AM) were heard on 16 and 19 September 2019. I reserved decision and delivered the AM orders on 8 October 2019 with clarifications on 9 and 14 October 2019. Final judgement was extracted on 23 December 2019.

7       The father appealed the AM orders in their entirety and the appeal was heard before the High Court Family Division. The High Court also dealt with related summonses in HCF/DCA 127/2019, HCF/SUM 289/2019, HCF/SUM 324/2019, HCF/SUM 55/2020, HCF/RAS 10/2020, HCF/SUM 163/2020, HCF/SUM 244/2020, HCF/RAS 27/2020, HCF/SUM 340/2020.

8       The High Court made orders on 11 March 2021. In rendering his decision, the learned Judicial Commissioner Tan Puay Boon (as he then was) made the following remarks which I set out:

“141  Before concluding, I add the following remarks. Once the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance in the divorce issues are resolved, the parties should give serious consideration to becoming more accommodating towards each other in dealing with the matters concerning the Children, rather than continuously utilising their forensic skills to seek resolution in court all the time. This is especially so when the matters in dispute are administrative and not legal in nature. Moreover, as the Children grow up day by day, and enter different stages of their lives, such as beginning formal education, adjustments would necessarily have to be made to the current orders. Handling such adjustments in a more amicable way cannot be but in the best interests of the Children.

142    When last counted, there were 26 summonses filed in D 3162, the divorce suit. There were four appeals to the High Court Family Division from decisions in the Family Court, in which a total of four summonses have been filed. There was also an originating summons filed in the Family Court concerning the permanent relocation of the Children, and an originating summons filed in the Court of Appeal for leave to appeal the decision in RAS 10. All these were filed since July 2018, less than three years ago. The Children were aged three and one then, and are now six and four years old, respectively. They will reach majority at 18 in 12 to 14 years. It is a very heavy burden for parties to bear if they continue to choose to resolve disputes for the remaining of those years in the manner and at the rate they have chosen so far. I accept that the Children are still very young and may not now understand the conflicts taking place between the parties. But they will grow up and soon discover what is taking place between their parents. The conflicts will affect them, and it is not fair to them to be made to bear the same heavy burden as well.”

9       Notwithstanding this advice, after the conclusion of the appeal in March 2021, the parties filed 41 applications and 505 affidavits between April 2021 and December 2024.

10     The children were aged 3 and 1 when the divorce proceedings started. They are now turning 10 and 8 respectively. The marriage was contracted in July 2011 and ended in Interim Judgment in March 2019 subsisting some 8 years. But at the rate of the litigation parties decide to embroil in, the years they spend in litigation will soon outstrip the length of the marriage in no time. Indeed, these children have spent much of their childhood thus far with parents mired in litigation.

11     This latest appeal by the mother is a case in point. I have set out the crux of the appeal which is the mother’s dissatisfaction over what she perceived as her entitled time with the children over 3 dates: 4 October 2024, 31 August 2024 and 1 September 2024.

12     Before setting out the reasons for my decision, I also refer parties to DDN v DDO [2024] SGHC(A) 2 in which the Appellate Division (the AD) gave guidance to parties that parents should, in considering their children’s changing needs, exercise grace and flexibility in co-parenting and make arrangements in the best interests of their children: [18]. The AD also referred to VVB v VVA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 (at [24]): Instead of litigating in the courts for the variation of orders, parents should endeavour to make adjustments by agreement to the care and access orders where necessary.

13     It is unfortunate that 7 years after their divorce was granted, these parties continue to be locked in acrimonious litigation over issues pertaining to the children.

Dismissal of Prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024

Order in terms of prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3397/2024

4 October 2024

14     The issue pertained to with whom the children were to be with on 4 October 2024.

15     The mother sought an order that she should be entitled to make up access on 4 October 2024 whilst the father sought an order giving effect to an express agreement between the parties with regard to an equal split of school holiday for the period 30 August to 7 September 2024. Resulting from this agreement, the children were to be with the mother on 4 October 2024.

16     As set out, according to the mother, the parties agreed to a split of the children’s school holiday for the period 30 August to 7 September 2024. On 26 August 2024, the mother said that she spotted an alleged erroneous calculation of that school holiday period but as parties had made their respective plans with the children for their share of that period, she proceeded with the agreement. However, because of the erroneous split, she said that the alternating entitlements of the parties shifted with the result that the school holiday after the term break fell to the father and the next one (4 October 2024) to the mother.

17     The make-up time with the children she sought therefore pertained to what the mother said stemmed from the erroneous calculation of that school holiday period. As a result of this alleged erroneous calculation by the father, the mother took the view that she had been disadvantaged. She offered to keep the arrangements the parties had agreed to but sought another 1.5 days with the children.

18     The husband’s position was straightforward. There was no reason to grant the order sought by the wife as the children were in fact with her on that day. This was pursuant to an express written agreement detailing how the parties were to share the time with the children. The husband said that the agreement was set out in an exchange of emails on 1 October 2024 exhibited in the husband’s affidavit filed on 25 October 2024 at pages 32 to 33.

19     My decision was likewise straightforward – it was predicated on the parties’ written agreement. Notwithstanding calculations and division of days, parties are always at liberty to agree between themselves on the sharing of time with the children. I refer to paragraph 11 above. In line with co-parenting and considering the children’s needs and welfare, the parties reached an agreement. The agreement was not disputed. The mother herself said she would comply with the agreement as arrangements had been made for the children. She proceeded with her share of that school holiday period in accordance with the agreement. The time sharing of the children for that school holiday period was spent.

20     Having reached such an agreement and acting in accordance with the agreement, the mother then raised an issue with an alleged erroneous calculation. She sought to impose “penalties” on the father by claiming an extra 1.5 days with the children. When she filed the summons, it became a replacement of one day.

21     Although she did have the children with her on 4 October 2024, the mother sought a replacement one day “in lieu of her entitlement to the children for a one-off school holiday on 4 October 2024”.

22     From what I can surmise, the mother’s disgruntlement stemmed from the definition of school holidays and the application to that particular school holiday period. For completeness, this definition (of school holidays) was dealt with by the High Court in its decision of 11 March 2021 in which the Court defined school holidays for the parties as follows:

“[83] The Husband has asked that school holidays be defined, and the Wife has agreed to the draft definition in the AC. This draft was revised by the Husband in the Appellant's Speaking Notes ... to cover multi-day school holidays. I substitute para 16 of [the AM Orders] with the following, based on the revised draft:

School holidays are to be equally shared between the parties. A school holiday shall, for the purposes of these Orders, be a non-teaching day as stated in the children’s school calendar (“the calendar”). In the case of a multi-day school holiday, the school holiday commences on the first non-teaching day of the holiday break as stated in the calendar and shall continue until the day before the first teaching day as stated in the calendar. In all cases, a school holiday shall run from 5:30pm on the eve of the day until 7:30pm on the day itself. ..."

23     However, the point to be noted is not the definition of school holidays or whether there was an erroneous calculation but that parties had an agreement. They both acted on the said agreement; the school holiday period in question had lapsed and the mother had the children with her on 4 October 2024 in reliance on that agreement. Indeed, in the spirit of co-parenting, the parties have been enjoined repeatedly to agree on time sharing with their children as they are best placed to determine this. Having done so, the mother should not press on to claim a disadvantage of a loss of one day with the children with whom she has care and control.

24     The mother is also not a naïve litigant in person. She is legally trained and has fired many salvos herself in the litigation arena with applications for time sharing, clarification of time sharing and the filing of many affidavits. Having agreed with the father on the holiday period in question, she should not now be permitted to backtrack and claim an additional day. There was no basis for this Court to grant the relief sought in prayer 6 of the mother's Summons and this prayer was accordingly dismissed.

Order in terms of prayer 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024 – make up access to the father

31 August and 1 September 2024

25     The children had a mid-term break in the week of 2 to 6 September 2024. On Friday 30 August, the children did not have to attend school because it was Children's Day. 31 August was a Saturday, and this was the father’s time with the children pursuant to the AM Orders. 1 September was a Sunday and Father’s Day and meant for the father to spend time with the children.

26     The parties had agreed that 30 August 2024 was a single-day school holiday and that this day was meant for the father. Father’s Day was also meant for the father. This then led to the multi-day school holiday in the week of 2 to 6 September which would include the weekend of 7 and 8 September. The parties agreed to the calculation of 7 days (2 to 8 September 2024) and the mother agreed to take the first half as this was again, an equal split. This was set out in emails in pages 35 to 36 of the father’s affidavit filed on 25 October 2024.

27     However, 3 days before handover to the father, the mother claimed that Children’s Day on 30 August 2024 also formed part of the multi-day school holiday starting on 2 September 2024. This led to emails being sent as referred to in pages 23 to 32 of the mother’s affidavit of 8 October 2024. The mother was only prepared to let the father have the children from Tuesday 3 September 2024. This was notwithstanding that parties had reached an agreement on time sharing as set out in paragraph 26 above.

28     Because of the mother’s change in position, again departing from an agreement at the 11th hour, the father did not see the children on 30 August 2024 (his entitlement pursuant to the definition of a single-day school holiday), Saturday which was part of his weekend access order pursuant to the AM orders and more pertinently, on Father’s Day.

29     The parties had agreed to the arrangement with the school holidays to be divided between them from 2 to 8 September 2024. Because the mother resiled on the agreement and retained the children with her depriving the father of his single-day school holiday, his Saturday access and Father’s Day, the father was therefore entitled to the make-up access.

30     The parties subsequently agreed to a replacement and swapped single-day school holiday which resolved the issue of replacement time for the father on 30 August 2024. The father was therefore entitled to the make-up access for his loss of access on 31 August 2024 and 1 September 2024 and I so ordered.

Concluding remarks

31     Whilst the High Court had defined single-day school holidays and multi-school holidays (see paragraph 11 above), the parties have managed to agree and rework time sharing of their children considering the children’s needs and welfare as well as the parties’ own schedules. It is important for the parties to agree and resolve this time sharing of their children without the Court’s intervention; they are, after all, the children’s parents. It is also not right to agree on an arrangement and then throw it out on the 11th hour then insisting on “rights” and “claims”.

32     The parties would do well to move away from their perceived entitled positions and think in terms of what would work best for the children with the least movement for handovers. At the crux of this matter, the issues are not legal issues. These are parenting matters, and it is unfortunate that their inability to co-parent spawned an appeal for 3 dates of access/make-up time.

33     I have said before that these parties would benefit from the assistance of a parenting coordinator or a mediator as they are wasting precious time in drafting affidavits and filing applications ironically about time sharing with the children; time which would have been better spent with their children. I hope for the children’s sake that the parties would heed the advice of the Court as set out in paragraph 8.

html:
WZH v WZI

WZH v WZI
[2025] SGFC 15

Case Number:Divorce Suit No. 5338 of 2022
Decision Date:20 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kevin Ho
Counsel Name(s): Mr Alain Abraham Johns and Ms Emira Binte Abdul Razakjr (Alain A Johns Partnership) for the Plaintiff; Mr Muhammad Hasif Bin Abdul Aziz (A.W. Law LLC) for the Defendant.
Parties: WZH — WZI

Family law – Ancillary powers of court – Division of matrimonial assets

Family law – Custody – Access to Children

Family law – Child – Maintenance of Child

20 February 2025

District Judge Kevin Ho:

Introduction

1       These grounds of decision relate to the ancillary reliefs sought by the parties consequent on their divorce in FC/D 5338/2022.

2       The present case involved a marriage of approximately 5 years. The Plaintiff-Husband (“Husband”) and the Defendant-Wife (“Wife”) registered their marriage on 25 September 2018 and, although the parties were blessed with two children in their time together, the Husband filed for divorce on 17 November 2022 (shortly after the Wife’s departure from their matrimonial home a month earlier).[note: 1]

3       Interim judgment for divorce (“IJ”) was eventually granted on 13 December 2023. Thereafter, the parties spent the following year preparing for the eventual ancillary matters (“AM”) hearing which came before me in November 2024.

4       At the AM hearing, both parties’ counsel confirmed the following to the Court:

(a)     The parties have since agreed that both parents should share joint custody of the children of the marriage, [K] (5 years old) and [R] (3 years old) (collectively referred to as, the “Children”), with the Wife having sole care and control.

(b)     The Wife was not seeking any maintenance post-divorce.

(c)     The remaining AM issues (ie. the division of matrimonial assets pursuant to s 112(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“WC”), the maintenance payable for the Children, as well as the Husband’s access arrangements) were disputed. However, counsel acknowledged that the parties’ disagreement on the issue of access were not significant.

5       After hearing parties, I provided my brief grounds of decision to the parties via a Registrar’s Notice sent pursuant to r. 670(2) of the Family Justice Rules 2014.

6       I now set out below my full grounds of decision on the contested AM issues below, starting with the issue of the Children’s access arrangement (given the parties’ broad agreement on the matter).

Access to the Children of the Marriage

7       As stated above, both parties agreed that the Wife should be granted care and control of the Children. Accordingly, it was also not disputed that the Husband should be allowed access to the Children. The question, however, was what the terms of the access order.

8       What was somewhat unusual in the present case was the Wife’s request for the Court to make orders which were, in some situations, more generous than what the Husband had asked for. The Court was therefore asked to decide whether it was reasonable for the Husband to be given less access than what was being offered by the Wife. Let me explain.

9       The Wife asked this Court to order that the Husband be given weekly unsupervised overnight access from Sunday to Monday. In addition, she also asked that the Husband be given access to the Children during every public holiday, and that the Husband take overnight access on the 1st day of Chinese New Year (“CNY”) public holiday to the 2nd day.

10     However, it was the Husband’s position, in his written submissions, that he only wanted access every Sunday (with no overnight stay), and that he be given overnight access once a month from Saturday morning to Sunday evening. He also only sought access on alternate public holidays, and from the CNY eve to CNY Day 1 during the CNY festive period.

11     That said, during the AM hearing, the Husband’s counsel confirmed that the Husband was prepared to accept what the Wife had proposed with regard to public holiday and CNY access. As such, I made the relevant orders accordingly.

12     What remained disputed were the weekly unsupervised access arrangements, and various additional orders relating to inter alia overseas access and the Children’s place of residence (the latter of which I shall come to, below).

13     At the outset, I wish to point out that if the Wife’s proposals were indeed borne out of her hope that the Husband spends more time with the Children – as she had claimed in her submissions – this was indicative of a positive mindset towards effective co-parenting and should be encouraged.

14     The importance of such an approach and mindset, which in some cases means helping the other parent to be stronger, was highlighted by the High Court (Family Division) in VXM v VXN [2021] SGHCF 42 (at [53]):

“[i]f it is in the welfare of the children to require parents to be cooperative with the other parent, to extend grace, and even to help the other parent to be a stronger parent if needed, then these needs of the children prevail over the personal needs of the individual parents.”

15     Nevertheless, the Court would be alive to the fact that while an access parent should be given ample opportunity to build a stronger bond with his or her children, the orders themselves must cater to the children’s readiness and to the access parent’s ability to meet the terms of the orders.

16     After all, orders requiring an access parent to be available or present during specific timeframes and/or extended periods themselves impose a positive obligation on that parent to meet and follow the terms of such orders. Such orders – if overly extensive – may sometimes create discord between the parties, or even disappointment on the part of the children, if the access parent refuses or is otherwise unable to comply with the same.

17     It is therefore important for the Court to undertake a holistic assessment as to what orders would ultimately be in the Children’s “welfare” and best interests: see s 125(2), WC. This involves a multi-faceted and multi-factorial analysis, and which should be understood in its widest sense (see IW v IX [2006] 1 SLR 135). In my view, such an analysis may sometimes include inter alia the access parent’s personal wishes and his or her ability to meet the terms of any orders made.

18     Having considered the matter, I decided not to make all the orders sought by the Wife, as I do not find them to be in the Children’s welfare.

19     Instead, I broadly agree with the Husband’s proposed orders (including those orders sought by the Wife which he was prepared to accept) which I found to be appropriate in the circumstances. I therefore ordered that:

(a)     Subject to (b) below, the Husband shall have unsupervised access to the Children, every week from 10.30 am to 8.00 pm on Sundays.

(b)     The Husband shall have unsupervised overnight access to the Children on the last Saturday of every month from 10.30 am on Saturday to Sunday 8.00 pm.

(c)     With effect from the date of this Order, the Husband shall have access to the Children on every Public Holidays (excluding the CNY holidays) from 10.30 am to 8.00 pm.

(d)     During CNY public holiday period, the Husband shall have access on CNY Day 1 from 10.30 am to the CNY Day 2 at 10.30 am.

(e)     Subject to any agreement between the parties, the Husband shall pick up the Children from their place of residence at the beginning of access, and shall return them on or before the end of the access period.

(f)     The Wife is to take all necessary steps to facilitate the aforesaid access arrangements.

20     I now address the three (3) remaining disputed issues between the parties. These relate to overseas access, video-call access and the disclosure of the Children’s residential address.

21     To begin with, I found it bizarre that the question of overseas access was raised by the Wife in her submissions when the Husband was clear that he was not seeking any orders for overseas access.

22     The Husband recognised that overseas access was an issue which both parties may have to revisit when the Children are ready to go overseas with him. The Husband’s position was that this should be a matter which both parents can discuss and resolve amongst themselves later on.[note: 2]

23     The Wife, on the other hand, asked that the Court make a positive order forbidding the Husband from taking the Children for overseas access until the parties’ younger child turns 13 years old. For context, their younger child, [R], was only 3 years old (in 2024). Such an order meant that I would be effectively granting a 10-year injunction against the Husband from travelling overseas with the Children even though: (i) no order for overseas travel had even been sought by the Husband; and (ii) neither the Wife nor her counsel could provide any clear or cogent reasons why I should make such a prospective order, and for the number of years sought.

24     Having considered the matter, I decided not to make any orders relating to overseas access. Any such order would be entirely speculative (at the present juncture) and not grounded on any legitimate basis. Should the need arise, the question of overseas access should be dealt with separately and/or in subsequent proceedings.

25     Nevertheless, I strongly encourage the Wife – given what I had mentioned above about the need to be a bigger, stronger and wiser parent – to approach this issue with the same mindset she had adopted on the issue of Husband’s weekly and public holiday access. Children thrive when their parents act as role models and demonstrate to them that disputes and differences can be resolved through calm discussion and mutual understanding.

26     I next deal with the issue of the Husband’s video call access. The Wife’s written submissions did not address this issue directly although she did refer to an existing consent order vis-à-vis interim care and control and access (vide. FC/ORC xxx/2023) where there was provision for weekly video call access. The Husband’s position was that the existing video-call access arrangement should remain.

27     I was of the view that video-call access, which were already part of the existing consent order between the parties, should continue since there was no good reason put forth by either party to change this arrangement.

28     For good order, as orders made in the AM proceedings were a form of final relief, I made the same video-call access orders (as part of my overall AM orders) so that it was clear between the parties that FC/ORC xxx/2023 has since been superseded by my orders.

29     The final issue between the parties relate to whether the Wife should be made to disclose to the Husband, the Children’s residential address.

30     As the Husband’s counsel had highlighted at the AM hearing, the Wife had steadfastly refused to disclose the Children’s and her residential address, even going as far as redacting all such reference and information in the documents she had filed in these proceedings.

31     In my view, it was ancillary to, and consequential upon, the custody and access orders which were made vis-a-vis the Children for the Husband to also be provided with such information. I therefore agreed with the Husband that the Wife should be made to inform him of the Children’s residential address. To avoid doubt, the Court is empowered to impose such conditions as it may think fit to impose when making an order for the custody or care and control of the Children: see ss 126(1) and (2A), WC.

32     Being a joint custodial parent, I find that it was reasonable for the Husband to know where the Children live, in the event that he has to make any custodial decision and/or in the case of health emergencies. He would also need to know where he should pick up or return the Children for access. Neither party provided any evidence to suggest that the Husband was (or continues to be) a threat or danger to the Children.

33     In this regard, the Wife did advance some allegations regarding her personal safety. However, such concerns (if at all) relate to her personal safety and not the Children’s. In any case, these would already have been addressed by the personal protection order she had obtained against the Husband in separate proceedings. I see no reason for these concerns to justify withholding the Children’s place of residence from the Husband.

Division of Matrimonial Assets

34     I now move on to the address the major dispute between the parties, viz. the just and equitable division of their matrimonial assets.

Matrimonial pool of assets

35     I start by addressing the assets within the parties’ matrimonial pool (“Matrimonial Pool”).

36     In the present case, both parties had filed their respective Fact and Position Sheets setting out each party’s position on what fell within the Matrimonial Pool, prior to the AM hearing. The Wife’s counsel was also subsequently granted leave to file a revised version to account for some discrepancies which was highlighted during the hearing.[note: 3]

37     With regard to their matrimonial home, both counsel confirmed that the parties’ property at Ghim Moh Road (“Matrimonial Flat”) fell within the Matrimonial Pool and should be valued at the agreed figure of $435,000. After taking into account the outstanding mortgage loan, the net value of the Matrimonial Flat would be approximately $204,677.50 (ie. adopting the Husband’s calculations for the outstanding mortgage amount).[note: 4]

Wife’s Assets

38     As regards the Wife’s assets (save for the issue of dissipation which I will address below), I make the following broad findings and/or observations:

(a)     The parties were largely in agreement vis-à-vis the Wife’s cash (or cash-equivalent) assets held in her sole name. Although there were some discrepancies and differences in the original Fact and Position Sheet filed by the Wife, her revised version broadly aligned with what the Husband had stated in his own Fact and Position Sheet.

(b)     In total, I found the Wife to be holding assets amounting to approximately $528,970.38 (excluding the value of her motor vehicle, her branded handbag, and her cryptocurrency). For completeness, it was not disputed that the Wife had used the monies in her Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) account to purchase a “GRO Saver Flex” policy. During the AM hearing, the Husband – through his counsel – accepted the Wife’s valuation figure of $12,254.24 for this asset.

(c)     With regard to the Wife’s car, the parties disagreed as to the value which should be ascribed to this asset. The Wife submitted that the value of car was only $19,926.78, while the Husband submitted that the car’s purchase value (ie. $56,273.62) should be used instead.

(d)     I agreed with the Husband that the car’s purchase value (and not its estimated present value) should be used. It was not disputed that the car in question was purchased after the commencement of the present divorce proceedings, but before IJ was granted. The Husband did not consent to this expenditure and to the Wife’s use of matrimonial funds to acquire this asset.

(e)     In my view, this situation fell squarely within the ambit of what is referred to as the “TNL dicta” (drawn from the Court of Appeal’s seminal decision in TNL v TNK [2017] 1 SLR 609 (“TNL”)).

(f)     In WOS v WOT [2024] 1 SLR 437 (“WOS”), the Appellate Division of the High Court explained that the TNL dicta recognises that “substantial sums expended during the period where divorce proceedings are imminent must be returned to the asset pool if the other spouse has at least a putative interest in it and has not consented, either expressly or impliedly, to the expenditure either before it was incurred or at any subsequent time”: see WOS at [43].

(g)     As such, the monies expended by the Wife in acquiring her car should be accounted for. If the Wife had used some $56,273.62 to acquire what she now values at less than $20,000, then this “loss” was one which the Husband should not be responsible for.

(h)     With regard to the Wife’s branded handbag, there was some dispute between the parties as to its value. The difference is comparatively minor – the Husband valued it at $1,500 more than the Wife. Unfortunately, I was not persuaded by the Husband’s evidence of value (which comprised internet printouts/articles regarding the value of branded ladies’ handbags[note: 5]) which did not relate to the actual value of the Wife’s bag and, more importantly, did not account for its condition and re-sale value. As the Husband did not discharge his burden of proof, I adopted the Wife’s valuation of $3,000.

39     I now turn to the Wife’s cryptocurrency assets. This was a significant dispute given the amount involved, ie. $176,898.88 (being the value ascribed by the Husband) as compared to $72,947 (based on the Wife’s own declaration). As with the Wife’s car, I found it relevant to apply the TNL dicta to resolve this dispute.

40     To put matters in context, the Wife had liquidated approximately $103,000 worth of the parties’ cryptocurrency on the pretext that she had to use the same to pay for her and the family’s expenses. The Wife sought to provide reasons for her use of these funds because the principle underlying the TNL dicta allows for “run-of-the-mill” expenses used for the family to be exempted from its application.[note: 6]

41     Yet, as the Wife’s counsel rightly conceded during the AM hearing, the monies which the Wife was shown to have used to pay her solicitors, and her mother could not be reasonably be said to constitute “run-of-the-mill” expenses which are exempted from the application of the TNL dicta. These transactions alone accounted for approximately 60% of the significant payments and/or withdrawals she had made from monies she received in 2023 from liquidating the cryptocurrency assets. The remaining withdrawals were payments to herself, or for her credit card expenses.

42     Overall, I found it appropriate to return to the Matrimonial Pool the sum of $76,050, being $103,000 (which was the amount received by the Wife from the liquidation of the relevant cryptocurrencies) less $22,050 (being $2,450 x 9 months). I have allowed for the deduction of $22,050 as recognition of the household and/or the Children’s expenses which the Wife had to bear during the relevant period using the liquidated funds.

43     I note that at [17] of District Judge Darryl Soh’s (“DJ Soh”) Oral Grounds of Judgment (“DJ Soh’s Judgment”) in FC/SUM 1827/2023 (ie. the Wife’s earlier interim maintenance application), DJ Soh had declined to make an order for backdated maintenance in view of the fact that the Wife had “access to and used matrimonial funds to pay for her and the Children’s expenses”. I therefore accept that part of proceeds from the sale of the cryptocurrencies went to sustain the family’s expenses.

44     The figure of $2,450 I had used was consistent with the maintenance amount which DJ Soh had ordered in FC/SUM 1827/2023 (“Interim Maintenance Order”). I found this amount to be a reasonable proxy of what would have been “run-of-the-mill” family expenses during the relevant period.

45     Accordingly, I valued the Wife’s total sole named assets to be $664,294. This figure included her CPF monies, car, other cash assets, as well as the amount returned to the Matrimonial Pool arising from her liquidation of the cryptocurrency assets.

Husband’s assets

46     I now move on to the Husband’s sole named assets.

47     The parties were largely ad idem on most of the Husband’s assets,[note: 7] save for one significant item – the alleged dissipation of assets by the Husband. In the Wife’s revised written submissions, she submitted that I should “add-back” a total of $706,455[note: 8] to the Matrimonial Pool because the Husband had dissipated this amount through allegedly clandestine or suspicious transfers.

48     Having carefully considered the evidence presented, I agreed with the Wife that some of the bank transactions entered into by the Husband were not “run-of-the-mill” and should be returned to the Matrimonial Pool pursuant to the TNL dicta.

49     Although not strictly necessary, I also accept the Wife’s submission that some of the Husband’s other transactions/payments were not properly explained and there was a strong suggestion that the Husband had attempted to conceal assets from her and the Court. In my view, an adverse inference can also be drawn against the Husband in respect of these transactions with the same effect that these assets should be notionally “added back” to the Matrimonial Pool for the purpose of the AM proceedings. I shall explain my findings, below.

50     First, I wish to make clear what I did not find to be suspicious transactions and/or transactions falling within the ambit of the TNL dicta.

(a)     Contrary to the Wife’s submissions, I did not find the Husband’s withdrawals (of up to $1,000) from his OCBC and POSB bank accounts to be an attempt to dissipate assets, nor were they significant transactions falling within the TNL dicta.

(b)     I accept the Husband’s submission that these were used to pay for his personal expenses, or as allowance to his parents (out of filial piety). In reaching this conclusion, I took into account the Husband’s earning capacity, and the lifestyle he was maintaining (and was entitled to maintain) at the material time. Likewise, I do not find the payment of $1,565 to one [S] (his accountant) to be inappropriate.

(c)     Indeed, the Wife’s claim in this regard appeared to be based on her subjective belief as to what were the Husband’s attempts to dissipate assets. As the Husband’s counsel pointed out during the AM hearing, the Wife herself could have been said to be similarly “dissipating” assets since she spent monies of similar amounts. I found the Wife’s approach – which was primarily based on what she believed to be “large” transactions undertaken by the Husband post-divorce proceedings – to be too speculative. Moreover, I agreed with the Husband’s submission that some of the transactions identified by the Wife were, in fact, transactions between the Husband’s own bank accounts (for eg. the transaction said to have occurred in January and March 2023)[note: 9] – this reflected the speculative (and, possibly, over-inclusive) nature of the Wife’s approach.

(d)     I also did not agree with the Wife that the transaction involving $19,900 in November 2022 was an act of dissipation, or an instance of profligate spending. I accepted the Husband’s explanation that this was a payment for stamp duty to the tax authorities. In my view, this is supported by his bank transaction record showing payment to the commissioner for stamp duties.[note: 10]

(e)     The only item which I found to be within the scope of the TNL dicta was the Husband’s withdrawal and subsequent payment of $10,000 his mother. The Husband argued that this was meant to fund his mother’s medical expenses, but I agreed with the Wife’s submission that he had not discharged his burden to explain the said expense.[note: 11] No documentary proof was adduced to support his explanation. This amount ought to be “added-back” to the Matrimonial Pool.

51     I now move on to a key aspect of the Wife’s case, viz. the significant monies the Husband had transferred to one [RK] in 2022 and 2023. In total, the Husband had transferred $420,000 to [RK] (out of the alleged amount $706,445 which the Wife claimed had been dissipated).

52     The Husband did not dispute that the monies were indeed transferred to [RK]. However, his position was that these were legitimate transactions paid pursuant to contractual agreements between [RK] and him. To support his claim, he exhibited 2 “business agreements” he had signed with [RK] on two dates – ie. 1 November 2022 and 1 November 2023 (collectively, the “BAs”).

53     The Wife strenuously disputed the propriety and reliability of these 2 BAs. To buttress her arguments, the Wife pointed to the unusual timings of these contracts.

54     With regard to the 2022 BA, the Wife highlighted that the relevant $180,000 transfer to [RK] occurred on 8 December 2022, shortly after the Husband had liquidated certain time deposits from one of his investment products.[note: 12] As regards the 2023 BA, a sum of $240,000 was transferred to RK two (2) days after the Husband had received the surrender monies for his SingLife policy.[note: 13]

55     Having reviewed the evidence provided, I agreed with the Wife that the nature and circumstances surrounding the creation and/or execution of the 2 BAs to be highly suspect.

56     Putting aside the apparent visual similarity between the 2 documents (which, as the Wife had pointed out, were identical in form using the same fonts and linguistic style), the BAs themselves were digital documents (in the sense that the BAs were stored in an electronic form, with the signatures appended electronically) containing almost identical clauses and terms.

57     The two BAs even contained the same errors and/or surplusage in language.

(a)     For eg. the preamble of the 2022 BA, somewhat oddly, states that the “Client” (ie. the Husband) wanting to obtain [RK]’s “professional attributions” without any clear explanation of what “attributions” means.

(b)     Both BAs erroneously defined a period of time (eg. the period from November 2022 to October 2023) as the “Effective Date”, when a period of time is clearly not a “date” per se.

(c)     In any event, the phrase “Effective Date” is never used anywhere else in either contract thus rendering the use of a defined term entirely meaningless and superfluous.

58     While these visual and linguistic peculiarities, in and of themselves, do not automatically imply that the BAs were unenforceable or a sham, they operate as indicators suggesting that the BAs were, in fact, not the product of detailed negotiations nor were they prepared as part of an arms’ length deal. These features took on some importance given the significant monetary value involved.

59     What was more concerning was the complete lack of details and clarity in the legal terms and obligations arising from the BAs.

60     To begin with, the BAs were entirely silent on the specific obligations which each of the Husband and [RK] had actually taken on in these contracts. Other than the BAs stating – in its preamble – that the Husband wishes to obtain [RK]’s so-called “professional attributions” (whatever such a term meant in the 2022 BA) or “professional services” (in the 2023 BA), the contracts themselves say nothing as to how, when, and to whom such “attributions” or “services” were to be rendered.

61     I should highlight that the description of the “services” to be rendered by [RK] were wholly vague – the terms used were, for eg. “Administrative Support”, “Production Developments and “Life Coaching”, none of which were defined or explained in either BA. The payment terms were similarly lacking in clarity and detail – it merely states a sum of money “paid upfront for full 12 months contract” without stating who was to pay what to whom.

62     The absence of what would have been critical terms was equally telling. There was no express term on how and when [RK] was to provide his services, including whether he was entitled to any time off and/or whether he was meant to work for the Husband round the clock. There were no terms whatsoever on the issue of breach – nothing was said as to what would happen if [RK] had failed to provide the services sought, or if they were of a poor quality.

63     One would assume it would have been crucial for such terms to be included when parties negotiate a contract for services. Otherwise, the Husband appeared to be content to part ways with approximately a quarter of a million dollars “upfront” without any recourse should the counterparty later renege on his obligations.

64     This lack of clarity thus fortified the Wife’s allegation that it was highly unusual for the Husband to “increase” the contractual value by $60,000 (or a 30% increase from the 2022 BA’s contractual value) in the 2023 BA even though [RK] was providing the exact same work or served to the Husband. Why did the Husband decide to “pay” even more money to [RK] without any corresponding increase in any of [RK]’s obligations?

65     The above concerns neatly dovetailed with the timing of the BAs. I accept that the Wife’s point that so-called payments pursuant to the two BAs appeared too conveniently timed with when the Husband received funds through the liquidation of his other matrimonial assets.

66     I also took note of the obvious inconsistency between the date of the transfers and the alleged payment terms of the BAs. As observed earlier, the BAs (which were sparsely drafted) contained only 1 payment-related term, ie. that the full contract sum was “paid upfront for full 12 months contract”. Yet, it was plain from the dates of the actual transfers that the contract sum was not in fact “paid upfront” as envisaged under the BAs.

(a)     In respect of the 2022 BA, the payment to [RK] took place more than 1 month after the contract was purportedly signed on 1 November 2023. The Husband provided no evidence to show that he had negotiated with [RK] any separate payment arrangement or agreement.

(b)     In other words, either the Husband was in breach of the 2022 BA the minute it was signed, or [RK] had agreed to perform work free of charge for more than a month without any expectation to be paid. Either way, I did not find these possibilities to be persuasive.

(c)     Similarly, for the 2023 BA, payment to RK was not done “upfront”, and occurred only 1 week later. This was highly unusual given that by 2023, the parties presumably would have already been in a contractual relationship for close to one year, and knowing full well that the 2022 BA would be coming to an end by 31 October 2024. If parties were desirous to extend their contractual relationship, the Husband should have known when he would be in a position to pay [RK]. Yet, the parties chose to sign an agreement where payment was stated to have been done “upfront” even though no such payment would be made.

67     Although each of the aforesaid issues – when considered individually – may possibly be explained by the Husband’s and/or [RK]’s inattention to detail as laypersons or mere oversight, the overall picture suggests a complete lack of care and/or interest in the actual enforceability or legality of the BAs. The BAs appeared to have been hastily drafted by the Husband to explain, ex post facto, the monies he had transferred to [RK].

68     I therefore conclude that the BAs were created by the Husband with the intent of giving a veil of legitimacy for the transfers he had made to [RK]. In my view, the true purpose of the transfers was to conceal and/or hide what would have been matrimonial assets liable for division. There was sufficient evidence and basis to support the drawing of an adverse inference against the Husband: see UZN v UZM [2021] 1 SLR 426 at [68].

69     In any event, regardless of the BAs’ legitimacy, I find that the payments to [RK] were made using matrimonial monies without the Wife’s consent, and do not constitute “run-of-the-mill” expenses. They were also not ordinary business expenses as it was not at all clear why [RK] were paid those amounts given the nature of the services to be provided by him, and the lack of clarity as to his precise scope of work. The 30% increment paid to [RK] in 2023 was also not supported by good reason or cause.

70     In the circumstances, I found that a sum of $430,000 (being $420,000 transferred to RK, and the $10,000 transferred to the Husband’s mother) should be notionally “returned” to the Matrimonial Pool, and be subject to division in the AM proceedings.

Just and Equitable Division: Appropriate Methodology & Approach

72     Having addressed the contents and value of the Matrimonial Pool, I now move on to discuss the appropriate ratio of division.

73     In her submissions, the Wife’s position was that neither the structured approach recognised in ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 (“ANJ approach”) nor the trends-based approach (per TNL) would be entirely suitable.[note: 14] According to her, the parties’ marriage and her employment status were unique in that she was working for the Husband during the marriage and she believed that this may result in a skewed assessment of her matrimonial contributions (particularly, in considering her indirect contributions) if the ANJ approach was rigidly applied.

74     Nevertheless, the Wife – having regard to the High Court (Family Division)’s recent decision of WUI v WUJ [2024] SGHCF 25 – submitted that she was prepared to adopt the ANJ approach. The Husband’s submissions, on the other hand, proceeded on the assumption that the ANJ approach would be used.

75     In my view, the Wife’s concerns appeared to stem from a misapprehension as to how the ANJ approach would be applied. I do not agree with her submissions on at least 2 aspects.

(a)     First, one must have regard to why the Court of Appeal in TNL decided that for long single-income marriages, the ANJ approach was unsuitable. One key factor was the Court of Appeal’s concern that the ANJ approach may result in the over-valuing of the breadwinner spouse’s financial contributions and, at the same time, undervaluing the non-working spouse given that in the long single-income marriage paradigm, the non-working spouse tends to have little or nothing in the way of direct financial contributions (which was an integral part of the ANJ approach’s analytical framework).[note: 15]

(b)     Such a concern would not strictly apply in short marriages, and, in any event, was not a concern at all in the present case.

(c)     Second, I found the Wife’s concerns to be somewhat overstated. The ANJ approach was, in any case, sufficiently robust and could take into account the Wife’s direct and/or indirect contributions (even if, as the Wife claimed, her indirect contributions may not be so easily discernible or explained given her unusual employment situation).

(d)     Indeed, the Court of Appeal in ANJ v ANK itself explained the importance of the “broad brush approach” when considering the question of the spouses’ direct and indirect contributions.[note: 16]

76     I am thus of the view that the ANJ approach should be adopted in the present case as the marriage was one involving dual-incomes, with both parties making direct and indirect contributions to the marriage.

77     To recapitulate, the ANJ approach requires the Court to:

(a)    ascribe a ratio that represents each party’s direct contributions having regard to the amount of direct financial contribution each party has made towards the acquisition or improvement of the matrimonial assets; (b) ascribe a second ratio to represent each party’s indirect contribution to the wellbeing of the family throughout the marriage. Thereafter, using each party’s respective direct and indirect percentage contributions, the court derives each party’s average percentage contribution to the family that would form the basis to divide the matrimonial assets.

(see TOF v TOE [2021] 2 SLR 976 at [63(b)])

78     I will now explain how this approach should be applied in the present case.

Just and Equitable Division: Direct Financial Contributions

79     With respect to their respective direct financial contributions (“DFC”) to the marriage, the parties appear to largely agree on the following:

(a)     their direct contributions towards the acquisition of the Matrimonial Flat;

(b)     that the assets held by a party (and which has been found to be acquired by their own effort) would be used as a “proxy” for their direct contributions to the marriage; and

(c)     flowing from (b) above, the Husband’s sole-named assets represented his DFC.

80     The parties’ main disagreements principally relate to whether the SingLife Policy (ending -304) and the cryptocurrency held by the Wife should be treated as her DFC, or should part of these assets be treated as representing the Husband’s contributions because he was the person who had paid for these assets (either in part or wholly).[note: 17]

81     In my view, the Husband had not shown sufficient evidence in support of his claim that the Wife’s declared SingLife Policy was jointly purchased with his money. While he sought to explain that the policy was purchased in January 2020 through a single lump-sum payment, that assertion alone does not necessarily mean that half of this amount should be attributed to him. I was not persuaded that the Husband had shown the Wife to be totally incapable of affording the premium for this policy at the material time.

82     However, as regards the Wife’s cryptocurrency asset, I was of the view that half of the value of the said assets should be attributed to the Husband. This amount included the notional amount I had added-back to the Matrimonial Pool as set out at [42] above.

83     In this regard, the Wife had herself repeatedly asserted that the cryptocurrency was purchased with the parties’ joint monies.[note: 18] It would follow that she should recognise the Husband’s contribution to these assets.

84     Although the Husband argued that he was the one who had paid for all of the cryptocurrency assets to the tune of approximately $709,000,[note: 19] I did not find this allegation to have been sufficiently proven. Most of the Husband’s arguments were premised on inferences which he drew from what the Wife had deposed in her other affidavits apropos her income at the material time, and her ability to purchase the said asset.

85     Insofar as the Husband sought to rely on the fact that the Wife’s income/earnings ultimately came from him to show that he was the one who had “paid” for the cryptocurrency (or any other asset acquired by the Wife), I rejected this argument.

86     As mentioned above, the broad-brush approach remains relevant even in the context of the ANJ approach. I did not agree with the Husband that simply because the source of the Wife’s salary and/or income was the Husband’s business meant that all of her salary or income should be treated as if they were his contributions. In paying his Wife a salary (and declaring to the authorities as such), the Husband was clearly acting qua employer and not as her spouse. The monies received by the Wife, at the material time, represented her wages for work done and belonged to her both legally and beneficially.

87     Accordingly, in respect of the Wife’s cryptocurrency assets, I only attributed a sum of $74,498.50 (being $148,997 ÷ 2) to the Husband for the purpose of assessing his DFC.

88     For completeness, with regard to the issue of the parties’ contributions to the acquisition of the Matrimonial Flat, although parties were broadly in agreement, I found it appropriate to use the parties’ total CPF-based payments (at or around the IJ date) to derive the relevant ratio to be applied to the Matrimonial Flat’s net value, ie. The use of the IJ date reflects the recognition that the parties’ contributions to the marriage would stop after IJ has been granted.

89     The ratio to be applied to the Matrimonial Flat’s net value would be 51 (Husband) : 49 (Wife), based on the amount of CPF monies that had used to fund the said purchase.

Just and Equitable Division: Indirect Financial Contributions

91     I will now consider the parties’ indirect contributions (“IDC”) to the marriage.

92     At [75(c)] above, I alluded to the relevance of the broad-brush approach under the ANJ approach for both the parties’ direct and indirect contributions. I reiterate that when determining the parties’ IDC, the Court does not adopt “a rigid and mechanistic calculation exercise”,[note: 20] and would focus on “broad factual indicators such as the length of the marriage, the number of children, and which party was the children’s primary caregiver”[note: 21] rather than the minutiae of the parties’ family life during the marriage.[note: 22]

93     Although the parties’ marriage here was not a long one, they nevertheless have two (2) children to the marriage. Thus, their contributions in the realm of caretaking and raising the Children need to be accounted for.

94     On her part, the Wife submitted that a ratio of 60:40 in her favour should be applied. She supported her case by referring to her role as the Children’s caregiver,[note: 23] her management of the household and the assistance she had rendered to Husband’s business.[note: 24]

95     The Husband, on the other hand, submitted that a 50:50 ratio should be applied as it was his position that he too was the Children’s primary caregiver, and that he made significant indirect financial contributions to the family.

96     Although the gulf between the parties’ position was not great, having considered the evidence and the parties’ submissions, I was of the view that the appropriate ratio should be 55:45 (in the Wife’s favour).

97     In reaching this ratio, I agreed with the Wife’s claim that she was, in fact, the Children’s main caregiver.[note: 25] Although the Husband did provide some assistance on this front, I find that Wife’s efforts to be greater.

98     In ANJ v ANK, the Court of Appeal noted (at [24]) that:

[…] Contributions in the form of parenting, homemaking and husbandry, by their very nature, are incapable of being reduced into monetary terms. No mathematical formula or analytical tool is capable of capturing or accommodating the diverse and myriad set of factual scenarios that may present themselves to court as to how the parties may have chosen to divide among themselves duties and responsibilities in the domestic sphere. It is in making this determination that what is known as the broad brush approach would have to come into play. What values to give to the indirect contributions of the parties is necessarily a matter of impression and judgment of the court. In most homes, even in a home where both the spouses are working full time, in the absence of concrete evidence it is more likely than not that ordinarily the wife will be the party who renders greater indirect contributions [...]

[Emphasis in bold added]

99     I did not find the Husband to have provided concrete evidence in support of his claim that he made greater (or, at least similar) indirect contributions in the realm of homemaking, parenting, or husbandry, so as to displace my finding that the Wife had, more likely than not, rendered greater IDC.

100    I found the present marriage to be one where each spouse took on slightly different roles in the marriage, even though the Wife was working for the Husband. The Husband’s contributions consisted of mainly of indirect financial contributions in the sense that he had paid for various expenses incurred by the family.

101    Overall, awarding the Wife a slightly higher ratio of indirect contributions was justified on the facts.

102    To be clear, in reaching the IDC ratio set out above, I did not agree with the Wife’s claim that the Husband had committed such misconduct so as to justify ascribing a negative value towards his contributions. The examples cited by the Wife’s counsel – such as Chan Tin Sun v Fong Quay Sim [2015] 2 SLR 195 – involved far more egregious conduct. Allegations of the Husband’s behaviour (including those involving family violence) have been addressed in separate fora and I do not find those arguments to warrant reducing his IDC.

Just and Equitable Division: Average Ratio & Weightage

103    In the circumstances, the average division ratio would be as follows:

104    The next issue I would briefly address is whether the above ratio ought to be adjusted through placing different weightages on each of the parties’ DFC and IDC.

105    In his submissions, the Husband asked that I place greater weightage on the parties’ direct contributions given the short length of their marriage. In support thereof, the Husband cited the Court of Appeal’s decision in ATE v ATD [2016] SGCA 2 (“ATE v ATD”).

106    While it is well-established that the court can apply different weightages in the appropriate case, it is nevertheless important to understand why a court would do so. ATE v ATD itself provides a useful example.

107    In that case, the Court of Appeal was considering a case involving a relatively short marriage where, for most of the marriage, the parties were childless. When the parties’ only child was born, the parties separated shortly thereafter. The Court further found the husband in that case to be calculative and stingy vis-à-vis the wife (who was the more financially successful party). The parties kept their finances separately throughout the marriage, and the wife never depended on the husband. The parties also had the assistance of a domestic helper and the wife’s mother in caring for the child. Under those circumstances, the Court of Appeal found it appropriate to place greater weightage on the parties’ direct contributions.

108    In its subsequent decision in USB v USA [2020] 2 SLR 588 (“USB”), the Court of Appeal had occasion to further opine on when a court should adjust the weightage placed on the spouses’ direct and indirect contributions. The Court of Appeal’s following observations (at [40] – [42] of its judgment) are particularly apposite:

40    Generally, indirect contributions are less significant in short marriages, especially those without children. The court may take this into account by ascribing a higher weightage to direct contributions. In ATE v ATD and another appeal [2016] SGCA 2, this court assigned the parties’ direct contributions a higher weightage in a marriage lasting about five years. Andrew Phang Boon Leong JA held at [21]:

Given that the marriage was a short one, that both Husband and Wife were working, the manner in which both Husband and Wife conducted their lives during the marriage itself, and that there was a not inconsiderable amount of assistance on the domestic scene, the appropriate ratio between direct and indirect contributions ought to be 75% and 25% respectively.

41     It should be reiterated that the court has a discretion to adjust the weightage of direct and indirect contributions in a short marriage – it is not compelled to arrive at an unequal weightage. There may well be good reasons for the court to retain equal weightage between direct and indirect contributions even in a short marriage, especially if there are children. Apart from short marriages, we add the important caveat that adjusting the weightage of the direct and indirect contributions should be done as an exception. This is because of the features of a long marriage as recognised by this court (ANJ v ANK ([1] supra) at [27]):

… Indirect contributions in general tend to feature more prominently in long marriages … The courts also tend to give weighty consideration to homemakers who have painstakingly raised children to adulthood, especially where such efforts have entailed significant career sacrifices on their part.

42    Where the court exercises its discretion to adjust the weightage, apart from in a short marriage, we are of the view that cogent reasons should be provided to explain the departure from the norm of equal weightage.

[Emphasis added in Bold]

109    The facts in the present case were markedly different from ATE v ATD in that the parties here have 2 children to the marriage – [K] was born in August 2019, about 1 year into the parties’ marriage, and [R] was born 2 years thereafter. Parties largely remained an intact family until late 2022, with both parties expending efforts to care for the Children (albeit with external assistance). As I had noted above, the parties took on different roles during the marriage, which each expending efforts in different areas.

110    I emphasise that the Court of Appeal’s clear guidance in USB that any adjustment of the weightage is a matter of discretion and that a court is not compelled to arrive at an unequal weightage just because marriage was short, especially when there are children (as is the case here). When a court does place unequal weightage on the parties’ contributions, there must be cogent reasons to do so.

111    In arriving at the appropriate IDC ratio (at [96] above), I already took into account factors such as the length of the parties’ marriage and their respective roles in the raising the Children and the maintenance of the household. I also considered the fact that the Husband himself accepts that some of the “bonuses” which he had paid the Wife “were either diverted back into the business or into investments”, and monies were by “channel[ed] back to [him]” for such purposes.[note: 26]

112    I therefore saw no additional and/or separate reason why I should place unequal weightage on the direct and indirect contributions. Indeed, placing greater weightage on direct contributions alone (as suggested by the Husband) may create the additional effect of over-valuing the assets which are held by the Husband. I therefore maintained the norm and placed equal weightage on the parties’ DFC and IDC ratios.

Implementation and Apportionment
