114    My detailed orders are set out at [139] below.

Maintenance

115    I now move on to the final area of contention, ie. the amount payable by the Husband as his share of the Children’s maintenance. The Wife had confirmed that she was not seeking maintenance for herself.

116    As stated above, the Interim Maintenance Order which was in force between the parties required the Husband to pay maintenance for the Children in the sum of $2,450 per month. It is trite that that being an order for interim maintenance, the obligations therein would come to an end once I make a final maintenance order as part of the AM proceedings: see AXM v AXO [2014] 2 SLR 705 at [20] (“AXM”).

Court’s power to order maintenance for the Children

117    Although the law relating to maintenance is largely uncontroversial, for conceptual clarity, I find it necessary to address a point raised in the Wife’s written submissions, ie. her purported reliance on s 118 of the WC and the alleged “material change” which has occurred since the making of the Interim Maintenance Order.[note: 27]

118    I start by highlighting that this Court’s power to make a final order for the Children’s maintenance stems from s 127 of the WC, which provides that:

Power of court to order maintenance for children

127.—(1)    During the pendency of any matrimonial proceedings or when granting or at any time subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage, the court may order a parent to pay maintenance for the benefit of his or her child in such manner as the court thinks fit.

119    In my view, the Wife’s reference to s 118 of the WC in her written submissions[note: 28] was erroneous for at least two reasons.

(a)      First, s 118 does not actually apply in the present case because that provision addressed applications for the variation of spousal maintenance orders made under s 113 of the WC. Applications to vary a child maintenance order are governed by s 127, read with Parts 8 and 9 of the WC (in particular, s 72 of the WC).

(b)     This is not necessarily a distinction without a difference. As the Court of Appeal had noted in AXM (at [33]), the language of s 72 appears wider that s 118.

(c)      Second, and more importantly for present purposes, regardless of whether one is referring to s 118 or s 72, it would not be correct to say that the AM court’s role is to consider whether Interim Maintenance Order ought to be “varied” as I am not bound to follow the Interim Maintenance and this Court is, strictly speaking, hearing the matter afresh: see AXM at [20].

(d)     This means that whether the final maintenance order should be similar to (or different from) the Interim Maintenance Order does not depend solely on whether there has been “misrepresentation or mistake of fact or whether there has been any material change in the circumstances”.

120    Notwithstanding the above, it appeared from the parties’ submissions that they each sought to persuade me that the terms of the Interim Maintenance Order should not be replicated in its entirety in my final maintenance order because they each believe that circumstances have changed such that some (but not all) of the terms of Interim Maintenance Order should be adjusted.

121    Insofar as the Wife’s case used the terms of the Interim Maintenance Order as a broad “starting point”, I agreed with that approach. In my view, the Interim Maintenance Order, which was made in late 2023 after a detailed assessment of the Children’s expenses where both parties presented the relevant evidence, remained highly relevant.

122    To avoid doubt, I have considered the Husband’s submissions (including his claims that the Wife had not provided evidence of certain expenses, and/or that there was alleged double counting or excessive claims). However, as the High Court (Family Division) had noted in WBU v WBT [2023] SGHCF 3 (“WBU”) (at [10] and [11] of the judgment), maintenance orders are often made with a view of providing a “budget” for the care parent to use to maintain the children:

10    It follows that in seeking to quantify the child’s reasonable expenses, parties should avoid an overly mathematical approach where receipts are adduced to prove every single item of expenditure. This is not to say that no evidence is ever required to support proposals for what is sought as reasonable maintenance; it depends on the type of expenses sought, and of course, on the facts of each case. While receipts are useful as an indication of the child’s accustomed standard of living, they are not necessarily conclusive of what the child’s reasonable expenses are. It may be helpful for parties to apply their minds to drawing up what can be described as a ‘budget’, whereby broad categories of the child’s estimated needs are identified, and a corresponding reasonable sum is proposed for each category (see, for example, the table set out below at [13]). It was observed in UEB v UEC [2018] SGHCF 5 (at [13]): [quote omitted]

11    In applying this “budget” approach to quantify maintenance, two points are worthy of note. First, the budget instils accountability between the parties in their continuing roles as co-parents, serving as a baseline financial framework for the parties in respect of their expenses concerning the child. Second, considering the categories of expenses within a “budget framework” is consistent with the notion that deciding how best to provide for the child (which includes what exactly to spend on in providing for the child) is a parenting matter. Thus, the court will not be overly prescriptive in how these budgeted monies are specifically applied to various detailed items of expenses. In drawing up the appropriate budget, parties may disagree over decisions such as what to spend on for the child’s benefit, including what the child is to eat, what enrichment classes the child should attend, and even which lifestyle habits to cultivate in the child. These are fundamentally parenting decisions involving parents’ views and aspirations for their child which are personal and unique to each set of parents. A court of law is not the most appropriate forum to resolve such parenting matters. Instead, it is a fundamental part of the parties’ parental responsibility to attempt to resolve their differences and come to a compromise for the child’s best interests. Even after a marriage has broken down, the mutual “give and take” which is the very pith and marrow of family decision-making should not cease […]

123    I found the Family Court’s earlier assessment that the Children’s monthly expenses amounted $9,083 (inclusive of their share of the household expenses) to be based on a reasonable and appropriate budget, having regard to the Children’s standard of living and needs.

Changes since the Interim Maintenance Order

124    I now address the changes which each party has asked for in their respective AM submissions.

125    On the Wife’s part, she sought an additional order that the Husband be responsible for paying her for the Children’s share of the monthly rent she is paying for her current rented apartment.[note: 29] This category of expense was expressly excluded in DJ Soh’s decision as the Wife was staying with her parents when the Interim Maintenance Order was made, and there was no clear evidence that her parents had demanded rent from her (even though she claimed to be paying such “rent”).[note: 30]

126    The Wife explained that she had since taken on a lease for the sum of $3,500 per month, and therefore asked that the Husband to contribute thereto. The Husband disagreed on the basis that he had never agreed to the Wife taking on this lease.

127    As I had mentioned above, the law relating to maintenance is fairly trite and one established principle is that the obligation to provide maintenance for one’s children includes the provision of reasonable accommodation expenses, especially in circumstances where it was not unreasonable for the care parent and the children to live in their own apartment, separately from the other parent after the breakdown of the marriage: see VXM v VXN [2022] 3 SLR 1174 at [17] and [19], per Debbie Ong J (as Her Honour then was).

128    I thus found the Wife’s claim for a contribution towards the Children’s share of her $3,500 monthly rental expense to be reasonable.

129    That said, given what she would receive from the division of the parties’ matrimonial asset (in view of my decision above), I would expect that she should take steps to acquire her own property in the long term, and she cannot assume that the Husband should be providing for this expense in perpetuity. After all, she had wanted care and control of the Children, and having been granted the same, she should take steps to procure permanent long-term accommodations for them. It was also the Wife’s position in her AM Fact and Position Sheet that she is seeking an order for the sale of the Matrimonial Flat in the open market.[note: 31]

130    Any future changes in this respect may be addressed either by parties through mutual agreement, or by a variation of the order (if a change is justified).

131    On the Husband’s part, his submissions were centred on persuading the Court that his personal financial circumstances have changed such that the approx. 83 (Husband) : 27 (Wife) apportionment ratio used by DJ Soh was no longer be appropriate since his earnings have decreased while the Wife’s income has increased since the time of the Interim Maintenance Order.[note: 32] He sought changes to the terms of Interim Maintenance Order on that basis.

Apportionment of the Children’s expenses.

132    The use of the parties’ earnings and income as the basis for apportioning the Children’s expenses between the two parents is similarly well-established: see for eg., WBU at [40] – [43]. In determining the same, the Court undertakes a holistic assessment of the parties’ financial abilities, earning capacity and resources consistent with s 69(4) of the WC.

133    In the present case, I accept that the Wife’s income had increased from when the Interim Maintenance Order was made. By her own admission, she now earns approximately $10,000 each month. This is twice the amount which DJ Soh had assessed her income to be in November 2023.

134    As regards the Husband’s earnings, his claim that his earnings had reduced appeared to be based principally on his latest income tax assessment wherein he reported an annual income of $106,117 (or approximately $8,800 per month).[note: 33]

135    However, I agreed with the Wife that the Court’s assessment was not limited to one party’s current asserted income. The party’s overall earning capacity (which can be seen from taking a longitudinal view of his/her income over the years) was also relevant. In the Husband’s case, his current income reflected an unusual and drastic decrease from his previous years’ income, which, at its peak (in 2020), amounted to some $698,970 per year.[note: 34]

136    Even when he filed his first AM affidavit in February 2024, he declared his income to be $25,000 per month. Considering the Husband’s historical earnings, I found the figure of $25,000 (which DJ Soh had used as a proximate for the Husband’s earning capacity) to remain fair and reasonable, even if the Husband’s declared income in his latest income tax documents was lower. In making this assessment, I considered the fact that the Husband ran his own business as well as my observations (at [68] – [70] above) apropos the Husband’s attempts and ability to hide/put aside assets.

137    Accordingly, the apportionment ratio should be adjusted to 70 (Husband): 30 (Wife). This change in apportionment ratio would consequently mean that the Husband’s share of the Children’s expenses would be changed to approx. $6,360. Since he was currently paying for the Children’s school fees and insurance premiums in the sum of approx. $5,240 and should continue to do so, he should be responsible for the shortfall amount of $1,120 per month.

138    In addition, the Husband shall pay to the Wife the sum of $1,633, ie. 70% of $2,333 (being the Children’s share of the monthly rent).

Conclusion

139    In the premises, I made the following orders:

For the Children’s issues

(a)     In relation to the Children’s issues, I granted (by consent) the parties joint custody of the children of the marriage, [K] and [R], with care and control of the Children granted to the Wife.

(b)     I granted the Husband unsupervised weekly access from 10.30 am to 8.00 pm on Sundays, except that on the last Saturday of every month, he can have overnight access to the Children from 10.30 am on Saturday to Sunday 8.00 pm.

(c)     I also granted the Husband: (i) access to the Children on every public holiday and during the CNY period as proposed by the Wife; and (ii) video-call access 3 days each week. Consequential orders were made relating to the pick-up and return of the Children, as well as requiring the Wife to provide to the Husband the address of the Children’s place of residence (including any change thereof, if and when there is such a change).

Division of Matrimonial Assets

(d)     With regard to the division of the parties’ matrimonial assets, I ordered that the Wife be entitled to the sum of $328,179.86 (being her share of the parties’ matrimonial assets) and made provision for how this order was to be implemented.

(e)     In essence, I gave the Husband the option of acquiring the Wife’s share in the Matrimonial Flat by paying her the aforesaid sum of money. If he chose not to do so, then the Matrimonial Flat would be sold and the net sale proceeds would be used to pay off what the Wife was entitled to (with the Husband making good any shortfall in cash).

(f)     Save as set out above, I ordered that each party shall retain the assets in their sole name and possession. I also gave both parties liberty to apply.

140    When I delivered my decision to the parties via Registrar’s Notice, I invited both counsel to provide submissions on the issue of costs (if any) for the AM proceedings.

141    Having considered the matter, and in light of the fact that neither party could be said to have been wholly successful in these proceedings, I made no order as to costs. In doing so, I took into account the observations made by the High Court in JBB v JBA [2015] SGHCF 6 (at [31] to [33]) as to when costs orders in AM proceedings would be appropriate.

XJK v XJL

XJK v XJL
[2025] SGFC 25

Case Number:Divorce No 1496 of 2023 (Ancillary Matters)
Decision Date:04 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Natasha Choo (M/s A C Shone & Co) for the Wife; Luke Lee Yoon Tet (M/s Luke Lee & Co) for the Husband.
Parties: XJK — XJL

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Bank accounts in joint names with third party – Wife contending that funds in bank accounts in joint names of the Husband and his mother were matrimonial assets – Husband’s mother claiming that the funds belonged to her entirely – Husband’s mother deciding against applying for a stay of the ancillary matters proceedings or for a declaration of her interests in the bank accounts – Whether court can determine if the funds belong to the Husband’s mother entirely

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Bank accounts in joint names with third party – Wife contending that funds in bank accounts in joint names of the Husband and his mother were matrimonial assets – Burden of proof

4 March 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       The parties were married in May 2015 and have a 9½-year-old son (born in August 2015) (“Son”).

2       The Wife commenced divorce proceedings in March 2023. The parties were able to resolve many of the ancillary matters by mutual agreement. An interim judgement – which incorporates the terms of their agreement – was granted by consent on 6 November 2023.

3       The parties were however unable to agree on how their matrimonial assets should be divided. This issue came before me for a resolution.

Applicable approach

4       It is common ground that the matrimonial assets should be divided based on the “structured approach” enunciated in ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 (“ANJ”). (In the present case, the marriage had lasted for about 8½ years. Save for about 15 months when the Wife stopped working to take care of the Son after his birth, the parties had a dual income marriage.[note: 1])

5       Under the “structured approach”, I will need to first identify and value the matrimonial assets. Thereafter, I will have to divide the assets after taking into account each party’s –

(a)     direct/financial contributions towards “the acquisition or improvement of matrimonial assets” and

(b)     “indirect contributions to the well-being of the family”: XDZ v XEA [2024] SGFC 90 (“XDZ”) at [29].

6       I will now apply the “structured approach” to the present case.

The Flat

Value of the asset

7       I begin with the matrimonial flat (“Flat”). It is currently being occupied by the Husband and Son – the Wife had left the Flat on 15 December 2022.

8       The Flat is subject to HDB’s minimum occupation period (“MOP”) requirement. It can be sold only after 9 October 2025.[note: 2] Given the MOP requirement, there is currently no transaction in the resale market that can be considered to value the Flat.

9       In the circumstances, I assessed the value of the Flat by subtracting the parties’ outstanding loan from HDB to purchase the Flat (“outstanding loan”) (about $90,332.03[note: 3]) from its purchase price ($312,500.00). Applying this approach, I valued the Flat at $222,167.97:

 

Item

Parties’ position

22     The issue of whether the funds in the Joint Accounts are matrimonial assets is hotly contested.

(a)     According to the Husband, the relevant funds belong to his mother “entirely” and are thus not matrimonial assets.[note: 10] His mother has filed affidavits to support this position.

(b)     On the other hand, the Wife submitted that the relevant funds belong entirely to the Husband. She further submitted that he had made several withdrawals from the Joint Accounts to avoid their division.[note: 11]

Third party interest – the Husband’s mother

23     As a preliminary point, I note that there is a third-party who has an interest in the Joint Accounts – the Husband’s mother.

24     In the circumstances, the following bears highlighting:

(a)     Section 112 of the Charter does not confer power upon a court either (i) to adjudicate a claim by a third party to an alleged matrimonial asset or (ii) to make orders against the third party in respect of that asset: UDA v UDB [2018] 1 SLR 1015 (“UDA”) at [28], [29] and [31] to [34].

(b)     Where a third party wishes to directly assert his/her rights to an alleged matrimonial asset, that party should commence independent civil proceedings against either or both spouses for a declaration as to his/her interest and other relief. The third party can also apply to intervene in the s 112 proceedings – for the sole purpose of notifying the court of his/her interest and of applying for a stay. When faced with such an application, the court ought to stay the s 112 proceedings: UDA at [54] and [55].

The mother does not intend to intervene

25     In the present case –

(a)     The Husband’s mother had asserted that the funds in the Joint Accounts belonged to her entirely.

(b)     The Husband’s mother had however decided not to file a stay application. Neither does she intend to apply for a declaration that the funds in these accounts belong to her beneficially. She had made this decision because of her age (she is about 81 years old)[note: 12] and her health condition.

(c)     The Husband’s mother had expressly stated on affidavit that she is prepared for me to make a fair and just decision in the proceedings between the Husband and the Wife. According to the mother, she had submitted in evidence all the relevant documents in her possession to prove that all the funds in the Joint Accounts belong to her.[note: 13]

Power to make factual findings v Power to make binding orders

26     In deciding how to proceed in this matter, I found the following guidance from UDA to be instructive:

(a)     If a court is notified of a third party’s claim to an alleged matrimonial asset but no separate legal action has been commenced, then the options available to the court will depend on the legal ownership of the property and whether the spouses seek a binding order over the property or the third party: UDA at [53] and [55].

(b)     If the property is legally owned by one of the spouses who claims to hold it on trust for the third party, the court can determine whether the property is a matrimonial asset without involving the third party at all if no order is sought by or against the third party directly: UDA at [58].

(c)     However, if an order binding the third party is sought, then a separate set of proceedings will have to be issued: UDA at [58].

27     Based on the above, I can determine whether the funds in the Joint Accounts belong to the Husband’s mother entirely – so long as I do not make binding orders against her. If the Wife wishes to seek such orders, then she will have to commence separate proceedings against the Husband’s mother. Presumably, the Wife will only do so if I find that the relevant funds belong entirely to the Husband.

Burden of proof

28     In determining to whom do the funds in the Joint Accounts belong to, I took the following approach.

(a)     Based on first principles, as a joint account holder, the Husband has a legal (and by inference, a beneficial) interest of the funds in the Joint Accounts.

(b)     In the absence of evidence to the contrary, funds in a joint account belong to the account holders in equal proportions: Timing Ltd v Tay Toh Hin [2021] 4 SLR 1040 at [18]; WWM v WWN [2024] SGHCF 27 at [14]. In other words, the Husband is presumed to be the beneficial owner of half the funds in the Joint Accounts.

(c)     Given the above, the burden of proof is thus as follows:

(i)       The Husband has the burden to prove his case that all the funds in the Joint Accounts belong to his mother and not to him.

(ii)       The Wife has the burden to prove her case that the Husband’s mother has no beneficial interest in the relevant funds whatsoever, and that they belong entirely to the Husband.

(iii)       Additionally, the Wife has the burden to prove her case that the Husband had dissipated the relevant funds from the Joint Accounts to avoid their division in the divorce.

29     Applying the above principles, I find that the Joint Accounts are not matrimonial assets and are thus not liable for division. Let me explain.

POSB 027 XXX

30     I find that the Husband has rebutted the inference that he has beneficial interests in the funds in POSB 027 XXX. I come to this finding based on the following.

(a)      First, it is not disputed that his mother had opened the account. According to the mother, the Husband did not contribute any fund in the account. The mother’s evidence is supported by the evidence. The bank records for POSB 027 XXX show that the account had (i) $54,750 on 27 May 1994[note: 14] and (ii) $75,436.23 on 31 December 1999.[note: 15] At the material times, the Husband was only 16 years old (1994) and 21 years old (1999). Furthermore, between 27 May 1994 to 1999, there were several deposits into, and withdrawals of funds from, the account. The largest of these involved $35,000. Given his young age and the amount of funds involved, it is unlikely that the Husband would not been the one who had conducted such transactions at the material times.

(b)      Second, the mother gave evidence that she had no intention to gift to the Husband the funds in the account during her lifetime, and that he would be entitled to them only upon her death.[note: 16] I have no reason to disbelieve this evidence. The mother is elderly and there is no evidence that she has any source of income. In the circumstances, there is no reason why she would want to gift to the Husband significant amount of funds in the account.

31     Additionally, the Wife’s claim – that all the funds in POSB 027 XXX belong to the Husband – is based on her submission that “there is no evidence to show that the monies belong to the Husband’s Mother”.[note: 17] With respect, this claim ignores the fact that (a) the account is in joint names with the mother, (b) funds in a joint account prima facie belong to the account holders in equal proportions (see [28(b)]), and (c) the Wife has the burden to prove her case that the funds belong entirely to the Husband.

32     Given that the Wife has failed to prove that all the funds in POSB 027 XXX belong to the Husband, there is no need for me to address her case that there was dissipation of funds. That said, I wish to make a few observations. The Wife relies on a withdrawal of $49,000 on 8 July 2023 for her submission that there was dissipation of funds. I am not persuaded by this submission. First, it is the mother evidence that she had transferred the $49,000 to her other son. Second, a transfer of $49,000 does not seem all that unusual for this account. The bank book shows that between 2006 to 2020 (i.e., before the marriage), there were eight other instances where huge sums of $40,000 or more had been deposited/withdrawn from the account.[note: 18]

UOB 908 XXX

33     Next, I come to the joint account in UOB 908 XXX.

34     According to the Husband’s mother, this account was opened in 1999. At the material time, the Husband was only 20 years old, recently released from imprisonment, unemployed, and did not have money to deposit into the account.[note: 19] I accept the mother’s evidence that the account was operated by her solely and that the Husband did not contribute any funds into this account.[note: 20]

35     The Wife made the following submissions.

(a)      First, the mother’s evidence was intended to avoid the Husband’s funds in the account from being liable for division.[note: 21]

(b)      Second, the $100,000 withdrawn from the account on 19 August 2022 should be added to the matrimonial pool because the marriage was already breaking down at the material time.[note: 22] To support this contention, the Wife’s counsel referred me to a quarrel between the parties in 2017 or 2018 which led to the Wife seeing a lawyer for advice on getting a divorce.[note: 23]

36     I am not persuaded by the Wife’s submissions.

(a)     I have examined the bank records for the account. (The available records before me are from 2011 to 2019.[note: 24]) I do not see anything therein that discredits the mother’s evidence.

(b)     Furthermore, the Wife had submitted that “there is nothing to suggest that it was the Husband or the Husband’s Mother who had managed the account” (emphasis added).[note: 25] In other words, the Wife acknowledged that it was plausible that the account was managed by the mother.

(c)     As for the submission in [35(b)] above, I note that the $100,000 was broken up into three parts of $33,333 each – two parts were placed in two separate fixed deposits (in joint names with the Husband) and the remaining part was used to pay an insurance policy/fixed deposit (“Policy”) in full. According to the mother, she had bought the Policy using the Husband’s name – in case the insurers refused to insure her because of her age. The financial benefits under the Policy belonged to her.[note: 26] In my view, these transactions are consistent with the mother being the person who operated the UOB 908 XXX account and disposing of the funds as she pleased.

(d)     I am unable to agree with the Wife that the withdrawal of $100,000 from the account had occurred at a time when divorce was “imminent”: UZN v UZM [2021] 1 SLR 426 at [67] and [68].

(i)       It bears highlighting that the Wife did not file a divorce after seeing the lawyer in 2017 or 2018. The parties had continued to live together for the next four years. It was only in March 2023 that the Wife decided to file for divorce.

(ii)       The $100,000 was withdrawn about four months before the Wife left the Flat (December 2022) and about seven months before she filed for divorce (March 2023). In WQG v WQF [2024] SGHCF 13 at [2] and [3], the High Court declined to infer that a transaction that had occurred about two months before a divorce – a period that is even shorter than the present case – was intended to deplete the matrimonial pool.

UOB 314 XXX

37     Finally, I turn to UOB 314 XXX. According to the Husband’s mother she had made the following transactions in connection with the account:[note: 27]

(a)     On 29 October 2022, she withdrew $50,000 from UOB 908 XXX (joint account with the Husband).

(b)     Two days later (on 31 October 2022), she deposited the $50,000 into UOB 314 XXX, a fixed deposit account. The evidence shows that the fixed deposit had a tenor of 10 months (i.e., it matured on 31 August 2023).

(c)     On 31 August 2023 (i.e., when the fixed deposited matured), the mother withdrew $50,000 from the account and deposited the funds into her joint account with her daughter.

38     The above evidence is consistent with the bank records.[note: 28] The fact that the mother could freely transfer $50,000 between her various joint accounts (including one with her daughter) supports her contention that the funds in these accounts belong to her.

39     Apart from speculation, the Wife has not adduced any evidence to prove otherwise.[note: 29]

Relevant considerations

50     Under the “structured approach”, I must also consider the indirect contributions the parties have made to “the well-being of the family”.

51     Such contributions typically include the following: XDZ at [29(b)].

(a)     Paying household expenses.

(b)     Performing household chores.

(c)     Caring for the child(ren) and other family members.

(d)     Expending money and effort to maintain/enhance the condition of the matrimonial home. (Note. This is to be distinguished from the expenditure of funds, when a matrimonial home is first acquired, to renovate it and make it habitable. The expenditure of such funds should be considered in assessing the parties’ direct contributions: WTL v WTM [2024] SGHCF 40 at [33] and [34].)

(e)     Expending money and effort to enhance the quality of life of family members.

(f)     Making personal sacrifices for the family, e.g., stop work to look after the child or so that a spouse may advance in his/her career and endeavours.

(g)     Supporting a spouse. This can carry a lot of weight especially when the support is given during the spouse’s personal crisis.

My decision

53     I am mindful that certain aspects of the parties’ cases regarding their indirect contributions are disputed or may appear to contradict each other: see the italicized text in [52] above. In the absence of objective evidence (which is often the case), I would be slow to accept a party’s evidence when he/she takes a sweeping position that the other party did not contribute in any way whatsoever, e.g., to household expenses, household chores, and childcare.

54     Taking a holistic view of the factors in [52] above, I find that the Wife had made greater indirect contributions to the family. Adopting a broadbrush approach, I find the parties’ respective share of indirect contributions to be 60% (Wife) and 40% (Husband).

Ratio for division of matrimonial assets

55     Considering both the direct and indirect contributions by the parties, I find that the matrimonial assets should be divided equally between the parties.

57     Finally, I come to the issue of how the matrimonial assets should be split – taking into account the value of the assets that each of them are entitled to.

Parties’ share in the Flat

58     In my view, it would be appropriate –

(a)     For each party to retain the assets currently held in their names, and

Transfer of interests in the Flat

60     Each party has requested that the rights, title and interests in the Flat be transferred to him/her solely – on the understanding that the Son will continue to reside in the Flat with that party.

61     In my view, it would be just and equitable to proceed as follows:

(a)     The Husband shall have the right of first option to buy over the Wife’s share in the Flat.

(b)     If the Husband wants to exercise this option, then he must pay $106,571.56 to the Wife within a reasonable period. Given the amount involved, a reasonable period for the Husband to make the payment would be three months from the date of this decision..

(c)     If the Husband fails to exercise this option, then the Wife shall have the option to buy over the Husband’s share in the Flat.

(d)     If the Wife wants to exercise this option, then she must pay $25,264.40 to the Husband within a reasonable period. Given that a smaller amount is involved, and the fact that the Wife has more time to raise the necessary funds, a reasonable period for the Wife to make the payment would be one month from the date when the Husband’s option expires.

(e)     If the Wife does not exercise her option, then the Flat shall be sold in the open market within a reasonable period after the MOP has ended (i.e., after 9 October 2025). In my view, a reasonable period would be within two months from 9 October 2025.

62     In deciding to give the Husband (not the Wife) the right of first option to buy over the Flat, I have considered the interests of the Son. Let me explain.

(a)     According to the interim judgment, the parties are to share the care and control of the Son in the following manner:

(i)       Wife: Friday (after school) to Sunday 8.00 pm.

(ii)       Husband: Sunday 8.00 pm to Friday (before school).

(b)     It is evident from the above that the Son spends more time with the Husband (4½ days in a week) than the Wife.

(c)     If the Wife is given the right of first option to buy the Flat and she decides to exercise this option, this will affect the Son adversely in two ways. First, he will be spending most of the week living away from the Flat. It is unclear whether the Husband will be able to buy/rent premises with the same level of convenience as the Flat to live with the Son. Second, there is a risk that the child will be spending more time on school days to commute between the Husband’s new residence and the Flat/the Son’s school. All this is not in the child’s interests.

Conclusion

63     To conclude, I make the following orders:

The Flat

(a)     The Husband shall have the right of first option to buy over the Wife’s share in the Flat located at [XXX]. The Wife’s rights, title and interest in the Flat shall be transferred (other than by way of sale) to the Husband with no CPF refunds to be made to the Wife’s CPF account upon –

(i)       The Husband paying, by 31 May 2025, $106,571.56 to the Wife. The Husband shall bear the costs related to the transfer; and

(ii)       The Husband taking over, by 31 May 2025, the Wife’s share of the outstanding loan and being fully responsible for servicing the loan moving forward.

(b)     If the Husband fails to exercise the right of first option by 31 May 2025, then the Wife shall have the option to buy over the Flat. The Husband’s rights, title and interest in the Flat shall be transferred (other than by way of sale) to the Wife with no CPF refunds to be made to the Husband’s CPF account upon –

(i)       The Wife paying, by 30 June 2025, $25,264.40 to the Husband. The Wife shall bear the costs related to the transfer; and

(ii)       The Wife taking over, by 30 June 2025, the Husband’s share of the outstanding loan and being fully responsible for servicing the loan moving forward.

(c)     If the Wife fails to exercise her option by 30 June 2025, then the Flat shall be sold on the open market by 31 December 2025. The sale proceeds shall be applied as follows:

(i)       To make full payment of the outstanding loan.

(ii)       To pay the HDB resale levy (if any).

(iii)       To pay the requisite CPF refunds in accordance with applicable CPF Rules and Regulations to the parties’ respective CPF accounts.

(iv)       To pay all costs and expenses incidental to and relating to the sale of the property.

(v)       The balance sale proceeds shall be divided in the following manner: 80% to the Wife and 20% to the Husband. See [59(f)].

(vi)       The parties shall have joint conduct of the sale of the Flat.

(vii)       Either the Registrar or the Assistant Registrar of the Family Justice Courts under s 31 of the Family Justice Act 2014 is empowered to execute, sign, or endorse all necessary documents relating to matters contained in this order on behalf of either party should either party fail to do so within seven days of written request being made to that party.

Other matrimonial assets

(d)     Each party shall retain all other matrimonial assets in their respective names.

64     Finally, I urge parties to agree on the costs. If there is no such agreement, the parties are to write in to inform the court by 31 March 2025. The court will thereafter hear the parties on costs on a date to be fixed. For the purposes of filing an appeal, time shall start to run from (a) 31 March 2025, or (b) the date the costs order is given, whichever is applicable.

XHU v XHV

XHU v XHV
[2025] SGFC 23

Case Number:Divorce No 182 of 2024 (Summons No 3441 of 2024)
Decision Date:27 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Sabrina Wong Xue Yun, Wong Soo Chih (SC Wong Chambers LLC) for the plaintiff; the defendant in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XHU — XHV

Family Law – Costs

27 February 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my decision on the costs of SUM 3441/2024 (“SUM 3441”) which was the Husband’s application for discovery. My decision in respect of SUM 3441 can be found in XHU v ZHV [2025] SGFC 11.

2       Counsel for the Wife argues that the Husband should have to pay the Wife costs, fixed at $2000 (all-in). They say that the Husband’s application in SUM 3441 was unmeritorious and had “unnecessarily or unreasonably protracted, or added to the costs or complexity of” the divorce proceedings. They also emphasise that the Husband had not pursued his discovery request in good faith.[note: 1]

3       The Husband, on the other hand, after having been reminded to put in his submissions on the costs of SUM 3441, stated that he did “not have any cost to claim”.[note: 2]

4       Where costs are concerned, it is well-established that costs shall follow the event, though the court can depart from this starting point if the circumstances of the case justify doing so: VVB v VVA [2022] SGHCF 1 at [9] and [10] citing Rule 852 and 854 of the Family Justice Rules 2014; XCR v XCS [2024] SGFC 84 at [4] citing WXE v WXF [2024] SGFC 40 at [7] – [8].

5       In the present case, the Wife is entitled to costs. That is because she had successfully resisted the Husband’s application for discovery in SUM 3441. The Husband did not manage to obtain the orders which he sought in SUM 3441.

6       As to the quantum of such costs, that shall be fixed at $600 (all-in). In fixing the quantum of such costs, I take into account the fact that the Husband had only sought discovery in respect of two items, and that the affidavits and submissions were not particularly voluminous. While counsel for the Wife argues that his application was unmeritorious and that it was not taken out in good faith, they have not set out why this is the case, apart from pointing to the fact that this is evident from the Husband’s “haphazard application and pleadings”. In any event, I do not find that the Husband’s conduct warrants an upwards adjustment in the quantum of such costs to be awarded.

7       It is therefore ordered that the Husband shall pay the Wife the sum of $600, being the costs of SUM 3441. This shall be done no later than 10 April 2025.

[note: 1]Wife’s Written Submissions dated 11 February 2025.

[note: 2]Husband’s email to court dated 24 February 2025.

XHS v XHT

XHS v XHT
[2025] SGFC 20

Case Number:D 1052/2021 (FC/SUM 1760/2023)
Decision Date:20 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Chia Wee Kiat
Counsel Name(s): Ms Pearlyn Yeo Qi Yan (Yeo & Associates LLC) for the plaintiff; Ms Roqiyah Begum (Netto and Magin LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XHS — XHT

Family Law – Division of matrimonial assets – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

Family Law – Child – Care and control – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

Family Law – Child – Maintenance – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

20 February 2025

District Judge Chia Wee Kiat:

Background

1       The plaintiff (the “Husband”) and the defendant (the “Wife”) were married on 6 March 2011.[note: 1] The Husband works as a deputy manager[note: 2], and the Wife a lecturer.[note: 3] The parties have a boy, [T], who is aged 13 this year.[note: 4]

2       The Husband filed for divorce on 8 March 2021 under the simplified track.[note: 5] Interim Judgment (“IJ”) was granted on 6 April 2021.[note: 6] Under clause 3 of the IJ, the parties agreed to the following orders (“Consent Order”):

By Consent:

a.    That the Plaintiff and the Defendant be granted joint custody of the child of the marriage, namely [T], with care and control to the Plaintiff.

b.    The Defendant shall have access to the child of the marriage including but not limited to the following:

(i)    Monday 5.30 pm to 8 pm;

(ii)   Wednesday 5.30 pm to 8 pm;

(iii)   Friday 5.30 pm to Saturday 5 pm.

c.    The Defendant’s rights, title and interests in the matrimonial property known as [Property A] shall be transferred (other than by way of sale) to the Plaintiff upon the Plaintiff making the full required CPF refunds into the Defendant’s CPF account(s) and no cash consideration, within six (6) months from the date of the Final Judgment. All expenses relating to the transfer (including conveyancing, stamp, registration and administrative fees of the transfer) shall be borne by the Plaintiff solely. Upon effect of the transfer of the matrimonial property, the outstanding loan (if any) and all expenses relating to the matrimonial property will be borne by the Plaintiff entirely.

d.    The sum of $200,000.00 in parties’ fixed deposit shall be divided equally between the Plaintiff and Defendant.

e.    There shall be no maintenance for the Defendant.

f.    The Plaintiff shall maintain the child of the marriage solely.

g.    (a) The Registrar and/or Assistant Registrar of the Family Justic Courts under Section 31 of the Family Justice Act (No. 27 of 2014) is empowered to execute, sign or indorse all necessary documents relating to matters contained in this order on behalf of either party should either party fail to do so within seven (7) days of written request being made to the party.

(b)    The Plaintiff and the Defendant agree to set up a fund for the child with a deposit of $130,000.00. Mutual written agreement needs to be sought in order to use the said fund. In the future, the Defendant will do a 1-to-1 match deposit to the fund with the Plaintiff if needed.

(c)    The Plaintiff and the Defendant shall each retain all other assets in his/her own names.

(d)    That neither the Plaintiff nor the Defendant shall have any further claim against each other.

(e)    That the above terms shall be in full and final settlement of parties’ claims against each other.

(f)    That there be liberty to apply.

3       The IJ was made final on 9 July 2021. [note: 7]

4       On 2 June 2023, the Wife filed FC/SUM 1706/2023 (“SUM 1706”) seeking, inter alia, the following orders:

To set aside/vary Clauses 3(a) to (g) of the Interim Judgment dated 6 April 2021 (FC/IJ 1555/2021) (the “IJ”) in respect of the consent orders relating to custody, care and control, maintenance for child, division of matrimonial assets (including matrimonial flat).

5       The Wife alleged that the child would “continue to experience verbal and emotional mistreatment, which is a primary motive behind this application.”[note: 8]

6       In brief, the Wife wanted:[note: 9]

(a)     care and control of the child;

(b)     reasonable amount of maintenance for the child; and

(c)     the division of matrimonial assets to be redetermined.

7       SUM 1706 came up for hearing before me on 27 August 2024. In light of the issues raised by parties with respect to [T], I called for a Custody Evaluation Report (“CER”) and reserved my decision.

8       Having received the CER, I fixed the matter for decision on 27 December 2024, which was re-fixed to 13 January 2025 at parties’ request. Shortly before the date of decision, the Wife’s counsel wrote a letter dated 2 January 2025 to the court to “highlight the Plaintiff’s ongoing and hostile conduct”. This invited a reply dated 8 January 2025 from the Husband refuting the Wife’s allegations as “a blatant attempt to mislead the court”. The Wife responded with a rebuttal dated 10 January 2025 “to address the Plaintiff’s numerous misleading and unsubstantiated allegations”.

9       At the resumed hearing on 13 January 2025, I reminded counsel that when the court had reserved judgment as I had done in this case, no new evidence should be presented without the leave of court: see VYP v VYQ [2021] SGHCF 40 (at [36]). I also reminded counsel that it was a discourtesy to the court to make further submission without seeking leave: see VEW v VEV [2022] SGCA 34 (at [9]). As these letters were presented to the court after judgment was reserved, I made it clear that I did not consider the contents of the letters in reaching my decision.

10     When giving my decision, I provided brief grounds to parties and indicated that these might be elaborated on and supplemented with fuller grounds if required. As the Wife has appealed the whole of my decision vide HCF/DCA 8/2025 filed on 24 January 2025, I set out below my full grounds of decision.

Division of matrimonial assets

11     I begin with the Wife’s application to “set aside/vary” the Consent Order in relation to the division of matrimonial assets. The starting point is s 112(4) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“the Charter”), which provides that the court “may, at any time, it thinks fit, extend, vary, revoke or discharge any order made under this section, and may vary any term or condition upon or subject to which any such order has been made”.

12     The Husband submitted that the Wife’s application was confusing as it was not entirely clear if the Wife was trying to set aside the Consent Order or vary the Consent Order.[note: 10]

13     I agreed that clarity was important as the thresholds for setting aside and varying a consent order in relation to the division of matrimonial assets are different. Moreover, the Wife’s application went beyond the division of matrimonial assets. It extended to the setting aside and variation of orders in relation to custody, care and control and child maintenance, for which different provisions and considerations apply. Yet, the entirety of the Wife’s submissions was premised on s 112(4) of the Charter, which is applicable only to the division of matrimonial assets. This was unsatisfactory as it obfuscated the issues that had to be determined by the court.

14     Notwithstanding the deficiency in the Wife’s submissions, I gave careful consideration to the merits of her application in accordance with the applicable provisions and relevant case law with respect to each area of her application.

Whether the Consent Order should be set aside

15     The threshold for setting aside a consent order relating to the division of matrimonial assets was set out in Lee Min Jai v Chua Chew Koon [2005] 1 SLR (R) 548 (“Lee Min Jai”) and discussed in AOO v AON [2011] 4 SLR1169 (at [10]) and AYM v AYL [2013] 1 SLR 924 (“AYM v AYL”) (at [17]).[note: 11] As noted in Lee Min Jai (at [6]), “[a] court would interfere with an order of court obtained by consent, only on just and equitable grounds”.[note: 12] Choo Han Teck J explained (at [5]) as follows:

Under s 112(4) of the Women’s Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Rev Ed), the court “may, at any time it thinks fit, extend, vary, revoke or discharge any order made under this section, and may vary any term or condition upon or subject to which any such order has been made”. But this section, and the authorities referred to by Mr Chia, should not be construed as an invitation to revise the terms of a settlement merely so that they appear more equitable or will be, in fact, more equitable in the objective opinion of the court. Privately settled terms in respect of the ancillary matters in a divorce may not always appear to be fair. But divorce is a very personal matter, and each party would have his own private reasons for demanding, or acquiescing, to any given term or condition in the ultimate settlement. What the court should be alert to, is that one party had not taken an unfair advantage over the other in the course of negotiating and settling the terms. Hence, in Dean v Dean [1978] 3 All ER 758, the court held (as set out in the headnote) that:

[W]here an agreement between the parties had been reached at arm’s length and the parties had been separately advised, the agreement itself would be prima facie evidence of the reasonableness of its terms, and formal discovery would probably be unnecessary.

16     Hence, to set aside a consent order on the division of matrimonial assets under s 112(4) of the Charter, an applicant must prove one of the vitiating factors: see UMM v UML [2018] SGHCF 13 (at [8]).[note: 13] A vitiating factor is a contractual doctrine that includes misrepresentation, mistake, undue influence, duress, unconscionability, as well as illegality and public policy: see TR v TQ [2009] 2 SLR (R) (at [97]). While the precise application of each of the vitiating factors to consent orders made in the matrimonial context has not been definitively decided (see AYM v AYL (at [15])), some of the reasons that have been cited in setting-aside applications include duress, misrepresentation and undue influence: for example, see UMM v UML and ATZ v AUA [2015] SGHC 161 (“ATZ v AUA”) (at [22]). In addition, the absence of full and frank disclosure of material facts by one of the parties may also result in a consent order being set aside: see AYM v AYL (at [31]).[note: 14]

17     In the present case, the Wife claimed that the Consent Order was obtained through “duress, undue influence and misrepresentation” which severely compromised her ability to make a free and informed decision.[note: 15] She sought to set aside the Consent Order on grounds that she categorized as follows: (a) misrepresentation; (b) duress and undue influence; and (c) emotional and psychological coercion.[note: 16]

18     Having carefully considered the evidence before me, I found that the Wife did not satisfy the requisite threshold to set aside the Consent Order. I elaborate on my reasons below, adopting the categories framed by the Wife.

Misrepresentation

(1)   False Legal representation

19     The Wife alleged that the Husband had falsely claimed that the appointed lawyer was acting on behalf of both parties and yet consistently denied the Wife’s requests to communicate directly with the lawyer. This left the Wife without proper legal representation, making her vulnerable to the Husband’s exploitation.[note: 17] In support of her claim, she reproduced the following WhatsApp messages:[note: 18]

2/9/21, 6:58 PM – [H]: It’s our lawyer, basically draft based on what we agree. You want time slot, put in. You want cpf refund, I put in. You want joint account to spell out, I put in.

2/9/21, 6:59 PM – [H]: Ok, then I ask them to draft, you can ask them as you are also the client.

20     The Husband’s position was that there was no such false representation. The involvement of the lawyer was limited to merely drafting the terms based on the discussions between the parties themselves. The Husband said that he was not well versed in legal terminology and mistakenly believed that engaging a lawyer was to ensure the proper handling of all necessary paperwork. During the meeting at his lawyer’s office, it was explicitly stated that the lawyer represented him alone, and the clauses in the IJ were drafted pursuant to parties’ private negotiations and agreement.[note: 19] The Wife was apprised of her right to seek independent legal advice but made a personal decision not to personally engage a lawyer.[note: 20]

21     Further, the Husband said that the Wife had not presented the complete WhatsApp message.[note: 21] He reproduced the following extracts:[note: 22]

[W]    I am uncomfortable with your lawyer, only acting in your benefit without any consideration for [T]

I am already giving you care and control part … all the house and car

who is squeezing who

[H]    It’s our lawyer, basically draft based on what we agree. You want time slot, put in. You want cpf refund, I put in. You want joint account to spell out, I put in.

[W]    all I am asking is to spell out clearly not to have any misunderstanding …

22     As noted by the learned authors in Halsbury’s Laws of Singapore – Contract (Volume 7) (LexisNexis) at [80.172]:

Misrepresentation refers to an untrue or misleading statement that induces the formation of a contract. It may operate as an important defence in the hands of a representee to vitiate a contract …

23     As elaborated at [80.189]:

An essential ingredient of an operative misrepresentation is that it influenced or induced the representee in his decision to enter into the contract. There would be no inducement if the representee did not know of the representation or was aware of its untruth or was not influenced by it, as where he would have entered into the contract even had he known the true facts or where he relied on his own judgment or investigations. Inducement refers to the causal relation, which is a question of fact, between the representation and action on the part of the representee to act.

24     The WhatsApp message produced by the Wife showed that the Husband had represented to her that the lawyer was “our lawyer” and that “you are also the client”. While this was prima facie a misrepresentation, I found no evidence to suggest that it was fraudulently made. When the Wife attended at the lawyer’s office, she was told that the lawyer represented the Husband alone. This was evident from the acknowledgement signed by the Wife in the presence of a Commissioner for Oaths, which stated as follows:[note: 23]

I acknowledge that I have considered the terms of the agreement and have also been informed of my right to seek independent legal advice.

25     The Wife had considered the terms of the agreement and was informed of her right to seek independent legal advice. Given these undisputed facts, the Wife could not be laboring under any misapprehension when she entered into the agreement. The misrepresentation was corrected and could not have influenced or induced her at the material time.

26     Moreover, there was ample evidence to show that the Wife had exercised her own judgment in her negotiations with the Husband. This was borne out by her affidavit, examples of which are reproduced below:[note: 24]

Para 51.

However, when I received the first draft of the divorce documents, I noticed that my access to [T] was stated as “reasonable access”. I confronted the Plaintiff and requested to change the term “reasonable access” to “equal access”… I disagree and demand the equal access as suggested earlier.

Para 52.

When I received the 2nd draft divorce document, the access arrangement was still the same. I confronted the Plaintiff. I requested for liberal access. Finally, parties agreed to “schedule access and reasonable access”.

Para 54.

I confronted the Plaintiff as to his intention of limiting my access as mentioned above. The Plaintiff claimed that he had asked the lawyer to indicate schedule access and reasonable access and claimed that they have missed it.

Para 55.

… I had to repeatedly ask him to include the following: “The Defendant shall have reasonable access to the child of the marriage including at least the following …

Para 56.

The Plaintiff agreed and the same was included in the draft consent order …

Para 67.

During the divorce period, the Defendant’s (sic) initial proposal was to utilize the $200,000 to pay off my CPF monies in which the balance monies of around $70,000 is to be distributed equally. However, I disagreed.

Para 68.

Eventually, parties agreed that the Plaintiff will reimburse my CPF monies utilized for the purchase of the matrimonial flat separately and distribute the monies in the said account equally between parties.

Para 70.

In the Plaintiff’s first few drafts of the divorce documents, the Plaintiff refused to refund my CPF monies utilized for the purchase of the matrimonial flat upon me transferring the matrimonial flat to his name. However, when I found out that in the event, I transfer the matrimonial flat to the Plaintiff’s sole name without him refunding my CPF monies, it would put me into a huge CPF debt of estimated $130,000, I confronted him of the same …

Para 72:

As I did not want to be thrown into six-figure debt with HDB, I had to keep insisting for full CPF refund.

Para 75:

… I refused and demanded that the Plaintiff do a full refund of my CPF monies. The Plaintiff finally agreed to do so …

Para 80.

I proposed the Plaintiff to match my $130,000 amount to make this account $260,000 that cannot be used for [T] living expense nor education …

[Emphasis in bold added]



27     It was clear from the above extracts that the Wife had no difficulty confronting the Husband over matters she disagreed with, would not compromise when she needed to stand firm, was capable of making proposals of her own and possessed the clarity of mind to make considered decisions. Clearly, she was exercising independent judgment. There was no causal relation as such between the misrepresentation and her decision to enter into the agreement.

28     The Wife claimed that without proper legal representation, she was vulnerable to the Husband’s exploitation. The Wife alleged that the Husband exploited her limited knowledge of Singapore’s divorce laws and her cultural background from Thailand, where women’s rights were less protected.[note: 25]

29     However, it was undisputed that she was informed of her right to seek independent legal advice. It was her prerogative to seek help if she needed assistance. It would be inequitable for the Wife to blame the Husband for her lack of legal representation when she could have taken reasonable steps to obtain independent legal advice.

30     As was similarly observed by Debbie Ong J (as she then was) in UMM v UML (at [10]):

Starting with the arguments on the Husband’s capacity to appreciate the documents before him, if the Husband genuinely did not understand the terms of the 1st DCO, he could have sought assistance or expressed that he needed more time to consider them. As noted by the DJ, the Husband is educated, and held the rank of First Warrant Officer in the Singapore Armed Forces before his retirement. I also observe that more than a year elapsed between his signing of the 1st and 2nd DCOs. I emphasise that it is a serious matter for one to sign a legal document before a Commissioner of Oaths or before a lawyer.

31     More pertinently, the picture that emerged from her evidence and the contemporaneous WhatsApp messages between the parties was simply incongruous with the case she tried to make out to the court. I found her to be assertive, and she certainly did not come across as one who could be easily induced, influenced, coerced or exploited. The fact that she was able to get the Husband to concede to her demands spoke for itself.

32     Finally, it should be noted that in a WhatsApp message to the Husband, the Wife herself had acknowledged that “we had good amicable agreement”.[note: 26] This message was sent on 27 September 2021,[note: 27] five months after the Consent Order was recorded. It put beyond doubt that the Husband had not taken any unfair advantage over her in the course of negotiating and settling the terms, and that the agreement reached was consensual. In light of all the evidence, it seemed more likely that the Wife was seeking to take advantage of the innocent misrepresentation by the Husband to advance her case.

(2)   Deception in Custody/Access Matters

33     The Wife also alleged that the Husband misled her about the feasibility of shared custody and control of their child.[note: 28] In support of her claim, she reproduced the following extracts:[note: 29]
