XIG v XIH

XIG v XIH
[2025] SGFC 16

Case Number:No 5888 of 2021
Decision Date:11 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Patrick Tay Wei Sheng
Counsel Name(s): Raymond Yeo (Raymond Yeo) for the applicant; Caryn Lee Ke Wen, Mohamed Baiross, and Chia Ming Yun (I.R.B. Law LLP) for the respondent.
Parties: XIG — XIH

Family Law – Matrimonial Proceedings – Ancillary Matters

11 February 2025

District Judge Patrick Tay Wei Sheng:

1       The spouses married in September 2010. They had a son and a daughter, who were born in February 2011 and in March 2012 respectively. By 2018, the marriage had fallen apart. In December 2021, these divorce proceedings were commenced. Interim judgment of divorce was granted in May 2022 on the ground that each spouse had behaved in a manner that made it intolerable for the other to continue to live with him or her.

2       Despite the differences that led to this divorce, the spouses continued to co-parent their children. They agreed to share the custody of the children. They also agreed that the wife was to have care and control of the children and that the husband was to have access to the children each week, on public holidays and other special occasions, and during the children’s school vacations. This cooperation between the spouses was heartening, and these arrangements recorded in order of court dated August 2022 that was made with the consent of the spouses.

3       I heard the spouses on the remaining ancillary matters, which were the division of the matrimonial assets and the maintenance of the wife and the children. I divided the matrimonial assets 63.5:36.5 in favour of the husband. I also ordered the husband to maintain the wife for two years in the monthly sum of $200 and the children until they attained 21 years of age in the monthly sums of $1,300 for the son and $1,800 for the daughter.

4       The wife is dissatisfied with my decisions on the division of the matrimonial assets other than the matrimonial home and on the maintenance for the children. I now provide my reasons for these decisions.

Matrimonial assets

5       As the Court of Appeal observed in WQP v WQQ [2024] SGHC(A) 34 at [43], the division of matrimonial assets implicates a 4-stage process. First, the identification of the matrimonial assets. Second, the valuation of those matrimonial assets. Third, the determination of the contributions of the spouses to the acquisition of those matrimonial assets. Fourth, the fair apportionment of the matrimonial assets between the spouses.

Identification and valuation of matrimonial assets

6       I began by identifying and valuing the matrimonial assets.

Assets in joint names

7       The matrimonial home was the only asset that the spouses held jointly. The wife is not challenging my decision on the division of the matrimonial home and is challenging on my decision on the division of the other assets. Still, for completeness, and because I had examined all the matrimonial assets (including the matrimonial home globally), I set out my decision on it briefly.

8       The value of the matrimonial home as a matrimonial asset was the difference in the market price of the matrimonial home and the outstanding amount on the loan that had been taken for the purchase of the matrimonial home. The wife submitted that the market value of the matrimonial home was $889,000. The husband submitted that the market value of the matrimonial home was $819,000. In the absence of better evidence on the market value of the matrimonial home and given the relatively small difference between the values put forward by the parties, I took the middle of these two values (ie, $854,000) as the market value of the matrimonial home. The spouses agreed that the outstanding loan on the matrimonial home was $415,736. Accordingly, the value of the matrimonial home in the pool of matrimonial assets was therefore $479,124.

Assets in name of wife

9       I set out the assets in the name of the wife and the values that each spouse ascribed to each of these assets.

10     The spouses agreed that the wife had Central Provident Fund balances of $29,739, a UOB Bank Account with $6,262, a POSB Bank Account with $1,954, 400 Tencent shares with a value of $21,080, and 3,400 Xiaomi shares with a value of $5,864. All these items and their corresponding values were thus included in the pool of matrimonial assets.

11     But the spouses took different views on monies amounting to $148,625 that the wife had withdrawn between January 2019 and September 2022 from her UOB Bank Account and her POSB Bank Account. The wife did not dispute that she had withdrawn these monies but explained that she had spent the monies on the household. The husband disagreed and submitted that these monies should be included in the pool of matrimonial assets that fell to be divided between the spouses.

12     On the evidence of the wife, the marriage had broken down by 2018.[note: 1] The withdrawals, which took place between 2019 and 2022, had been made after the marriage had broken down. Once a marriage had broken down, any substantial sum expended by a spouse other than for daily or run-of-the-mill expenses had to be returned to the asset pool if the monies would otherwise have been matrimonial assets and the other spouse had not consented to the expenditure. Regardless of whether the expenditure was a deliberate attempt to dissipate the monies, or for the benefit of children or relatives, the spouse who made the expenditure had to be prepared to bear it personally and in full (see WOS v WOT [2024] SGHC(A) 11 at [43] and [49] citing TNL v TNK and another appeal and another matter [2017] 1 SLR 609 (“TNL”) at [24]).

13     It was therefore incumbent on the wife to account for the $148,625 as run-of-the-mill expenses and/or show that the husband had consented to the expenditures in question (see WJG v WJH [2022] SGHCF 28 at [29(c)]). Beyond bare assertions that the monies had been spent on the family, however, the wife offered little explanation for the expenditure. Although it was unsurprising that objective or documentary evidence may not have been available to bear out every expenditure in a family, the absence of such evidence to support even the larger withdrawals cast doubt on the credibility of explanations of the wife for the withdrawals as a whole.

14     I set out the notable withdrawals for which the objective evidence did not bear out and/or sat inconsistently with the claims of the wife on them:

(a)     The wife withdrew $15,000 between February and March 2020 and suggested that she had done so to support herself and the children when they moved out of the matrimonial home after the marriage had broken down. But neither the wife nor the children did in fact move out of the matrimonial home, and they continued to reside in the matrimonial home even at the time of these proceedings. Further, it was not in dispute that the husband had supported the family and paid for the outgoings of the household during the marriage, even after the wife had purported to move out of the matrimonial home. This left little need for the wife to withdraw monies to support herself and the children over and beyond that.

(b)     The wife withdrew $16,000 in April 2022 and suggested that she had much of these monies had been spent on course fees of $19,227 for a master’s degree for herself. But these course fees had been paid in two tranches – of $8,471 and $10,756 – with the latter due only in November 2022. And the wife offered no explanation for why she had made a withdrawal in April 2022 to meet course fees that were due over six months thereafter.

(c)     The wife withdrew $20,000 in July 2022 to repay a loan from one “Texas Lee”. But there was no documentary evidence in support of any liability by the wife to pay such a sum. This absence of documentation of the liability was particularly surprising given the relatively large quantum of this expenditure.

(d)     The wife withdrew $13,000 in December 2021, and $12,485 across July and August 2022 and claimed that part of the monies went to paying her legal expenses, ostensibly for these divorce proceedings. But legal fees for divorce proceedings should in principle be paid out of the payor’s share of the matrimonial assets and not the pool of matrimonial assets in general (see WUA v WUB [2024] SGHCF 10 at [8]). Such expenditures had to be added back to the pool of matrimonial assets.

15     Adding the $148,625 that the wife had withdrawn after the marriage had broken down to the other assets in the name of the wife, the value of the assets in the name of the wife totalled $213,524.

Assets in name of husband

16     I set out the assets in the name of the husband and the values that each spouse ascribed to each of these assets.

17     Most of the assets in the name of the husband were not in dispute, whether as to the identity of the assets or the value of the assets. The only assets over which the spouses diverged were 475 shares in Meta Platforms, Inc, a time deposit account in OCBC Bank that the husband held jointly with his mother, and the proceeds of the sale of shares in a business called “[PB]”.

18     The spouses agreed that 475 Meta shares in the name of the husband were matrimonial assets. But they diverged over the date at which those shares were to be valued. The wife submitted that these shares were to be valued at the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters, when these shares were worth $309,415. The husband submitted that these shares were to be valued at the date of the interim judgment in May 2022, when these shares were worth only $76,090. In VQF v VQG [2024] SGHCF 4 (“VQF”) at [1], the Family Division of the High Court observed that the date for ascertaining the pool of matrimonial assets was the date of the interim judgment, which dissolved the marriage. On the other hand, the date for valuing the assets and liabilities in that pool of matrimonial assets, save for money account balances, was the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters, because that date would facilitate the use of the most up-to-date values in ascertaining the economic fruits of the marriage. The husband asserted that the four-fold increase in the value of the Meta shares should accrue solely to him because it was his decision to hold the shares beyond the date of the interim judgment that produced the increase in the value of the shares. But there was little evidence to show, as of the date of the interim judgment, that the husband was assuming solely for himself rather than for the matrimonial pool the consequences of holding the Meta shares beyond that date. Without such evidence, there was little reason to depart from the position in VQF. The date for valuing the 475 Meta shares was thus the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters. At that date, these shares had a value of $309,415.

19     It was also not in dispute that there was a time deposit with OCBC Bank in the names of the husband and his mother that had a monetary balance of $134,800. The wife submitted that this value was to be added to the pool of matrimonial assets. The husband, however, claimed that he had made no contributions to and had no beneficial interest in this time deposit or the monies therein. In support of this claim, the husband adduced an affidavit deposed by his mother in which she repeated the claim of the husband. But the husband as a joint owner of the bank account was entitled to the undivided whole of the monies in that account. On the face of his legal ownership of the account, the monies therein were matrimonial assets. Insofar as the husband asserted that he had no beneficial interest in the account, it was incumbent on him to obtain a determination from the civil courts to that effect because the Family Justice Courts were unable to adjudicate on a claim by a third party to a putative matrimonial asset (see UDA v UDB and another [2018] 1 SLR 1015 at [44]). But there was no such determination before me. Beyond the bare and self-serving assertions of the husband and his mother, there was no evidence to show that, despite the legal interest of the husband in that account, he had no beneficial interest in the monies in that account. I thus included that account in the pool of matrimonial assets and valued it at $134,800.

20     It finally appeared that the husband had received approximately $20,000 from the [PB] business. He had received this sum in two tranches, which were a fortnight apart, in September 2021, which was shortly before these divorce proceedings were commenced in December 2021. Scant explanation was offered to account for these monies. In my view, these monies were matrimonial assets.

21     Adding the values of the Meta shares ($309,415), the OCBC Time Deposit ($134,800), and the proceeds of the sale of the [PB] business shares ($20,000) to the other assets in the name of the husband, the total value of the assets in the name of the husband was $927,175.

Division of matrimonial assets

22     Based on my findings above, the pool of matrimonial assets comprised $479,124 in assets in the joint names of the spouses, $213,524 in assets in the sole name of the wife, and $927,175 in assets in the sole name of the husband. The value of the pool of matrimonial assets thus totalled $1,619,825.

23     The exercise of dividing matrimonial assets sought to fairly apportion the economic fruits of the marriage between the spouses by duly recognising their breadwinning and homemaking contributions to the marriage, in line with the philosophy that marriage was an equal partnership (see TNL at [45]). Two different approaches applied based on the nature of the breadwinning and homemaking arrangements in the marriage. In general, the “structured” approach in ANJ v ANK [2015] SGCA 34 (“ANJ”) was used, whereunder the court ascertained ratios representing: (a) the spouses’ direct contributions to the acquisition of the matrimonial assets; and (b) the spouses’ indirect contributions to the welfare of the family. These two ratios would then be averaged and necessary adjustments to the weightage of each ratio could be made to reach a fair and just division of the matrimonial assets. But the ANJ approach would not be applied in long single-income marriages because it over-recognised the financial contributions of the breadwinner and under-recognised the non-financial contributions of the homemaker. Instead, the division exercise in such circumstances tended to centre on the indirect contributions of the homemaking spouse, and the weight to be ascribed to these indirect contributions would be broadly proportional to the length of the marriage. Hence, the final ratios of division ranged from 50:50 (in long single-income marriages of 25–35 years’ duration) to 75:25 in favour of the breadwinner (in shorter single-income marriages of 10–15 years’ duration).

24     The observations of the Court of Appeal in BOR v BOS and another appeal [2018] SGCA 78 (“BOR”) at [111]–[113] were instructive:

111    … In TNL v TNK, this court observed that the trend in long single-income marriages had tended towards an equal division of matrimonial assets, but different considerations may attach to short single-income marriages (at [48]). To give some context to the terms “long” and “short”, TNL v TNK itself involved a marriage of some 35-years. The cases which the court referred to as relevant precedents involved marriages of between 26 to 30 years.

112    The marriage in the present case lasted about 11 and a half years, much shorter than the examples which the court discussed in TNL v TNK. Different considerations apply to such mid-length marriages. As we stated in ANJ v ANK at [27] (albeit in the context of discussing the structured approach), as a general rule, the longer the marriage, the more weight is given to the parties’ indirect contributions. Conversely, the shorter the marriage, the less weight will be ascribed to indirect contributions.

113    We find that the precedents are generally consistent with this principle. Thus, in ATT v ATS [2012] 2 SLR 859 at [18], we observed that the trend in “moderately lengthy marriages” was towards awarding the homemaker wife about 35% to 40% of the matrimonial assets. It would appear from the examples discussed that what was meant by “moderately lengthy” was a period in the range of around 15–18 years. For marriages of shorter duration (around 10–15 years), the trend appears to be towards awarding the non-income earning party about 25% to 35% of the matrimonial pool. Thus in UGG v UGH (m.w.) [2017] SGHCF 25, which involved a marriage of 12 and a half years, a Wife who had made minimal direct financial contributions was awarded 31.35% of the pool of matrimonial assets. In ABX v ABY and others [2014] 2 SLR 969, which involved a marriage of nine years, the homemaker wife was awarded 25% of the pool of the matrimonial assets.

25     Nevertheless, as the Family Division of the High Court cautioned in UBM v UBN [2017] 4 SLR 921, a litigant could not focus excessively on categorising a marriage as one that was single-income or dual-income. Rather, the court was ultimately guided by the philosophy that a marriage was an equal partnership, and equal and sufficient recognition had to be paid to both breadwinning and homemaking contributions. The power of dividing matrimonial assets would therefore be exercised in broad strokes.

26     This caution was apposite in these proceedings, where the wife had worked periodically for a total duration of approximately a year within the 11-year marriage. At the time of these proceedings, too, the wife was actively looking for employment and had found employment by the conclusion of these proceedings. Still, the wife submitted that the TNL approach for long single-income marriages should apply,[note: 2] and that she should be awarded 50% of the matrimonial assets.[note: 3] But given the relatively short duration of the marriage, one year of work by the wife was not insubstantial. This marriage therefore did not fit squarely within the TNL framework for long single-income marriages. The structured approach in ANJ was thus, by default, the appropriate one to take.

Direct contributions

27     The husband, who was a breadwinner throughout the marriage, paid for the matrimonial home that had a value of $479,124 and the matrimonial assets in his name that had a value of $927,175. The wife, who worked for a year during the marriage, financed the matrimonial assets in her name that had a value of $213,524. The ratio of the direct contributions of the spouses was thus 87:13 in favour of the husband.

Indirect contributions

28     For the indirect contributions of the spouses, the marriage had lasted 11 years and the wife had been the primary caregiver to the two children throughout the marriage. The husband, who was the primary breadwinner, travelled regularly for work. Yet he paid the expenses of the household, oversaw the acquisition and fitting out of the matrimonial home, and engaged domestic helpers to assist the wife with her homemaking. As the husband submitted, these indirect contributions of his helped the wife with her homemaking and freed her to obtain educational qualifications including a diploma and a master’s degree, as well as pursue full-time jobs (albeit for limited periods of time). On balance, a fair apportionment of the indirect contributions of the spouses was 60:40 in favour of the wife.

Fair and equitable division

29     Taking the average of the ratios of the direct and indirect contributions of the spouses, the final ratio was 63.5:36.5 in favour of the husband.

30     The wife urged me to award her at least a 5% uplift in this final ratio by drawing an adverse inference against the husband for a lack of full and frank disclosure of his assets. She claimed that he had provide piecemeal responses to her applications for discovery and interrogatories and had been less than candied on his transactions especially in relation to his OCBC Time Deposit and his investment in the [PB] business. But the disclosure provided by the husband in discovery and interrogatories, even if occasionally piecemeal, was generally complete. Further, it was more principled, given that the values of the OCBC Time Deposit and the proceeds from the [PB] business shares were known, to add those values to the pool of matrimonial assets rather than to provide an impressionistic uplift to the final ratio of division in favour of the wife.

31     I thus awarded the wife a 36.5% share of the $1,619,825 pool of matrimonial assets.

32     For completeness, if this marriage were classified, as submitted by the wife, as a single-income marriage, the approach in TNL would apply. Thereunder, given the 11-year length of the marriage, the wife would likely have received 25-30% of the pool of matrimonial assets. This would have been less favourable for the wife than the 36.5% share of the pool of matrimonial assets that she would receive pursuant to the structured approach in ANJ. But given that the purpose of the TNL approach (as an exception to the default ANJ approach) was to provide due recognition to the homemaking contributions in single-income marriages, it would be justified to grant the wife, who was the primary homemaker here, the more generous of the awards under the TNL approach and the ANJ approach. Accordingly, I awarded her 36.5% of the pool of matrimonial assets.

Maintenance

33     At the time of these proceedings, the husband and the wife were each approximately 50 years of age. The husband earned a monthly income of $10,737. The wife earned a monthly income of $3,500.[note: 4]

34     For wife maintenance, the wife had earned a monthly income of $6,600 before the divorce, had lost that employment thereafter, and had found work only during the hearing of the ancillary matters at a monthly income of $3,500. It was commendable that the wife had made efforts to find such gainful employment, because the law encouraged former wives to seek employment to defray their personal expenses and contribute to preserve their pre-divorce lifestyles and standards of living (see Quek Lee Tiam v Ho Kim Swee (alias Ho Kian Guan) [1995] SGHC 23 at [21]–[22] and ARY v ARX and another appeal [2016] 2 SLR 686 at [13]). Still, the difference between the monthly income of the wife before and after the divorce was substantial. It was thus just to have the husband contribute to the reasonable expenses of the wife while she found her feet after the divorce. Taking account of the not insubstantial share of the matrimonial assets that the wife would receive, I ordered the husband to maintain the wife for two years in the monthly sum of $200.

35     For child maintenance, the wife sought a monthly sum of $3,250 for each child and asked that the husband further “bear the children’s mandatory education expense including school fees, school trips and any extra lessons and/or programs organized by the school”. She added that the maintenance should be payable until the children complete their tertiary education and attain their first tertiary degree.[note: 5] The husband proposed monthly figures of child maintenance of $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter.

36     At the outset, I found it unjustified at this juncture to have the husband maintain the children beyond the age of 21 years, which was the age upon which child maintenance obligations terminate unless otherwise ordered by the court (see s 69(6) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed)). The children were 13 and 11 years of age respectively. There was no certainty that they would be pursuing education beyond 21 years of age. As the Family Court in XFP v XFQ [2024] SGFC 97 observed at [10]–[12], maintenance catered to present and certain financial needs and not potential or uncertain aspirational wants. Absent certainty that the children would be pursing tertiary education, it would be unjustified to order maintenance to that effect.

37     As for the quantum of maintenance, the wife offered no breakdown for how each child spent $3,250 per month. Instead, she tabulated a detailed list of what she called “nocturnal activities” on the part of the husband then demanded that he put up $6,500 each month for the children.[note: 6] She appeared to premise her claim for $3,250 per child per month on the basis that the husband should be fully responsible for maintaining the children because he had a higher earning capacity than her.

38     The husband, on his part, likewise offered few specifics on the expenses of each child beyond asserting that $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter comprised 62% of the reasonable expenses of each of them.

39     Based on the submissions of the spouses, the following expenses of the children were not in dispute:

(a)     Student care: $245 per month per child

(b)     School transport: $123 per month per child

(c)     Pocket money: $160 per month per child

40     Over and above these sums, the wife justified her claims for child maintenance on the basis that the children attended tuition and incurred expenditures on “daily living necessities such as food and grocery expenses, transportation costs, personal care, clothing and other miscellaneous needs”.[note: 7] For tuition, in particular, the wife submitted that the son incurred $1,434 each month while the daughter incurred $450 each month.

41     As between the submissions of the husband and the wife on child maintenance, I found the submissions of the husband more credible. Even as neither spouse provided detailed breakdowns of the expenses of each child, the submissions of the wife were more difficult to accept for three reasons. First, she claimed that the reasonable expenses of each child were the same when, on her own calculations, the son spent approximately $1,000 more than the daughter on tuition each month and the other expenses of each child were broadly similar. Second, on the calculations of the wife, the daughter would be spending over $2,000 each month just on food and groceries, clothing, and other miscellaneous needs, which estimate was objectively high. Third, the wife appeared to premise her claim for child maintenance on the basis that the husband should maintain the children solely when the maintenance of children is a joint parental responsibility and she was not without earning capacity. Indeed, at the time of these proceedings, the wife was seeking work at the Singapore Corporate Counsel Association.

42     I thus preferred the estimates of the husband as to the reasonable expenses of the children and his proposals to pay $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter each month. The maintenance of the children was a joint parental responsibility, and the wife was not without financial resources to play her part in discharging that responsibility given the not insignificant amount of matrimonial assets that she would receive as well as the employment income that she had recently secured. Still, the wife would, even when she secured employment, require some time to settle into a breadwinning role after serving as a homemaker for much of the marriage. I thus ordered the husband to maintain the children in amounts that were slightly higher than those that he had put forward. The husband was thus to maintain the children until they attained 21 years of age in the monthly sums of $1,300 for the son and $1,800 for the daughter.

Conclusion

43     I thus made the following orders:

(a)     The pool of matrimonial assets, which had a value of, was to be divided in the proportions of 62.5% to the husband and 36.5% to the wife.

(b)     The husband was to maintain the wife in the monthly sum of $200 for two years.

(c)     The husband was to maintain the children until they attained 21 years of age in the monthly sums of $1,300 for the son and $1,800 for the daughter.

44     I made no order on the costs of these proceedings.
